HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Up 0.3%, Mostly Because of Gasoline 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose by a modest 0.3 percent in September, mostly reflecting higher gasoline prices, the Labor Department announced Thursday.
 Another report showed that production at factories, mines and utilities rebounded. 
 The latest reading on the Consumer Price Index, the government's most closely watched inflation barometer, should ease somewhat concerns by Federal Reserve policy makers about deflation, an economically dangerous and widespread weakness in prices. 
The report from the Federal Reserve on production showed that industrial output rose 0.4 percent in September, a turnaround from the disappointing 0.1 percent drop registered in August.
At factories, output rose 0.7 percent in September led by an increase in automobile production; production at mines was flat; and output at utilities fell 2.2 percent. 
Excluding energy and food prices, which tend to swing widely from month to month, core consumer prices edged up by just 0.1 percent in September for the second consecutive month. That showing on the core inflation rate suggested that most other prices were moderate.
In a second report from the department, new claims for unemployment insurance dropped for the second consecutive week, offering a hopeful sign that the pace of layoffs is slowing.
For the workweek ended Saturday, new applications for jobless benefits dipped by a seasonally adjusted 4,000, to 384,000, the lowest level since early February. The week before, claims fell by 17,000. 
The three economic reports depicted an economy that is perking up and for the most part is enjoying a stable price climate. 
"The reports should cheer those who have been hoping for signs of a more robust expansion," said Carl Tannenbaum, chief economist at LaSalle Bank. The Federal Reserve, he said, is likely to keep short-term interest rates at a 45-year low of 1 percent through the rest of this year. 
The Social Security Administration announced Thursday that benefit recipients will get a 2.1 percent cost-of-living increase next year, providing an extra $19 a month for the typical retiree.
Next year's raise is up from this year's increase of 1.4 percent, but continues to reflect an economy with inflation at a low ebb. 
In the overall inflation report, even with the recent increases in the C.P.I., Fed policy makers have expressed more concern about inflation going down, rather than up. 
For the 12 months ended in September, consumer prices rose 2.3 percent, compared with a 2.4 percent rise for all of last year. Core prices, meanwhile, went up just 1.2 percent, the smallest increase since 1966, and down from a 1.9 percent advance for all of 2002. 
The weakness in core prices is a byproduct of a lackluster economic climate seen last year and earlier this year. That climate had made it difficult for some companies to raise prices. 
Energy prices rose 3 percent in September led by a 6.3 percent jump in gasoline prices. 
In other economic news, businesses cut inventories by 0.4 percent in August and sales dropped 0.2 percent, a sign that companies have not totally let go of their wariness about the economy's direction.
And a survey by the Business Roundtable, an association of company leaders, found that chief executives were optimistic.

HEADLINE: Windsor Journal; 
Doctors Eying the U.S.: Canada Is Sick About It

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: WINDSOR, Ontario, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
Drs. Siva Sriharan and Srinivas Chakravarthi may never get rich staying in this small auto-producing city little more than a stone's throw from downtown Detroit, but they can eat all the hamburgers, ribs and potato skins they want for the rest of their lives at Casey's Bar and Grill.
 For the next year, they can also get their hair cut free at the Touch of Class beauty salon, and lease a Pontiac Grand Am without charge from a dealer in nearby Essex. Patients have pledged free house repairs and landscaping for their properties, and nurses have teased them with offers of free massages. 
 All the two doctors have to do is continue practicing medicine in Windsor.
Residents started proffering gifts when rumors leaked out of Hotel-Dieu Grace Hospital a few weeks ago that the two neurosurgeons -- of the four serving the city -- were toying with moving their practice to the United States.
"It's not about the money," said Dr. Sriharan, a 38-year-old immigrant from Sri Lanka. "We can't do our job properly with operating room time so extremely limited here."
Forced to compete for operating room time with other surgeons, he said that he and his colleague could complete only one or two operations on some days, meaning that patients whose cases were not emergencies could go months or even years before completing necessary treatment.
"Scarce resources are simply not being spent properly," Dr. Sriharan concluded, citing a shortage of nurses and anesthesiologists in the hospital where the single microscope available is old and breaking down.
The two surgeons are sharply critical of Canada's health care system, which is driven by government-financed insurance for all but increasingly rations service because of various technological and personnel shortages. Both doctors said they were fed up with a two-tier medical system in which those with connections go to the head of the line for surgery.
"It's the system that is pushing us out," said Dr. Chakravarthi, a 53-year-old Indian immigrant.
Many other Canadian doctors feel the lure of the United States these days, particularly if they live close to the border.
The supply of family doctors has increased at a rate lower than population growth in recent years, a problem that is complicated by an aging population and doctors seeking shorter hours. Waiting time for elective surgery is growing across the country, and becoming a hot political issue.
Meanwhile, there are signs that a brain drain of medical talent, particularly specialists to the United States,is becoming a serious problem.
There was a net migration of 49 neurosurgeons from Canada from 1996 to 2002, according to the Canadian Institute for Health Information, a large loss given that there are only 241 neurosurgeons in the country.
"Physicians across Canada are in an advanced stage of burnout due to work conditions," said Dr. Sunil V. Patel, president of the Canadian Medical Association, who attributed much of the problem to technological shortages and the powerlessness doctors feel when patients complain about long waits for treatment. "That burnout causes them to retire early or pull away from certain kinds of work or simply leave."
John O'Kane, 46, the owner of Casey's Bar and Grill, is leading the local crusade to keep the two neurosurgeons in Windsor. His offer of free food is rooted in personal experience; he is convinced that superior surgery performed on him last year by Dr. Sriharan to remove a broken piece of a spinal disk rubbing against a sciatic nerve is the reason he can again play ice hockey and tennis.
So far the doctors have not come by for any free food, nor have they responded to any of the other offers that have followed.
"For all I know they are vegetarians," Mr. O'Kane said with a laugh. (In fact, Dr. Chakravarthi is.)
The grass-roots surge of offers and almost daily letters to the editor published in the local newspaper urging the surgeons to stay put has not gone unnoticed by local politicians. Windsor's mayor, Mike D. Hurst, has speeded up a physician recruitment and retention initiative to combat local shortages of medical manpower.
"The popular response is an indication," he said, "that there is pure fear in our community of not having qualified, professional medical expertise available when it's needed."
As for the two surgeons, they say that while they are touched and embarrassed, they do not see how they can continue to work at the hospital under the present conditions.
But are they tempted by all the offers?
"Well," Dr. Sriharan smiled in a mock sigh. "I hear those girls at the beauty salon do very good highlights."

HEADLINE: Bolivia's Poor Proclaim Abiding Distrust of Globalization 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
The many Indian protesters who choked the streets and highways of this Andean nation again on Thursday may be poor and speak broken or accented Spanish, but they have a powerful message. 
 It is this: no to the export of gas and other natural resources; no to free trade with the United States; no to globalization in any form other than solidarity among the downtrodden peoples of the developing world. 
 The force of that message may yet topple President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, who tried to quell the unrest by offering a package of concessions late Wednesday night that the protesters rejected. 
Instead they vowed to continue with demonstrations meant to force his government to abandon a plan to export natural gas to the United States through a port in Chile. The protests have already left more than 80 people dead over the past month. 
Sensing that public support for the president, weak to begin with, has all but vanished, opponents of the gas export plan have now moved to press their advantage. 
"The blood that has been spilled is something sacred," Felipe Quispe, leader of the indigenous group that initiated the protests, said in response to Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's offer, made in a televised speech. "So we can't negotiate and we're not even going to talk."
Several thousand workers, mostly miners from the south and coca growers from the north, were reported to be marching on the capital Thursday. The armed forces demanded that they disperse, saying that the military would erect barricades to prevent them from entering La Paz, but the warning appeared to have gone unheeded.
More than merely threatening the longevity of Bolivia's government, the protesters have lent new energy to the discontent already percolating throughout the region. 
Across South America, labor unions, student and civic groups and a new wave of leaders -- Hugo Chavez in Venezuela, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in Brazil, and Nestor Kirchner in Argentina -- are expressing similar doubts about who actually benefits from a free flow of international trade and investment. 
But nowhere have those doubts been expressed as forcefully as in this poor nation of eight million people, increasingly divided along class and racial lines. A majority of Bolivians have Indian blood, descended from the original inhabitants of this continent who got a foretaste of globalization centuries ago with the age of exploration and the arrival of European colonizers.
"Globalization is just another name for submission and domination," Nicanor Apaza, 46, an unemployed miner, said at a demonstration this week in which Indian women in bowler hats and colorful layered skirts carried banners denouncing the International Monetary Fund and demanding the president's resignation. "We've had to live with that here for 500 years, and now we want to be our own masters." 
He and many other protesters see an unbroken line from this region's often rapacious colonial history to the failed economic experiments of the late 20th century, in which Bolivia was one of the first Latin American countries to open itself to the modern global economy. The $5 billion gas pipeline project is only the latest gambit.
Starting with the end of a military dictatorship two decades ago, Bolivia embraced the free-market model. State-owned companies were sold off. Foreign investment was courted. Government regulation was reduced, all in the name of a new era of growth and prosperity. 
The policies brought to heel runaway inflation. But otherwise, the average Bolivian has had little to show for the government's embrace of policies urged on it by the United States, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, now the focus of so much resentment. 
Exports have actually declined compared with their level 25 years ago. Growth has stalled for the past five years. Unemployment has soared, and Bolivia remains the poorest country in South America, with a per capita income of less than $950 a year -- by some calculations, less than it was before the free-market reforms. "After 21 years, the economic model in place has not solved the problems of poverty and social exclusion," said Carlos Toranzo of the Latin American Institute for Research here. 
The leading spokesman for the discontented here is Evo Morales, the charismatic 43-year-old leader of the coca growers' federation. As presidential candidate, he finished barely one percentage point behind Mr. Sanchez de Lozada in the election last year after a campaign that called for reversing the economic course. 
While few development experts see much benefit from reinforcing economic barriers around an already landlocked nation, talk of self-reliance has taken on great appeal.
"If you talk to average people about the Free Trade Area of the Americas or even the gas export law, they really don't know that much about them," said Eduardo Gamarra, a Bolivian scholar who is director of the Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies at Florida International University in Miami. "But Evo Morales and others have shrewdly used those ideas as a flag which plays on their deepest fears, the loss of identity and the giving away of what they consider to be their national patrimony." 
At a recent regional anti-globalization forum in Argentina, Mr. Morales maintained that the United States and multinational companies have "a plan to exterminate the Indian" in order to seize control of the riches of Bolivia and neighboring countries. 
"How much longer will the natural resources of Latin America remain in the hands of transnational companies?" he asked.
That suspicion is rooted deep in this country's bitter history. In the colonial era, silver from the mines of Potosi provided Spain with the wealth that allowed it to forge a global empire, and in modern times, tin made a few families, like the Patinos, fabulously wealthy.
"The wealth has always left the country and enriched foreigners, rather than staying here to improve our lives," said Pascuala Velazquez, an egg vendor of Aymara Indian descent, "but we cannot allow that to happen this time with the gas."
Rather than export gas and other resources, the protesters insist that they be used to help build an industrial base. But Bolivia does not have the money to carry out such a program on its own, and as a diplomat who represents a South American country asked, "Who in their right mind is going to be willing to invest in a country that is so unstable and hostile to foreign capital?" 
Perhaps another president could have convinced Bolivians of the merits of the gas project, expected to quadruple the country's exports over the next decade. But Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, 73, a loyal ally of Washington and a millionaire former mining executive, is regarded here as so much a puppet of the foreign and domestic economic interests that his every word is suspect.
One demonstrator, Remberto Clavijo, a shoe repairman of Quechua Indian descent, said, "He has governed this country for the benefit of the gringos and the multinational companies and the Chileans, not for the Bolivian people."

HEADLINE: Bill Would Penalize Colleges on High Tuition Rises 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Putting educators on notice, one of the Republican lawmakers overseeing higher education legislation in the House introduced a bill yesterday that would withhold federal money from colleges that raised tuition much faster than inflation, a category that could include hundreds of universities. 
 The congressman, Howard P. McKeon, a California Republican and a senior member of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, warned that as many as two million low-income students would be barred from pursuing postsecondary degrees in the next decade if college costs remained unchecked. 
 To keep that from happening, Mr. McKeon said his bill would create a government watch list of public and private universities that raised their tuition and fees more than twice the rate of inflation for three years in a row. If the offenders still did not curb their costs after another three years, they could lose their eligibility for millions of dollars in federal grants and programs under the bill. 
"I'm not just trying to make enemies for nothing," said Mr. McKeon, chairman of a subcommittee that has taken up the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act. "What I'm hoping is that we really get the attention of thousands of schools across the country, that they understand that this is a serious issue." 
Even before the legislation was introduced, it had become perhaps the most heavily debated and controversial issue surrounding reauthorization of the Higher Education Act. The proposal has inspired sympathy from Republicans, frustration from Democrats and an atmosphere akin to panic from colleges.
If the bill was in effect today, no fewer than 225 public universities, 470 private colleges and 625 for-profit trade schools would be placed on the watch list, according to the American Council on Education, an industry group. That is 24 percent of the nation's postsecondary institutions, the council said. House Education Committee staff members said the tally showed how rampant the problem of escalating tuition is.
"That obviously means that hundreds of schools are engaged in exorbitant tuition increases that hurt parents and students," said David Schnittger, a spokesman for the committee.
In their defense, colleges and universities argue that most of their costs are driven by expenses over which they have no control, like double-digit jumps in health care premiums or utility costs.
Beyond that, public universities contend that putting sanctions on them would be particularly unfair, since their tuition is mainly going up to compensate for deep cuts in state spending on higher education. They also point out that most public universities do not even control their own tuitions, but have them set by governors, legislatures or other publicly appointed bodies. Yet Mr. McKeon's bill would penalize them anyway.
Most important, the colleges argue, the legislation would ultimately hurt the very students it is intended to help. Although Mr. McKeon's bill would not withhold federal Pell grants and Stafford loans, two primary sources of assistance to low-income students, several other programs would be withdrawn. In particular, campuses could be cut off from federal money that helped pay student workers, provided scholarships and furnished low-interest loans to those in need of financial aid. 
"The federal government lacks a policy mechanism to control tuition without simultaneously hurting low- and middle-income students," said Terry W. Hartle, senior vice president of the American Council on Education. "There is simply no easy way for the federal government to penalize the schools without simultaneously taking away money for students. That's all it can really do."

HEADLINE: Ford Reports Narrower Loss For the Quarter 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Buoyed by its financial operations and cost-cutting, the Ford Motor Company said Thursday that it had narrowed its loss and handily beat Wall Street estimates for the second consecutive quarter.
 The company raised its operating earnings goal for the full year, from 70 cents a share to 95 cents to $1.05 a share. 
 "We continue to make significant progress on cutting costs, building relationships and launching great products," William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
For the third quarter, the company reported a net loss of $25 million, or 1 cent a share, compared with a net loss of $326 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier. Ford's operating profit of 13 cents a share was well ahead of the consensus analysts' estimate for an 11-cent loss, as compiled by Thomson First Call. 
Ford's earnings report indicated progress, but also left much to fix at a company that lost $6.4 billion in 2001 and 2002. Several of Ford's problems are common among the Big Three automakers, though General Motors has shown the healthiest operating results of the group in recent years.
But both G.M. and Ford, the world's two largest automakers, have been struggling to make money in their primary business. Not only is a price war sapping profits in the crucial North American market, but foreign competitors like Toyota and Honda are taking market share with far lower levels of incentive spending.
Ford and G.M. are also leaning heavily on their financing operations for profit. In the third quarter, Ford Credit, Ford's lending division, reported pretax profit of $809 million, up about 75 percent from a year earlier, though analysts are doubtful the pace is sustainable.
"Rates are starting to move up, so their borrowing costs are as low as they're going to get," said Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, referring to Ford Credit's own cost of borrowing money. He added that Ford had also been scaling back its leasing program and its lending to people with poor credit histories, which means there will be fewer loans to generate income in the future.
Ford's worldwide automotive operations reported a pretax loss of $609 million, just a $9 million improvement from a year earlier. As with G.M., operations in Asia, driven by the surging China market, were the highlight of Ford's third quarter. While operations in Europe and South America lost money, Ford eked out a $1 million pretax profit in Asia.
Of most concern to analysts is the company's $116 million loss in North America. Despite heady industry sales in the United States, where automakers expect to sell close to 17 million cars and trucks this year, the Big Three have struggled to make money in their home market.
"They're making some progress on the cost side but they have a lot of progress left to make, here and abroad," Mr. Girsky, the Morgan Stanley analyst, said of Ford. "At the end of the day you have a car business that's barely profitable this year in a 17 million market."
Ford executives say their new version of the F-150 pickup truck, which recently went on sale, will bolster results. The F-Series line, which is mostly made up of F-150's, is the most popular vehicle of any kind in the nation and a critical profit center for Ford.
Don R. Leclair, Ford's chief financial officer, also said the company saw "the U.S. economy beginning to show signs of strengthening" but also saw the Big Three price war as likely to intensify.
To compensate, Ford increased its cost-cutting target for 2003 to $3 billion from $2.5 billion.
"We're all, year to date, down a few tenths of a point of share," said Lloyd E. Hansen, Ford's vice president for revenue management, referring to the market shares of Ford, G.M. and the Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler. "I think there will be a pretty healthy battle as we go through the fourth quarter and incentives will continue to stay strong."

HEADLINE: Times Company's Earnings Slipped 15% inThird Quarter 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter fell 15 percent, as costs of paper and health care rose and advertising revenues slumped during July and August.
 The company posted net income of $50.1 million, or 33 cents a share, down from $59 million, or 38 cents a share, for the third quarter of 2003. Revenue rose 4 percent in the latest quarter, to $759.3 million, from $729.5 million in the period a year earlier. 
 In addition to its flagship paper, The Times Company owns 18 other newspapers (including The Boston Globe and The International Herald Tribune) and eight network-affiliated television stations.
The company had warned investors last month that because advertising demand was weaker than expected, its earnings would probably fall short of the 39 cents that Wall Street analysts had been predicting. At that time, executives had predicted earnings of 30 to 32 cents. But the company said yesterday that it beat that estimate by a penny partly because advertising had picked up since Labor Day.
The Times Company said September advertising revenue at its newspaper group -- excluding results from The Herald Tribune, an acquisition that The Times did not complete until January -- increased 2.3 percent compared with the month a year ago. Advertisements from entertainment, telecommunications, transportation and technology companies fueled those gains. Advertising revenue for the quarter grew 0.5 percent.
"We feel we are climbing out of the gloomier days of the advertising recession," Russell T. Lewis, the company's president and chief executive, said in a conference call with analysts. 
Company executives acknowledged that not all advertising indicators were positive last month. Retail advertising linage in The Times fell 4.7 percent in September from the month a year earlier, pulled down by the cautious spending of department stores. The company said, however, that it anticipated "strong" placements for the remainder of the year from chains like Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus and Marshall Field's.
The losses in retail advertising last month were more severe at the company's New England newspapers (down 11 percent compared with a year ago) and its regional newspapers (down 5.6 percent.) 
Classified advertising linage was also lower in September at the company's flagship newspaper compared with a year earlier (a drop of 10.9 percent), a function of the sluggish job market. The losses in classified advertising were less severe at its New England newspapers (2.7 percent) and regional newspapers (0.9 percent.)
The company alsoreported some success in the third quarter in its continuing effort to reduce expenses. Still, it said newsprint expenses rose 13.1 percent, compared with the period a year earlier. 
The Times Company's shares closed at $47.09, up $1.40, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Times Tower Is Delayed As Partner Awaits Loan 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would delay construction of a new headquarters on Eighth Avenue until its development partner obtains financing for the 52-story project.
 The Times said its partner, Forest City Ratner, had had difficulty obtaining a construction loan in the current economy for the portion of the tower that Ratner will own. The tower will be on Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets. 
 Russell T. Lewis, chief executive of the Times Company, said in a conference call yesterday with stock analysts that he did not anticipate moving into the new building until late 2006 or early 2007, about two years later than the company had originally anticipated.
Last month, the partners took possession of the property across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal where the skyscraper will be built. The 55 businesses on the site have all been relocated. But Forest City has been unable to land an anchor tenant for its space. Its negotiations with city officials for special tax-free financing known as Liberty Bonds are also at a standstill.
"Obviously it's a difficult climate for large commercial projects of that nature," Mr. Lewis said. "As long as there's no financing, the project will not go forward. We certainly expect that the market will improve in the future and then we would be prepared to move forward. Projecting exactly what will happen is not something I want to do."
But later in the day, Michael Golden, vice chairman and senior vice president of the Times Company, said he expected that Forest City would be able to get financing within the next year.
More than two years ago, the Times Company and Forest City reached a deal with the state's 42nd Street Development Project to build a new headquarters. The Times will own the 2nd through 27th floors, about 875,000 square feet, while Forest City will own the upper floors, about 725,000 square feet.
The partners are required to pay the acquisition costs of the land, but are liable only for $85.6 million. Anything above that will be refunded with interest over time. They are also required to demolish the existing structures and begin construction within a year after taking over the property.
But with rents falling and vacancy rates at relatively high levels, Forest City has not found a prime tenant. 
In recent months, Forest City began negotiating with city officials for $400 million in Liberty Bonds, which were designated for rebuilding New York after the attack on the trade center. Forest City ultimately applied for $150 million in bonds, but has been unable to get city approval.
Forest City declined to comment yesterday.
Some good government groups, urban planners and executives involved in downtown rebuilding have criticized plans to use Liberty Bonds they say were meant for Lower Manhattan. Regulations may allow it, they say, but Forest City should be forced to live by the deal it struck more than two years ago.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Slumping Sun Microsystems Posts Wider Loss

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
Showing continued signs of trouble, Sun Microsystems Inc. reported a wider loss yesterday for its fiscal first quarter and said that year-over-year sales declined for the 10th consecutive quarter. Company executives attributed the problem to continuing softness in corporate spending and said they had no plans to restructure or lay off workers.
 "We face an economic environment that has not improved and a difficult competitive landscape," Steve McGowan, Sun's chief financial officer, said in a conference call with financial analysts. 
 Sun's net loss for the quarter ended Sept. 28 was $286 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with a loss of $111 million, or 4 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue was $2.54 billion, down 8 percent from $2.75 billion.
Analysts had forecast a loss of 8 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call.
The company warned investors two weeks ago that its first-quarter loss would be far bigger than analysts had forecast and revised its fiscal fourth-quarter 2003 earnings from a meager profit to a $1.04 billion loss.
Total gross margin as a percent of revenue fell 1.1 percentage points during the quarter, to 40.1 percent. The company reported that cash flow from operations was a negative $49 million.
Before Sun's announcement, its shares closed at $3.63, down 16 cents. They fell as low as $3.58 after hours. 
Sun, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., has been under intense pressure from some investors and Wall Street analysts to acknowledge that its current strategy, combined with its reluctance to reduce its work force even more, appears to be failing. In mid-September, Sun said it would cut more than 1,000 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force. The company cut roughly 11 percent of its work force in 2002.
Steve Milunovich, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, recently wrote in an open letter to Scott McNealy, Sun's chief executive, and the Sun board that the company was unfocused and could become "acquisition bait."
But Mr. McNealy and other Sun executives defended the company's strategy and said it was too early to take drastic measures like a corporate restructuring. Sun executives said the immediate focus would be on returning to profitability and improving cash flow, with both goals, they say, achievable in the coming quarters.
"If we are not able to achieve both of those over time we will take appropriate action," Mr. McGowan said. He said Sun was committed "to drive cost out of products and services" and to pricing its products more aggressively. 
Brent Bracelin, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, said he had hoped to hear Sun disclose specific plans to cut more costs. "This is a company in turmoil," he said. "But they're still unwilling to take a more aggressive stand."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Attendance is up, but caution still reigns as the big spenders on marketing gather again.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: DANA POINT, Calif. 

 BODY:
AS leading advertising marketers gather for a major annual conference, they remain wary of forecasting when the sputtering economic upturn will finally morph into the strong turnaround they have long expected.
 "I think the industry is in recovery, but growth isn't going to be robust," said James D. Speros, the chief marketing officer for the United States at Ernst & Young in New York. Mr. Speros is also the chairman of the Association of National Advertisers, which began its 93rd annual conference here last night. 
 "We are seeing some signs of bounceback," Mr. Speros said in an interview before the conference started, "but not tremendous bounceback." 
As a result, the agenda of the 2003 conference, which continues through Sunday, has been narrowed by Mr. Speros and the association leaders to topics of particular interest to members during tough times: measuring the return on investment for ad spending; becoming more innovative in making media decisions and more creative in developing campaigns; determining accountability; and building stronger brands.
The challenge is "bringing science to the art of marketing," said Robert D. Liodice, president and chief executive of the association, which is based in New York. It has more than 340 member companies that spend more than $100 billion a year on advertising and marketing communications for 8,000 brands.
"The economy is going to come back," Mr. Liodice said. "The question is when."
Until that time, which Mr. Liodice predicted would come sometime in 2004, "marketers will be focused," he said, "on squeezing every ounce of value from every dollar of their marketing spend."
As marketers seek signs of a potential turnaround, one sign may be close at hand: a surprising increase in attendance at the conference. The registration for the conference was 565 people, more than twice the attendance for the 2002 conference, held last October in Naples, Fla.
"It's good for the entire industry to get that many advertisers in one place to discuss important issues," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, who plans to attend the meeting of his marketer counterparts.
Attendance at the annual conferences for advertisers and agencies tends to mirror the health of their businesses, or at least the perceptions thereof among senior managers. Last year, about 400 people were initially expected at the conference, but only about 250 attended.
"The amount of members we had last year was paltry," Mr. Liodice acknowledged. "To be perfectly honest, we didn't manage last year's conference terribly well."
"We were quite concerned," he added, and determined "we either have to rebuild, and restore the luster to the conference, or do away with it."
A decision was made, Mr. Liodice said, to develop the agenda for the 2003 conference "by surveying our members and asking them what they want to know more about," then planning subjects and speakers based on those responses.
"We're doing simple marketing," he added. "We have learned that members come because of the content."
(Of course, the location of the conference, at the Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel hotel in what Fox Broadcasting would call "The O.C." -- Orange County, Calif. -- could not hurt.)
Mr. Liodice was named to his posts in July after serving on an acting basis since December, when his predecessor, John J. Sarsen Jr., left after almost nine years. Previously, as an executive vice president of the association, Mr. Liodice had a good perch for observing the highs and lows of the conferences over the years.
The low point, by all accounts, was a policy in effect from 1996 to 1999 enabling speakers to buy their way onto the conference agendas if they paid the association $100,000 each. The result was conferences replete with infomercial-style sales spiels from media companies, which left many attendees -- paying thousands of dollars for registration fees and hotel rooms -- disappointed and unhappy.
By comparison, the scheduled speakers for the 2003 conference include Jocelyn Carter-Miller, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at Office Depot; Dawn Hudson, president of the Pepsi-Cola North America division of PepsiCo; Robert A. Lutz, chairman for North American operations at the General Motors Corporation; Keith Reinhard, chairman of the DDB Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group; and James R. Stengel, global marketing officer at the Procter & Gamble Company.
The conference opened with a dinner at which the trade publication Brandweek, owned by VNU, presented its annual Marketer of the Year awards. The Grand Marketer of the Year, chosen from among winners in 10 categories, was Mark LaNeve, general manager of the Cadillac division of General Motors.
Other winners included some nontraditional choices. One was Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, honored for becoming a brand himself by meting out what Brandweek called "tough love on Wall Street." Another was Dr. Robert Atkins, the creator of the Atkins diet, who became the first posthumous honoree.
Brandweek also presented awards to two top executives at Allergan, the maker of Botox antiwrinkle treatments: David E. I. Pyott, chairman, president and chief executive, and Lester J. Kaplan, president for research and development.
The award raised eyebrows among those attendees who could still do so.

HEADLINE: Agreement in West Will Send Farms' Water to Urban Areas 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: BOULDER CITY, Nev., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Secretary of the Interior Gale A. Norton signed a contentious agreement here on Thursday that signals an epic shift in the struggle over water in the arid West from farmland to the swimming pools, showers and green lawns of cities.
 The agreement ends one of the West's longest-running water wars by requiring California, the nation's thirstiest state, to gradually reduce its dependence on the Colorado River, which acts as a huge spigot for snow melt from the Rocky Mountains for more than 25 million people from Denver to Los Angeles. 
 At its core, the agreement affirms a tough lesson for the bone-dry region: Because of finite supplies and a population boom, water reserved over the past century for irrigating crops must be diverted more and more to urban areas.
The deal calls for the largest movement of farm water to municipal users in the nation and will be in effect for at least 35 years. As compensation, farmers, some of whom might need to plant less, will be paid handsomely for water they get for a very small cost from the federal government. 
"With this agreement, conflict on the river is stilled," Ms. Norton said from a concrete perch overlooking the Hoover Dam, where a formal signing ceremony was attended by federal officials, representatives of the seven states that draw from the Colorado and four water districts in California that had been feuding over that state's share of the river.
The last time a water deal of this significance was reached on the Colorado, the federal government was represented by Herbert Hoover, who was then secretary of commerce under President Warren G. Harding. That deal, the Colorado River Compact, was signed on Nov. 24, 1922, and led to the construction of the Hoover Dam and California's commitment to limit its Colorado River water use to 4.4 million acre-feet.
In recent years, the state has been taking closer to 5.2 million acre-feet. An acre-foot is 326,000 gallons, or enough on average to provide for two households for a year. 
"This is a huge breakthrough," Ms. Norton said in an interview. "Even the agreement that allowed the construction of the Hoover Dam left some issues unresolved. This resolves issues that have been unresolved for over 70 years."
The deal comes at a time when the Colorado is enduring a fifth consecutive year of drought and California and its neighbors, experiencing unbridled population growth, are at loggerheads over how to meet everyone's water needs.
Ms. Norton and state and local water officials said the drought was a driving force behind the negotiations, as water districts across the West got a sobering view of how tight supplies could become.
"This deal has a huge economic impact by stabilizing the water supply not only for California, but for Nevada, Arizona and the upper basin states," said Pat Mulroy, director of the Southern Nevada Water Authority, referring to Colorado, Wyoming, Utah and New Mexico. "As all of these states develop, finding a point of water stability is essential."
Under the agreement, farmers in the Imperial Valley, a fertile basin in Southern California that would be a wasteland without water from the Colorado, must eventually sell hundreds of thousands of acre-feet of water a year to San Diego County, a sprawling coastal metropolis of more than three million people with virtually no local water supplies.
The San Diego district will pay market prices for the water, or about $258 per acre-foot at the outset. The farmers typically pay only delivery fees for their water, which amount to $15 or $20 per acre-foot. 
An earlier version of the deal collapsed in December when many Imperial Valley farmers balked at the notion of selling their water, but as water experts predicted then, it was only a matter of time before agricultural interests relented to the unstoppable march of the urbanized West. 
"About every 100 years, we have something like this we can agree upon," said Maureen Stapleton, general manager of the San Diego County Water Authority. "It is a day of historic celebration."
Noticeably absent from the festivities on Thursday, which included a reception at Hoover Dam and a banquet in Las Vegas, were many Imperial Valley farmers, who for the first time in a century will be giving up large volumes of their water.
"There is very little interest in celebrating," said Michael B. Cox, president of the Imperial County Farm Bureau, who skipped Thursday's ceremony. "A lot of us understand we needed to do a transfer, but man, so many of those provisions are just hard to accept."
The Imperial Irrigation District, which provides water to the farmers, remains deeply divided on the issue, approving the agreement by a 3-to-2 vote two weeks ago. Many farmers fear that the agreement has opened the way for more demands on their supplies and that ultimately they will be driven out business by the unquenchable thirst of California's growing cities.
Already, the state's largest water district, the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, receives nearly 9 percent of its supplies from agricultural sources, including some from the Imperial Valley.
"The farmers are split down the middle on this," said Bruce R. Kuhn, a district board member who was the swing vote. "This is a first. This is like the pioneers coming West."
But Lloyd Allen, an Imperial farmer who is president of the irrigation district, showed up on Thursday in his cowboy hat and heaped praise on Ms. Norton and Gov. Gray Davis of California, who pushed thenegotiations forward after December's impasse and helped break a deadlock by agreeing to state assistance for the Salton Sea, a salty body of water brimming with bird life in the Imperial Valley that relies on agricultural runoff to keep from drying up. 
"I am going to go out there in the middle of that bridge and I am going to get on my hands and knees and I am going to kiss that dam," Mr. Allen told the gathering. 
He continued, "This thing has made where I live a beautiful, beautiful valley. Now I find out it is going to make a lot more beauty over there on that coastal plain because you are going to get a lot of water from this."
California had promised to limit its use of Colorado River water in the 1920's. It was a pledge that Congress had insisted upon before approving construction of the dam, which created Lake Mead, a huge reservoir about 30 miles southeast of Las Vegas. .
But even with California's promises, the growing state continued to draw more than its share from the Colorado for the better part of a century, leading to protracted legal battles. Three years ago, the six other Colorado River basin states, along with the Department of the Interior, gave California an ultimatum: Get your house in order by Dec. 31, 2002 -- namely work out a deal where water from California's farms is shared with its cities -- or all supplies of river water above 4.4 million acre-feet will be cut off. 
When the deadline passed, Ms. Norton turned off the flows to the Imperial farmers and the Metropolitan Water District, an unprecedented punishment.
That jolt led to a new round of negotiations, which were completed only last Friday and were approved the same day by Ms. Norton. With the deal now signed, Ms. Norton said on Thursday that she would turn the water flows back on, and that California would be given 14 years to wean itself from its overdependence on the river.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: THE RECONSTRUCTION; 
UNANIMOUS VOTE BY U.N.'S COUNCIL ADOPTS IRAQ PLAN

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
The Security Council unanimously approved Thursday an American and British resolution authorizing an American-led multinational force in Iraq. The measure also set a Dec. 15 deadline for the Iraqi Governing Council to lay out a timetable for creating a constitution and democratic government.
 The international unity on display in the Security Council chamber when all 15 ambassadors raised their hands in assent was something of a diplomatic triumph for the Bush administration after months of apparent isolation here. 
 The United States and Britain won an international mandate to carry out what is largely their vision of Iraq's political future while creating a United Nations-authorized multinational force under American command. Excerpts, Page A12. 
In a statement, President Bush welcomed the vote, saying: "The world has an opportunity -- and a responsibility -- to help the Iraqi people build a nation that is stable, secure and free. This resolution will help marshal even more international support for the development of a new, democratic Iraq."
The Senate voted on Thursday night to insist that Iraq repay up to $10 billion in reconstruction aid. Page A12. 
As soon as the United Nations resolution passed, several late converts -- including France, Germany and Pakistan -- made clear that it was still too flawed, in their view, to spur any contributions of troops or money beyond current assistance.
Pakistan, a Muslim nation, was one of the countries that Washington had hoped would contribute troops. 
Russia, France and Germany, the countries that had most visibly opposed the war, issued a joint statement saying, "We believe that the resolution should have gone further on two major issues: first, the role of the United Nations, in particular in the political process, and second, the pace of the transfer of responsibilities to the Iraqi people."
Those comments made it clear that the resolution did little more than paper over the fundamental differences dividing the United States from many Council members, who contended that the measure should have mandated a quick, time-limited transfer of responsibilities from the coalition authorities to the Iraqis.
Still, the vote ended the United States' diplomatic isolation. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell called the vote "a great achievement for the entire Security Council, to come together again in this manner."
The resolution, Mr. Powell said, allows the international community "to move forward to restore full sovereignty of Iraq back to the Iraqi people in a careful, deliberate way."
The unanimous vote was the product of a last-minute deal brokered Wednesday between the United States and Russia, after China had indicated its support for the draft, Council diplomats said. 
Russia offered amendments giving the United Nations more flexibility in taking on political tasks and making clear that the multinational force's mandate would end when the political transition was complete.
But just when that transition will be over was left unclear. The Iraqi Governing Council must submit a timetable by Dec. 15 and allow it to be reviewed by the Security Council, but no stipulation on the nature of that timetable was included. That left the Bush administration with the room for maneuver that it had sought, officials said.
The administration appeared to have Russia to thank for the unanimous vote. "Russia was the catalyst," one Council diplomat involved in the talks said. Once China signaled support on Wednesday for the American text, Russia moved to get France and Germany on board, diplomats said, and all three announced their support Thursday morning.
About 90 minutes later, the Syrian ambassador, Faysal Mekdad, who had last talked to John D. Negroponte, the United States ambassador, at 1:20 a.m., told him that Syria, too, would go along, Mr. Negroponte said. 
But unanimity did not indicate enthusiasm. "We miss the clear signal that the transfer of sovereignty to the Iraqis will be accelerated," Germany's ambassador to the United Nations, Gunter Pleuger, told the Council after the vote.
The Germans and French had made clear that Western Europe can have no interest in any American -- or Western -- failure in Iraq, and Mr. Pleuger echoed that thinking. Political and economic reconstruction and the restoration of Iraqi sovereignty were crucial goals, hesaid, adding that "this can only succeed when the Security Council appears as unified as possible."
"We therefore did not want to stand in the way of unity of the Council," he said. 
Nonetheless, the unexpectedly complete success of the measure was deeply satisfying to Washington and London. The resolution gives the American-led Coalition Provisional Authority an international mandate to maintain troops to "contribute to the maintenance of stability and security in Iraq" while a constitution is drafted and ratified and a new government elected and established.
Jeanne J. Kirkpatrick, the American ambassador to the United Nations in the Reagan administration, said the overwhelming approval "has some symbolic value which can be cashed in for real value under the right circumstances."
She added, "I think, for instance, it is very important for Tony Blair in the U.K., and Tony Blair is very important for the U.S." Mr. Blair, the British prime minister, "is taking a real beating right now," she said, alluding to the strong criticism of Mr. Blair at home over Iraq.
Richard C. Holbrooke, President Bill Clinton's United Nations ambassador, said the vote "proves once again, that, flaws and all, the U.N. is a vital institution to American foreign policy." 
The new resolution was conceived after the Aug. 19 bombing of United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, in which 22 people died,

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 4658 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"ABOUT TIME: 700 YEARS OF EUROPEAN PAINTING," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, permanent installation. After three years in storage, the museum's European painting collection is back on view. Brooklyn owns some classy material, from Renaissance altarpieces to a clutch of smashing Monets. In this reinstallation, works from various periods have been linked with the theme of time, a good idea. The refurbished Beaux-Arts Court, with its large skylight, presents problems as an exhibition space, namely glare bouncing off Plexiglas-covered paintings. An exquisite small installation of early Italian painting from the collection is on the fifth floor. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; students and 62+, $3 (Holland Cotter).

* LOTHAR BAUMGARTEN, "Origin of the Night: Amazon Cosmos," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Nov. 30. The first New York screening of this overlong but mesmerizing film from the late 1970's offers another piece of the expanding puzzle of post-Minimalism. Up close and impersonal, it explores a busy day in the life of an Amazon tributary, offering close-ups of flora, fauna and shimmering water accompanied by written and spoken words and a marvelous musical soundtrack. Inspired by an ancient creation narrative, it is mostly a lyrical meditation on the facts of film, nature and language and the erosion of the wilderness by industrial progress. And as its setting is really a trashy swamp somewhere in Germany, it establishes Mr. Baumgarten's importance to 1980's setup photography. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Roberta Smith).

* "BESIDE 'THE ROSE': SELECTED WORKS BY JAY DEFEO," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Feb. 29. The Bay Area legend Jay DeFeo spent eight years painting "The Rose," which accumulated nearly a ton of pigment, built up at its thickest to 11 inches. This show includes 25 works from a career that spanned 40 years, out of which "The Rose" was only the most conspicuous part. Weight, scale, material experimentation, surface modulation, muted color and centripetal form: these were among the conceptual through-lines of DeFeo's art, with mystical ideas conveyed (but never stated outright) via transparent signs of physical exertion. "The Rose" is like a mandala. It is also an artifact of intractable effort, with a beauty that you can appreciate only when you stand in front of it and see how light plays across its face, in which there seem to be buried pentimenti of color. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

* "CROSSING THE CHANNEL: BRITISH AND FRENCH PAINTING IN THE AGE OF ROMANTICISM," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-77710, through Jan. 4. Although this show opens with a full-size replica of Gericault's "Raft of the Medusa," its 140 works give a substantial boost to what might be called the denationalization of the triumph of 19th-century French painting. Its startling diversity offers an accurate reflection of Romanticism's essential unruliness, and its careful tracings of the traffic in art, artists and ideas between Paris and London gives the British overdue credit for crucial influence on the French Romantics, especially Gericault and Delacroix. In the process, the show provides a finely detailed glimpse of a working art scene and the messiness that lurks beneath the surface of any art-historical narrative. Hours: Sundays, this Monday (Oct. 13) and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Smith).

"A FINE LINE: DRAWINGS BY ACADEMICIANS," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, through Jan. 4. This modest show of drawings by present and past members of the National Academy, organized by the Photo Realist painter Robert Cottingham, functions best as an instructive catalog of the varieties of line that artists may put into play. It includes the microscopically fine delineation of trees and a placid stream by the Hudson River School painter Jasper Cropsey; the jerky, primitivistic charcoal lines of a nude by Charles Cajori; the pale, feathery hatching in a still-life by William Bailey; the graphically definitive sketches of people, dogs and cakes from Wayne Thiebaud's notebooks; and much more. Hours, Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (Ken Johnson).

* "EL GRECO," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 11. The world is full of second-class El Grecos, but they are not in this first-class show. The portraits are fresh, true to life and understated. Elsewhere, El Greco emotes. The pitch hardly varies or drops. It's no wonder people tend to fall in love with him when they are young. Modern artists especially love him, as if he were a protomodernist. As the Belgian painter Luc Tuymans says of El Greco's work: "Everything goes upward. That's its mystical meaning. It's about the evaporation of material life." The show is also gorgeously installed. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "GEORGE INNESS AND THE VISIONARY LANDSCAPE," National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, through Dec. 28. Inness's achievement hovers in the background of 19th-century American painting with all the mysterious haziness of his tantalizing, startlingly simplified late landscapes. This taut 36-work summary of his development shows an artist whose artistic virtuosity was given substance by a religious vision of nature and an equally deep faith in the autonomy of paint as an expressive material. Distilling the examples of the German Romantics, the Barbizon artists and the Hudson River School, Inness forged a less-is-more conception of pictorial unity that was years ahead of its time. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; students and 65+, $4.50 (Smith).

* "PASSION FOR THE MOUNTAINS: 17TH-CENTURY LANDSCAPE PAINTINGS FROM THE NANJING MUSEUM," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181, through Dec. 20. The focus of this exquisite show is on the southern city of Nanjing between the defeat of the Ming dynasty in 1644 and the subsequent consolidation of the Qing dynasty. The scrolls, album paintings and fan paintings on loan from the Nanjing Museum distill both the verve of that cosmopolitan city and the mood of fatalistic nostalgia that has long defined classical Chinese art and was particularly acute in periods of political transition.A hand scroll titled "A Thousand Cliffs and Myriad Valleys" by Gong Xian, one of the great Nanjing artists, is a standout. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Thursdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3 (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

* "THE ART OF RINPA," Koichi Yanagi, 58A East 66th Street, (212) 744-5577, through Oct. 24. This show has fewer than a dozen objects, but doesn't think or feel small. Rinpa refers to an aesthetic impulse shared by artists working in various media from the mid-17th through 19th centuries. Although rinpa-style work may convey an initial impression of simplicity, it is defined by its decorative aplomb, as can be seen here in examples of calligraphy, ceramic, lacquerware and painting (Cotter).

"ENGLISH ROMANTIC ART, 1850-1920," Shepherd & Derom, 58 East 79th Street, (212) 861-4050, through Oct. 25. This extensive selection of Pre-Raphaelite, Victorian and Symbolist works is uneven but includes some beautiful things. There are, for example, startlingly vivid nature studies in watercolor by John Skinner Clifton, John Jessop Hardwick and Ruth Lindsay; a dopey yet magically luminous watercolor of children outdoors under a rainbow, by John Simmons; and a sweet, softly rendered pencil portrait of the artist's son by the once inordinately popular Edward Coley Burne-Jones (Johnson).

RICHARD POUSETTE-DART, "Mythic Heads and Forms: Paintings and Drawings From 1935 to 1942," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550, through Nov. 5. At the ripe old age of 19, and without any formal training, Pousette-Dart (1916-1992) turned out paintings of surprising strength and confidence, whose daring abstract idiom put him among the best of the first-generation New York School. Among the more powerful images in this small selection of oils and works on paper are "Head" (1939), a skull-like presence whose complex black-on-white linear markings seem a synthesis of African and American Indian art (Grace Glueck).

SAMUEL ROTHBORT, "Direct Carver," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000, through Oct. 25. Rothbort (1882-1971) was a Russian immigrant and self-taught modernist who made colorful, Ashcan-style paintings and sculptures carved from found pieces of wood and stone. Animals, self-portraits, mothers and children, and other motifs are realized with appealing rough immediacy. Some have Brancusian simplicity; some are surrealistic and some look like backwoods folk art (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

"AMERICAN EXPRESSIONISM: ART AND SOCIAL CHANGE, 1920'S-1950'S," Kennedy, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 541-9600, through Nov. 1. A group show of artists pegged by the show's curator, the art and cultural historian Bram Dijkstra, to the hopes, desires and economic troubles of the working classes in the Depression and afterward. The show's concept has been stretched to a one-size-fits-all cover for an improbable mix of artists whose styles run from the injustice imagery of Charles White and Harry Sternberg to the poetic modernism of Marsden Hartley and John Marin. Top-flight artists have been lumped with those who at best were mere illustrators. Yet nostalgia buffs who remember the socially concerned art of the 1930's and 40's will get a charge from some wonderful relics (Glueck).

MARILYN BRIDGES, Throckmorton, 145 East 57th Street, (212) 223-1059, through Nov. 1. Ms. Bridges's subject is monumental art and architecture seen from an extraterrestrial perspective. Through aerial photography, she uses distance, angle of vision and natural light to clarify the form, scale and sometimes the possible meaning of ancient sites. A pyramid at Giza seen from sky is dwarfed by its huge shadow. Borobudur in Java becomes a colossal mandala. Most fascinating are so-called Nazca line drawings in Peru, with gigantic images formed from narrow troughs incised in the earth (Cotter).

"THE 1940'S: MODERN AMERICAN ART AND DESIGN," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082, through Nov. 1. Set up like the living room of a sharp-eyed collector of Modernist antiques, this exhibition gathers paintings by Mark Rothko and Dorothea Tanning; sculpture by Alexander Calder and Jose de Rivera; furniture by Charles and Ray Eames and Frank Lloyd Wright; and much more. In another room, Charmion von Wiegand's colorful, abstract gouache paintings, titled "Improvisations: 1945," are lightweight but infectiously playful. (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

FRED EERDEKENS, Spencer Brownstone, 39 Wooster Street, (212) 334-3455, through Oct. 25. In the darkened gallery, a spotlight shines on clumps of puffy cotton hanging from the ceiling, casting a shadow picture of a dramatic partly cloudy sky. Out of it emerges, like a divine revelation, the phrase "Neo-Deo." It's a neat, funny and mysterious trick (Johnson).

PHILIP GUSTON, BRUCE NAUMAN, RAYMOND PETTIBON, Brooke Alexander, 59 Wooster Street, (212) 925-4338, through Dec. 21. Converging from three directions -- Abstract Expressionism, Process Art and California Pop -- three artists arrive at a zone of mordant existentialism. Consisting almost entirely of black-and-white prints, the exhibition sets up an absorbing, triangular conversation by Guston's studio nightmares, Mr. Nauman's harsh wordplay and Mr. Pettibon's mix of hare-brained erudition and comic book illustration (Johnson).

ALEX KATZ, "Cartoons," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441, through Nov. 15. "Cartoons" in this case refers to an old master technique for transferring images to canvas, wall or panel. Mr. Katz's elegant charcoal drawings of trim, good-looking people on large sheets of brown paper are richly atmospheric, in part because of the burnt sienna pigment he dusts over the fine perforations that follow the drawing's contours. Seeping through the pin pricks, the brown dust creates a ghost of the drawing on the underlying canvas for the painter (Johnson).

RYAN McGINNESS, "Worlds Within Worlds," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300, through Nov. 1. A slick and inventive designer, Mr. McGinness has developed an expansive vocabulary of eccentric, vaguely familiar symbols drawn from art historical and modern vernacular sources. He layers his babble of signs in glossy paintings that call to mind Lari Pittman, and he applies gridded fields of signs to skateboards and boutique clothing. As vinyl stickers, his emblems punctuate a walk-in maze of mirrored walls (Johnson).

SAVA SEKULIC, Phyllis Kind, 136 Greene Street, (212) 925-1200, through Oct. 25. A self-taught, Croatian-born Serb, Sekulic (1902-1989) had a life of deprivation and hardship, yet his deceptively simple paintings and drawings exude a sweet, mysterious humor and off-beat eroticism. Totemlike amalgams of animals and weirdly transformed humans feel like fragmentary views of a whole imaginary world. The inexplicable painting of a brown piglike animal riding a red bird is a hoot (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JANINE ANTONI, "To Draw a Line," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9100, through Oct. 25. Ms. Antoni's portentous installation consists of two giant industrial spools with a thick rope of blond human hair stretched between them; on the floor is a big pile of raw hair into which the artist fell during a preopening, tightrope performance. If Ms. Antoni were making fun of artistic narcissism, it would be amusing, but she seems to be in earnest (Johnson).

INGRID CALAME, James Cohan, 533 West 26th Street, (212) 714-9500, through Nov. 1. Ms. Calame's splashy, colorful abstract paintings arise from a meticulous process. She traces random stains on city sidewalks and streets and then transfers these found forms onto aluminum panels. Painting them, in layers, in glossy enamels, she produces an absorbing congestion. Marks on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange were the basis for a wrap-around mural of green paint on Mylar, which would best be called an interesting experiment (Johnson).

RICK PROL, "The Metamorphosis," Maya Stendhal, 545 West 20th Street, (212) 366-1549, through Oct. 31. A veteran of the early 80's East Village scene, Mr. Prol presents a series of big, expressionistic cartoon paintings of a lone man in a black suit having a manic fit of some sort. The paintings have heavily built-up, intensely colored surfaces, but the compositions are more static than you would expect, given the state of their zany subject. Don't miss the funky, bigger than life sculpture of a green monster -- part cat, part octopus -- frantically riding a bicycle (Johnson).

* JASON RHOADES, "Meccatuna," David Zwirner, 525 West 19th Street, through Oct. 25. The most memorable show in a while by this excessive slacker bricolagist and techno-installation provocateur. It includes one million Lego pieces; five enlarged casts of a petrified camel toe bone found in Florida, which Mr. Rhoades purchased on eBay; 48 cans of Geisha tuna from Saudi Arabia, and encircling the upper reaches of the walls, like calligraphy in Islamic architecture, colored neon signs bearing euphemisms for vagina. Sex and religion, crudely blended, make an incendiary cocktail, which Mr. Rhoades cheerfully serves up as festive comic spectacle, as if begging for a fight, while suggesting a purely aesthetic motif in the formal comparison of the Minimalist Kaaba to Minimalist sculpture, both as objects of reverence. The results are anything but minimal (Kimmelman).

* RICHARD SERRA, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111, through Oct. 25. In his latest show under the Gagosian Big Top, Mr. Serra adds some extra curves and corners, subtly but markedly shifting the tone and meaning of his work. With their flattened S-curve surfaces, the five towering elements of "Wake," the show's magnificent centerpiece, fuse the industrial and the organic, conjuring both ships' hulls and undulating seaweed. The gentle weightlessness of this work is countered by the spatial effect of "Blindspot," a spiral ellipse whose angled planes proceed in disorienting fits and starts (Smith).

ARPITA SINGH, Bose Pacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 989-7074, through Nov. 1. The psychological and the political merge in paintings by the New Delhi artist Arpita Singh. So do everyday life and allegory, Expressionism and ornament, historical sources from Bengali folk painting to Marc Chagall and a formal approach that is at once gauche and poised. Many pictures focus on the figure of a middle-age, worn-looking, often nude woman who may and may not be the artist. She occupies a dreamlike world of free-floating numbers and untethered objects: teapots, fetuses, knives, bright pink flowers. Toy-size warplanes fly like sharks through the air; a lotus serves as her pillow; men in dark suits stare or weep (Cotter).

"ARTAPPARATUS," Bryce Wolkowitz, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 243-8830 (through Nov. 1). This show presents four artists who make art in the form of machines and who also share an interest in looking and seeing. Alan Rath's funny, robotic machines seem to have human or animal consciousness; Jim Campbell uses L.E.D. (light-emitting diode) grids to create minimally illusionistic, curiously moody moving images; John F. Simon Jr. produces visually mesmerizing programs for laptop screens; and the electronic arts pioneer Steina presents a 1976 sculpture in which rotating video cameras and a mirror ball produce intriguing paradoxes of seeing and being in space (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "EVERYTHING MATTERS: PAUL KOS, A RETROSPECTIVE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 6. Mr. Kos's name rings too few bells here. He helped germinate the Bay Area Conceptual movement that pioneered video, performance and installation art in the late 1960's and early 70's. The spirit of his work is lighthearted and sly. One of his best early videos, from 1974, was shot in Wyoming: "Pilot Butte/Pilot Light" switches back and forth between that butte and Mr. Kos fashioning a lens out of a block of ice (you see him spinning the block on the inside of the lid of a pot to get the proper curvature), then focusing sunlight through the ice to spark kindling. The constant is Mr. Kos's catholic approach to materials. He balances a candle and a bell on the tip of a broomstick, which he discovered one day would stand up on its own if he jammed the business end of the broom against the floor just right. Better late than never to remind New Yorkers that some of what we take to be fresh or our own discovery in art has been going on for a long time elsewhere (Kimmelman).

"FILM REVIVAL," Dorsky, 11-03 45th Avenue, Long island City, Queens, (718) 937-6317, through Nov. 10. Four artists draw on marginal elements of film to make semiabstract paintings, works on paper and sculpture. Todd Brandt creates optically arresting fields composed of hundreds of 35-millimeter film canisters; Stefana McClure produces Minimalist rectangles by layering the foreign language subtitles of films by famous auteurs; Jesse Amado turns words from movie scripts into compacted typographic sculptures; and Carter Potter makes film and painting hybrids by wrapping 70-millimeter film stock around wooden stretchers (Johnson).

* NASREEN MOHAMEDI, Talwar, 108 East 16th Street, Mnahattan, (212) 673-3096, through Oct. 25. Mohamedi (1937-1990) was born in Pakistan, spent time in London and Paris, and taught art in Baroda, India. She is best known for linear drawings that suggest perspectival Agnes Martins floating in fourth dimension. This show presents her photographs from the 1960's and 70's. Abstracted images of places and things -- Islamic architecture; painted directional markings on Japanese streets; ocean swells after a storm -- have clear connections to her drawings and reflect an artist who broke with essentialist ideas of what Indian art should look like, engaged with the advanced international art of her day, and left a deeply personal body of work (Cotter).

FRANK MOORE, Sperone Westwater, 415 West 13th Street, West Village, (212) 999-7337 (through Oct. 25). Moore, who died last year at 48, was not a painter's painter. His pictures are topical, discursive, busy, crafty, witty and, in the best sense of the word, illustrative. They dealt with a predictable menu of liberal issues -- race, gender, AIDS, the environment -- but with unpredictably imaginative and generously humorous verve. This exhibition includes late works and a fine selection of paintings from the last 14 years (Johnson).

Last Chance

ADAM DANT, Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338, through tomorrow. This idiosyncratic English artist blends elements of comic books, illustration and graphic design into the fictive Bureau for the Investigation of Subliminal Imagery. It is a form of art-about-art that, loosed upon the museums of Europe, deepens into an examination of the complex process of visual perception (Smith).

PATRICIA TOBACCO FORRESTER, A.V.C. Contemporary Arts, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122, through tomorrow. Nature reaches out to Ms. Forrester, and vice versa, begetting these lush, dense watercolors of flowers, plants and trees. Alive with intense color and Expressionistic shapes, they are painted from life in mostly exotic locations, but through the interpretive lens of the artist's emotions. A large triptych, "Beech/Birch," crawls with densely tangled forest growth partly reflected in water; several vertical panels of floral effusions in stirring color, like "Waterlily Slice," bring complex interplays of leaves and blossoms close to the viewer's face (Glueck).

"THE GREENWICH VISIONARY: WORK FROM THE ESTATE OF BRUNO DEL FAVERO," Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 226-3768, through tomorrow. A mason turned landscape gardener who lived most of his life in Greenwich, Conn., Del Favero (1910-1995) took to painting in his old age without any formal training. (He is not, for example, great on perspective.) Outsiderish things tend to happen in his painterly visions, like a river teeming with huge fish that appear to be swallowing it up; a snake hovering in the air of an animal-haunted cityscape, coiled in the middle of what seems to be a flame. His painterly visions appear to be stirred by a wistful yearning for adventure, physical and spiritual. A soul shines through the awkwardness of his work (Glueck).

* LYLE ASHTON HARRIS, "Memoirs of Hadrian," CRG, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 229-2766, through tomorrow. The large-format photographs in this New York artist's first local show since 1996 were inspired by Marguerite Yourcenar's fictional autobiography of the aging Roman emperor. At the heart of the story is the figure of Antinous, Hadrian's young lover, who drowned and was posthumously deified by imperial order. Their relationship is described in the book as a power struggle, with the emperor fixated on his lover's physical beauty and un-Roman exoticism. The focus of Mr. Harris's pictures is a young black boxer, played by the artist, an object of intense public fascination, but one routinely cast in racist terms of hero, villain and victim (Cotter).

"INTERNAL EXCESS," the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, through tomorrow. Highlights of the center's latest selection of emerging artists include Arthur Aghajanian's sly charts analyzing familial relations; Mie Yim's pastel pictures of stuffed bears and bunnies in anxiety-fraught situations; Lamar Peterson's coolly surrealistic cartoon images of middle-class blacks; Douglas Florian's idiosyncratic abstractions painted on paper bags; Christine Hiebert's elegantly airy mural made of blue tape; and Astrid Bowlby's bewilderingly complex accumulation of cutout cartoon fragments (Johnson).

JULIAN LETHBRIDGE, Paula Cooper, 521 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1105, through tomorrow. Mr. Lethbridge paints with a rough immediacy that calls to mind Terry Winters and harks back to the all-over gesturalism of Pollock and de Kooning. In grays or two-color palettes, he creates busy fields of short straight lines, which seem to circulate in response to invisible electromagnetic currents over more broadly and loosely painted lower layers. The paintings have frontal authority; what they want is more adventurous unpredictability (Johnson).

* MARILYN MINTER, Fredericks Freiser, 504 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 633-6555, through tomorrow. One of several artists of the 1980's whose work links the often-disparaged Photo Realism of the 1960's and 70's with the style's current stampede, Ms. Minter continues to cultivate multiple ambiguities in lush, close-up images (both paintings and photographs) of heavily made-up mouths and eyes. Sweat, acne and peach-fuzz add unexpected twists, confusing not only sex but also age, and sharpening these examinations of artifice and desire with the suggestion of vulnerability and threat (Smith).

LOTHAR OSTERBURG, "At the Edge of the Real," Achim Moeller, 167 East 73rd Street, (212) 988-4500, through tomorrow. Conjuring monumental phenomena with minimal means, Mr. Osterburg presents picturesque photogravures of events like a zeppelin over Timbuktu or a landing craft's approach to a celestial body. But the settings and props are all contrived in his studio using mundane materials like twigs, toothpicks, peanut butter and wee electrical parts. Photographed through a magnifying glass or a macro lens, his pictures are given a romantic, retro look through photogravure. Blowing up small objects and settings to make large-scale photographs is nothing new, but Mr. Osterburg's skill in constructing his scenes and suffusing them with nostalgia is quite special (Glueck).

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Sunday. This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Lego Mecca Kaaba" (2003) by Jason Rhoades, techno-installation provocateur, from "Meccatuna," at David Zwirner in Chelsea. (Photo by David Zwirner Gallery); Detail of a 1610 portrait, from the El Greco exhibition at the Met. (Photo by Museum of Fine Arts, Boston)
