HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Albany: Jobless Rate Is Up, But So Is Job Creation 

BYLINE:  By Janny Scott (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 The unemployment rate for New York City jumped to 8.8 from 8.1 percent in September, according to monthly figures released yesterday by the state's Department of Labor. But the city also gained about 12,300 government and private-sector jobs, prompting economists to trace the jump in the joblessness rate to a surge in the number of New Yorkers actively looking for work. 
William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller, said the city's one-month job gain was the largest since September 2000. Statewide, the unemployment rate rose to 6.4, from 6.2 percent in August. Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist at Jones Lang LaSalle, a commercial real estate firm, said the securities, banking, employment services and film industries added jobs. There were job losses in insurance, computer and data services, and retail trade. Janny Scott (NYT)

HEADLINE: The Sweet Spot 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"What we have here is a form of looting." So says George Akerlof, a Nobel laureate in economics, of the Bush administration's budget policies -- and he's right. With startling speed, we've blown right through the usual concerns about budget deficits -- about their effects on interest rates and economic growth -- and into a range where the very solvency of the federal government is at stake. Almost every expert not on the administration's payroll now sees budget deficits equal to about a quarter of government spending for the next decade, and getting worse after that. 
 Yet the administration insists that there's no problem, that economic growth will solve everything painlessly. And that puts those who want to stop the looting -- which should include anyone who wants this country to avoid a Latin-American-style fiscal crisis, somewhere down the road -- in a difficult position. Faced with a what-me-worry president, how do you avoid sounding like a dour party pooper? 
 One answer is to explain that the administration's tax cuts are, in a fundamental sense, phony, because the government is simply borrowing to make up for the loss of revenue. In 2004, the typical family will pay about $700 less in taxes than it would have without the Bush tax cuts -- but meanwhile, the government will run up about $1,500 in debt on that family's behalf.
George W. Bush is like a man who tells you that he's bought you a fancy new TV set for Christmas, but neglects to tell you that he charged it to your credit card, and that while he was at it he also used the card to buy some stuff for himself. Eventually, the bill will come due -- and it will be your problem, not his.
Still, those who want to restore fiscal sanity probably need to frame their proposals in a way that neutralizes some of the administration's demagoguery. In particular, they probably shouldn't propose a rollback of all of the Bush tax cuts.
Here's why: while the central thrust of both the 2001 and the 2003 tax cuts was to cut taxes on the wealthy, the bills also included provisions that provided fairly large tax cuts to some -- but only some -- middle-income families. Chief among these were child tax credits and a "cutout" that reduced the tax rate on some income to 10 percent from 15 percent. 
These middle-class tax cuts were designed to create a "sweet spot" that would allow the administration to point to "typical" families that received big tax cuts. If a middle-income family had two or more children 17 or younger, and an income just high enough to take full advantage of the provisions, it did get a significant tax cut. And such families played a big role in selling the overall package.
So if a Democratic candidate proposes a total rollback of the Bush tax cuts, he'll be offering an easy target: administration spokespeople will be able to provide reporters with carefully chosen examples of middle-income families who would lose $1,500 or $2,000 a year from tax-cut repeal. By leaving the child tax credits and the cutout in place while proposing to repeal the rest, contenders will recapture most of the revenue lost because of the tax cuts, while making the job of the administration propagandists that much harder.
Purists will raise two objections. The first is that an incomplete rollback of the Bush tax cuts won't be enough to restore long-run solvency. In fact, even a full rollback wouldn't be enough. According to my rough calculations, keeping the child credits and the cutout while rolling back the rest would close only about half the fiscal gap. But it would be a lot better than current policy.
The other objection is that the tricks used to sell the Bush tax cuts have made an already messy tax system, full of special breaks for particular classes of taxpayers, even messier. Shouldn't we favor a reform that cleans it up?
In principle, the answer is yes. But an ambitious reform plan would be demagogued and portrayed as a tax increase for the middle class. My guess is that we should propose a selective rollback as the first step, with broader reform to follow.
Will someone be able to find the political sweet spot, the combination of fiscal responsibility and electoral smarts that brings the looting to an end? The future of the nation depends on the answer.

HEADLINE: A German Banker on Welfare Among Miami's Palms 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Maybe it is the image of a former banker, deeply tanned and dipping his toes in the surf on a Miami beach, while people here trudge windswept streets in dismal burgs. Or maybe it is the notion of a housekeeper, paid for by the German government, to keep the fellow's apartment tidy.
 Whatever the reason, the curious case of Rolf John, 64, living in Miami on $2,200 a month in German welfare checks, has driven people here batty. 
 "He's laughing at all of us," declared Bild, the mass circulation tabloid that broke the story of the man it nicknamed "Florida Rolf." Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has condemned the case as "a really horrible example of welfare abuse." 
When the German Parliament votes Friday on a sweeping package of tax cuts and welfare reforms, it is not a stretch to say it will be responding, at least in part, to the anger aroused by people like "Florida Rolf."
While his case is extreme -- and the German Health and Social Security Ministry has since said it will stop paying his benefits if he stays abroad -- it is not unusual. Stories of welfare recipients who own yachts and luxury cars are a staple of the German news media.
Mr. Schroder is expected to win Friday's vote after trying for months to persuade left-wing members of his coalition that Germany must finally take a scalpel to its welfare system, which can make being unemployed more lucrative than working.
As a symbol of the excesses, Mr. John played a role in spurring the debate.
"It's the perfect case for everybody to get upset about," said Josef Joffe, the editor of the weekly Die Zeit. "In a welfare state that was not collapsing under its load, you would just accept it and move on to the next case file. But we're living in another world in Germany today."
Mr. John is from the northern city of Osnabruck, but he has not lived there since 1979. When reached by telephone in Florida on Thursday, he sounded simply fed up with all the attention.
"They've written a lot of lies about me," he said. "I live a very simple life. I have a normal, one-bedroom, American-style apartment. When I moved here in the late 1980's, the rent was $450 a month."
Mr. John's apartment does not, according to German reporters who have visited it, command ocean views. But as a reporter for The New York Times found when trying to visit on Thursday, it is in a middle-class, gated complex with private security guards and located just 200 yards from the beach.
Mr. John said he decided to move to Miami after his marriage fell apart in Germany in the late 1970's. He said he worked for a few years as a banker in Florida, but lost all his money because of onerous divorce payments and the failed business venture of a close relative.
Later, he said, he became ill with diabetes and pancreatitis. After being turned away by a welfare agency in the United States, he filed for welfare benefits from the German government.
Germany has only loosely regulated the welfare benefits it extends to German citizens abroad. Mr. John's package includes $1,023 a month for rent, an $854 living allowance and $170 to pay for a housekeeper, since Mr. John is considered disabled.
When German authorities tried to cut back his housing allowance to $702, Mr. John's lawyer persuaded a court in Lower Saxony that he would fall into a depression if he were forced to leave his apartment and circle of friends in North Miami. 
Mr. John is similarly unmoved by outrage over the housekeeper. "I have a cleaning woman, sure," he said. "But I'm 90 percent disabled." Mr. John said he needs the housekeeper to clean his apartment, do his laundry and drive him to doctors' appointments, and he referred further questions to lawyers in Frankfurt and Miami, neither of whom would discuss the case. 
After Mr. John's case was publicized, the Health and Social Security Ministry researched other cases of Germans living abroad on welfare. They discovered that 1,055 people in more than 80 countries are claiming benefits at an annual cost to Germany of roughly $6.4 million. 
In September, Ulla Schmidt, Germany's health and social security minister, said the government would tighten the regulations allowing welfare benefits to German expatriates. Under the new rules, the only people to receive benefits will be Germans who are receiving long-term medical treatment outside the country or who are in foreign jails.
"There won't be any more welfare under palm trees," Ms. Schmidt told German reporters in a comment that made widespread headlines in following days.
Mr. John said he had written a letter of protest to Chancellor Schroder. In the meantime, he said he has no intention of pulling up stakes from Miami. 
"I've lived here for 25 years," Mr. John said in softly-accented English. "I have a lot of friends here. My homeland is the United States."

HEADLINE: Stressing U.S. Right to Attack Foes, Bush Leaves for Asia 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
President Bush embarked on his longest trip to Asia on Thursday by reasserting America's right to take pre-emptive action against its enemies, and with a warning that the world cannot allow Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, to be "defined" by Islamic extremists.
 Mr. Bush's comments, in a speech here just a few hours before he departed for Japan and in comments to Asian and Australian reporters that were released by the White House, marked an assertive declaration of what he called "a new American strategy" as he headed to several countries where anti-American sentiment runs high. He told the reporters that part of his aim during the trip would be "to make sure that the people who are suspicious of our country understand our motives are pure." 
 Mr. Bush rarely talks so directly about his pre-emption strategy, unveiled 13 months ago in a national security strategy that has come to define a major turn in America's approach to the world. His comments here were notable both for their timing, as he urged Asian nations to enter a new phase of a campaign against terrorism, and for the setting -- he delivered them on a stage alongside Governor-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose "Terminator" movies came to define an image of America around the world that is more vivid than most White House policy papers.
"America is following a new strategy," he said. "We are not waiting for further attacks. We are striking our enemies before they can strike us again."
Among those enemies, he made clear in the interview, are the militant Islamic groups in Indonesia and the Philippines that have been closely linked to Al Qaeda. He said he would use his three-hour visit next week to Indonesia, where he is to land on Bali, the country's primarily Hindu tourist resort, "to make it clear to the world that, by far, the vast majority of Muslims in that country value democracy and want to have a peaceful life."
"At the same time, it's very important not to allow a few killers to define Indonesia," he said, adding that he would tell President Megawati Sukarnoputri that "there needs to be a focused, concerted effort to bring people to justice."
That could be a particularly difficult message for Ms. Megawati, who is constantly balancing her commitment to fight terrorism with pressure from a significant minority in the country that wants to see it transformed into an Islamic state.
Some Asian diplomats have expressed concern in recent days that Mr. Bush's affinity for direct language and his determination to turn an economic policy meeting in Thailand into a forum on security issues could backfire, highlighting the president's public image in the region as a leader who is intent on expanding American influence, by military means if necessary.
"The way he chooses his words about North Korea, about Indonesia, will be very important because it will be amplified this week," said one senior Southeast Asian diplomat involved in helping plan the trip, which includes a speech on Saturday to the Philippine Congress. "We've been trying to make that clear to the White House."
In California, though, Mr. Bush gave no indication of moderating his tone, declaring that America was still at war, and "wars are won on the offensive."
Mr. Bush's speech on Thursday was described by the White House as a policy address, but much of it was identical to recent speeches he has given at Republican fund-raising events, including two here on Wednesday that raised $1.8 million for his campaign.

HEADLINE: Bush and Schwarzenegger Bond in Low-Key Reunion 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Perhaps the Sacramento-Washington deep freeze has begun to thaw.
 After two and a half years in which requests for federal aid from Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, have largely gone unanswered from the Republican administration in Washington, it seems that the soon-to-be governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, has a friend in the White House. 
 Mr. Schwarzenegger met President Bush for 45 minutes this morning as Mr. Bush stopped briefly in California on his way to Asia. According to accounts from both sides, little of substance was discussed. Instead, the meeting was the beginning of a bonding ritual between two leaders who may have a lot to offer each other in the months to come. 
Mr. Bush and Mr. Schwarzenegger said they used their time to renew a relationship that began more than 10 years ago, when Mr. Schwarzenegger served Mr. Bush's father as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness.
"We did have a good visit, and during that visit I was able to reflect upon how much we have in common." Mr. Bush said at the start of a speech on terrorism and the economy to a business group in San Bernardino, east of Los Angeles. "We both married well. Some accuse us both of not being able to speak the language. We both have big biceps. Well, two out of three isn't bad."
The president added: "Arnold Schwarzenegger is going to be a fine and strong leader for California. I'm proud to call him friend."
Mr. Schwarzenegger, introducing the president, said: "After speaking to the president this morning at great length about the problems of California, I can tell you one thing: There is no greater ally that this Golden State has in Washington than our president."
The meeting appeared choreographed so that Mr. Schwarzenegger, the most visible star in the political firmament, would not outshine the president.
Journalists were not allowed to photograph the one-on-one session, Mr. Schwarzenegger's introduction of the president was brief and low wattage, and the two men did not appear together to take questions from the throng of reporters. Mr. Bush left the convention hall immediately after speaking. Mr. Schwarzenegger appeared 45 minutes later for a 20-minute news conference.
A White House aide who sat in on part of the meeting said Mr. Bush and Mr. Schwarzenegger met one on one for 15 minutes and were then joined by a small group of advisers. The two also rode in the president's limousine from Riverside to San Bernardino, a 15-minute trip.
At their meeting in a hotel in Riverside, Mr. Schwarzenegger said to the president, "You were governor of a big state," and asked for general advice about the demands of the post. He did not relay the answer.
Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, said the meeting was "an opportunity to discuss shared positions and their common approach to governing on issues like education and the economy."
The governor-elect, speaking to the news media later, said his goal was to create a basis for better relations between California and the federal government. He said, however, that he had not made any concrete proposals. That would come, he suggested, after he is sworn in as governor next month.
"I did not go and present the president with any kind of detailed kind of request, a laundry list of things," Mr. Schwarzenegger said. "I thought at the first meeting it would be more beneficial if we started the meeting by building a relationship, building a foundation rather than jumping in there right away and asking about specific things."
He declined to criticize Mr. Davis for the chill between Sacramento and Washington that existed even before Mr. Bush took office.
"I cannot talk about what the past administration has done," Mr. Schwarzenegger said. "I will make sure that we will from now on have a good relationship with the White House and a good relationship with the federal government."
Mr. Schwarzenegger said that he and Mr. Bush did not discuss politics and that the presidential campaign was not mentioned. Republican leaders in Washington and in California see Mr. Schwarzenegger's election and the 60 percent of Californians who voted for Republicans in the recall as a sign that the president could possibly carry California next year. Six months ago, that would have seemed a pipe dream.
James L. Brulte of Rancho Cucamonga, the Republican leader in the State Senate, said California suffered numerous "self-inflicted wounds" under Mr. Davis, in part because the governor had no friends in the White House or the Republican majority in Congress. That could all change with Mr. Schwarzenegger in Sacramento, Mr. Brulte suggested.
Mr. Schwarzenegger, too, expressed confidence after his meeting with Mr. Bush that Washington would be more helpful to California as it struggled to correct a serious budget imbalance.
"It was a good meeting," he said. "We had some laughs and all that."

HEADLINE: Mississippi Incumbent Surprises His G.O.P. Opponent 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Miss., Oct. 15 

 BODY:
With his money, national Republican connections, political savvy and personal charm, Haley Barbour looked to many people last winter like a sure bet to be elected governor of Mississippi this year.
That was especially true because the Democratic incumbent whom he was challenging had presided over the weakest state economy in years in a region where President Bush is particularly popular and at a time when anti-incumbent sentiment seems to be increasing.
But the handicappers underestimated Gov. Ronnie Musgrove. He raised nearly as much money as Mr. Barbour, conserved most of it for the last few weeks before the November election and proved to be a relentless campaigner. 
Now, although no polls have been published, the candidates and political experts agree that the race is extremely tight. On the surface, it seems to boil down to two questions.
The first is whether Mr. Barbour can persuade voters that Mr. Musgrove is at fault for the tens of thousands of jobs lost in the state in his term.
The second question is whether the governor, a career politician who has never lived outside the state, can convince voters that Mr. Barbour is unfit to hold high office in Mississippi, because he spent most of his adulthood as a lobbyist and Republican wheeler-dealer in Washington.
Just below the surface, an undercurrent of racial division is also driving the campaign, just as it does every statewide campaign here.
The questions of the sour economy and the differences in the candidates' careers recurred throughout a debate between them on Tuesday night at Delta State University here.
"Mississippi has gone backward in the last four years," Mr. Barbour proclaimed at the outset.
Mr. Musgrove declared that he had spent his life in Mississippi "as a public servant" trying to "improve our schools and create better jobs" while Mr. Barbour had been "up there being paid millions of dollars to represent interests that want to hurt Mississippi."
Mr. Musgrove, 47, cannot deny that the state has lost tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs; that the unemployment rate, 6.3 percent in August, is the highest in years; or that the situation is grimmest in the Delta, the poorest region in the state.
So he relied on the tack that politicians from President Bush down take when the economy is weak on their watch. He pointed to some bright spots, particularly the opening of a Nissan plant near Jackson, and said the situation would have been worse had he not been so vigilant in generating new jobs.
Mr. Musgrove passed the fault, in his case to Washington for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which led many manufacturers to leave Mississippi for cheaper labor in Mexico, and to Mr. Barbour in particular, for supporting the agreement.
Similarly, Mr. Barbour, 55, cannot change his resume. Over the last 20 years, he has been a political adviser in the Reagan White House, a two-term national Republican Party chairman, a strategist and prodigious fund-raiser for Republican candidates and a highly paid lobbyist for major corporations like cigarette makers, pharmaceutical manufacturers and communications companies.
So he emphasizes that in all his years in Washington, his family stayed in his hometown, Yazoo City; that his children, now grown, went to school there (private schools, not public schools like Mr. Musgrove's son and daughter, who are in high school); and that he came back home almost every weekend.
In an interview after the debate, he argued that his connections could be used to benefit Mississippians. Noting that the state receives 37 percent of its budget from Washington, he said, "Having a governor who knows how to work the federal government will be valuable to Mississippi."
Mr. Barbour has made the most of those connections. Mr. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, as well as several cabinet members, have come here to campaign and raise money for their friend.
In Washington circles, no one can remember a back-room insider like Mr. Barbour running successfully for high office. But he is the rare operative who enjoys the gladhanding of politics as much as the behind-the-scenes maneuvering. 
Mr. Barbour raised a pile of money, $7.6 million as of Sept. 30, more than twice the sum any previous candidate for governor ever raised in Mississippi. Mr. Musgrove raised $5.2 million. 
Although Mr. Barbour, who began television commercials in February, had $977,000 left in his accounts, Mr. Musgrove squirreled away his money and had $3.4 million remaining for the last five weeks of the campaign. That disparity can be explained by the fact that Mr. Barbour had already paid for all his television time through Election Day, and Mr. Musgrove had not. But in terms of money, the governor is clearly competitive.
Mr. Musgrove is a tireless campaigner who regularly stumps from before dawn till nearly midnight. His exhausted staff members say the governor needs but three or four hours of sleep a night.
Usually in Mississippi, close races are decided by the relative sizes of the black and white turnouts. About one-third of the voting-age population in the state is African-American, the largest proportion of any state, and almost all who go to the polls vote Democratic. A large percentage of white Mississippians vote Republican in statewide races. The rule of thumb, political strategists in the state say, is that Democrats need 20 percent to 30 percent of the white vote to win, depending on the turnout sizes. In 1999, Mr. Musgrove narrowly defeated his Republican opponent, Mike Parker, 49.6 percent to 48.5 percent, and the black turnout was the largest in state history for a governor's race. The governor says he is doing everything in his power to achieve that turnout this year.
Mr. Barber seems to be taking subtle steps to encourage a strong white turnout. He wears a lapel pin bearing the United States and Mississippi flags. The state flag features the Confederate battle emblem and is a sore subjects with most blacks. Last year, Mr. Musgrove supported a proposal in a statewide referendum to adopt a new design for the flag. It lost, two to one. 
In the debate, Mr. Barbour raised an issue that had not come up much, advocating requiring voters to prove their identities at the polls, to prevent election fraud. Many blacks say the identity requirement reminds them of white authorities' intimidation in the days of segregation. Despite Mr. Barbour's repeated mentions of the topic on Tuesday, Mr. Musgrove ignored it. His campaign manager, Lisa McMurray, said he opposed voter identification.
There is some evidence that African-Americans are less enthusiastic now about Mr. Musgrove than they were in 1999.
Representative Bennie Thompson, the most prominent black elected official in the state, said he was lukewarm about the governor and sensed that his constituents felt the same way.
"He has a long way to go to get the excitement back to where it was four years ago," Mr. Thompson said.
In an interview, Mr. Musgrove said there were some bad feelings between him and Mr. Thompson because of "policy differences" over the years.
Joseph B. Parker, a political scientist at the University of Southern Mississippi, said Mr. Thompson's coolness was a bad sign for the governor. 
 "Bennie Thompson," Mr. Parker said, "probably saved Musgrove's bacon last time."

On Tuesday at Delta State University in Cleveland, the candidates debated again, in a race that has grown tighter. (Photo by David Purdy/The Sun Herald)

HEADLINE: Dean Says Economic Priorities Are Jobs and a Tax Overhaul 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, on Thursday put forward the broad strokes of an economic plan, including $100 billion to create jobs, the elimination of $100 billion in tax loopholes and the creation of a small-business loan fund.
 Dr. Dean, a Democratic presidential candidate, spelled out his proposals in a Georgetown University auditorium where Bill Clinton made several major policy speeches in his first national campaign. 
 The staple of the plan was a two-year, $100 billion Fund to Restore America that would give states and municipalities grants to create jobs in domestic security, infrastructure, education and health care. 
But beyond the jobs fund, the economic speech was often short on specifics. 
As he does every day on the road, Dr. Dean vowed to balance the federal budget but failed to say by when. He said he would restore the Clinton administration's performance review system to root out government inefficiencies but named no fat bureaucracies ripe for the knife.
As for the small-business loan program, he said only that it would be modeled on mortgage financing. He planned to flesh out the details this weekend.
Dr. Dean also promised to "set about making the tax system fairer and simpler" and shift more of the tax burden from individuals to corporations, as well as crack down on tax shelters for corporations that move their headquarters overseas to avoid taxation. 
Dr. Dean denounced the Bush administration as practicing what he called "Enron economics," a reference to the failed energy trading company. As he has in the past he called for repealing all of President Bush's tax cuts.
"The tax cuts weren't written for the majority of America," Dr. Dean told the crowd of about 500 students in Gaston Hall. "These tax cuts, like Enron's finances," he said, "are a scheme to make the rich richer, to starve Social Security and Medicare, and to put our nation's financial strength at risk by creating the largest debt in American history."
Dr. Dean's call for a $100 billion jobs fund was similar to a program proposed a few weeks ago by Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the retired Army officer also seeking the nomination.
Besides the new job-growth fund, Dr. Dean said he wanted to push for deficit reduction by encouraging the return to the practice of finding savings or new revenues to offset any spending increases approved by Congress, and require a vote of 60 senators for any expansion of the national debt. 
Several of Dr. Dean's competitors jumped on him for his insistence that all of President Bush's tax cuts be repealed.
"He is right to note that this president is shifting the burden from wealth to work," Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said in a statement. "Unfortunately, instead of addressing the problem, he makes it worse by raising taxes on the middle class."
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts said, "Howard Dean wants to correct George Bush's mistake by penalizing the middle class, and that's wrong."
After the speech, Dr. Dean went across town to Asbury Methodist Church, where he picked up his first union endorsement, from Local 25 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union.At the same time, 12 trade unions agreed to join forces on Thursday to create a labor federation that will support the presidential campaign of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and focus on the issues of trade, jobs and health care.
The new federation, called the Alliance for Economic Justice, will represent about 3.5 million workers, including members of the Teamsters, United Steel Workers, United Food and Commercial Workers Union and Laborers' International Union. The AFL-CIO, opted not to endorse Mr. Gephardt -- or any other Democratic candidate -- earlier this month.

HEADLINE: Bush to Face Asian Fears of New U.S. Unilateralism 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
When President Bush arrives for the annual meeting of Asian and Pacific nations this weekend, he will be met by Asian leaders newly fearful that the United States is veering toward protectionism at home and losing sight of its role as leader of global trade.
 In this first major economic gathering since the breakdown of global trade talks in Cancun, Mexico, last month, Asian leaders will tell the United States that the developing world has not forgotten its desire to win more concessions to open the American and European markets for its agricultural products and textiles. 
 Above all, leaders of countries in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum will be looking for an American vision of world trade that is greater than its current focus on two-way and regional trade agreements.
"First, we will want to hear that the U.S. joins us in wanting to make the Doha round work," said Heng Chee Chan, Singapore's ambassador to the United States, referring to the current global trade talks known as the Doha round. "We want a strong statement promising to push the talks forward in December, when we meet again in Geneva," she added. 
For his part, Mr. Bush will be carrying a message to the meeting, in Bangkok, that security is at the heart of economic prosperity and that his war on terrorism must be at the forefront of the group's agenda. He will hold discussions with a number of countries on their contributions to the war in Iraq and to Afghanistan.
He will also address what he sees as imbalances in the trading world, notably asking China and Japan to let their currencies float freely in the open market.
The potential for misunderstanding is considerable.
In this, the fastest-growing trading region in the world, nearly every nation -- including India, China, Japan, the Southeast Asian countries and Australia -- is opening its borders to more trade with its regional partners, negotiating agreements with each other and throughout the area.
And while they are all too aware of the threats poised by terrorism, they are insistent that expanded markets and trade are essential to chip away at the roots of poverty.
Before leaving Washington, the President and his senior aides set out an agenda for the Asia-Pacific meeting that failed to erase some of these fears. To the Asian giants -- Japan and China -- Mr. Bush said this week that he would push them to let the markets determine exchange rates for their currencies, a goal heavily promoted by Republican and Democratic lawmakers who say that tens of thousands of American manufacturing jobs have been lost because of cheap Chinese imports.
His national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said that the trade agenda included individual discussions with Thailand, completing an agreement with Australia, regional talks to encourage Southeast Asian nations to further open their markets, and a commitment to continue global trade talks when the president thinks that countries "are ready to be serious about moving forward."
"There's a lot going on in the region," Ms. Rice said at a White House briefing this week. "This fits nicely into the president's multitiered approach on trade."
To Charlene Barshefsky, the former United States trade representative who negotiated China's entry into the World Trade Organization for the Clinton administration, this agenda looks suspiciously like an attempt to use China as "an excuse for their own failed economic policies."
"China's currency isn't going to solve our economic problems," she said in an interview, "and telling people to go into their own corners and create their own trading blocs isn't going to help global trade."
Robert B. Zoellick, the current United States trade representative, met with Thai officials on Thursday to prepare for the talks and will travel to China once the Asia-Pacific meeting is over to continue discussions with Chinese officials on several trade issues.
Robert Kapp, the president of the U.S.-China Business Council, said that Mr. Bush should be given credit for attending this meeting, given the security concerns in the region, and that it should come as no surprise that the war on terrorism is at the top of his agenda.
But he also said that Asian leaders would be eager to see whether the United States adopts a unilateralist tone with them, expecting them to follow the American lead on a series of issues.
"If the administration takes the 'my way or the highway' approach, then I suspect the APEC nations won't take it very well," he said.
The winner in that case could be China. With its expanding markets and increased foreign investment, China is poised to eclipse the United States in economic influence in the region.
In a report issued by the World Bank, Asia was given high marks for its strong growth and for "increasing integration of the region, evident most strikingly in booming trade with China."
Cambodia, the newest nation to join the World Trade Organization and among its poorest members, is one of the countries that sees expanded trade as essential for its survival.
"We need to catch up very fast, with no time to waste," said Roland Eng, the Cambodian ambassador to the United States. "That means we need to build up trade and investment. And the trend now is that the market opening up is China." 
China and India are members of a new group of developing nations formed at the Cancun talks to win concessions from the United States, Europe and other wealthy nations to reduce their agricultural subsidies and open their markets to farm products from the developing world.
Both these countries have begun negotiations with the Association of Southeast Nations for a regional free trade agreement. And in the preliminary negotiations, China has already offered to open its market to some farm products.
Nancy Birdsall, president of the Center for Global Development in Washington, said that the United States would have the opportunity at this weekend's meeting to show that it wants to help the developing world in global trade talks that would open rich markets for agriculture, or it could continue pursuing two-party trade talks with Asian countries. 
"The APEC summit," she said, "may consolidate a major shift in American policy away from taking leadership in the world stage of trade toward a new tactic of ticking off countries one by one in bilateral talks. The weak nations can only lose in those kind of negotiations."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: THE SENATE; 
Defying Bush, Senate Votes To Make Iraq Pay Back Loan

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
The Senate defied the Bush administration on Thursday by insisting that Iraq repay up to $10 billion in reconstruction aid, even as a divided House took a different path and prepared to grant President Bush's $87 billion request for Iraq and Afghanistan without conditions.
 A bipartisan coalition of moderate senators, saying that American taxpayers should not bear the entire burden of rebuilding Iraq, prevailed against strong administration opposition in a 51-to-47 vote Thursday evening. Their amendment -- approved shortly after Vice President Dick Cheney failed to bring wavering senators in line through a round of phone calls -- would require half of the $20.3 billion in reconstruction aid to be a loan to Iraq, unless the administration persuaded other countries to forgive 90 percent of Iraq's existing debt. 
 If the $150 to $200 billion in foreign debt is forgiven -- which appears highly unlikely -- the full $20 billion in aid would be given to Iraq. The amendment was principally sponsored by Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana. It won the support of 8 Republicans, 42 Democrats and one Independent. 
"The American people are very generous," said Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, a co-sponsor of the loan plan. "But the American taxpayer does deserve to be repaid eventually for some of our investment in this country. And Iraq deserves to be treated as a country that has the enormous economic potential that it clearly has."
For many senators, the administration's unyielding approach to postwar reconstruction could not be reconciled with the waves of opposition that their constituents have voiced in the five weeks since Mr. Bush announced his intention of spending $87 billion in Iraq and Afghanistan. At a time when record-high deficits have squeezed public-works projects at home, many senators said it was only fair to ask Iraq to contribute to its own rebuilding with its future oil revenues.
"All we're asking the Iraqi people to do is to take part of that $130 billion or $150 billion, whatever it will be that it adds up to, and share part of it with us, just share $10 billion with us," said Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia.
Sponsors of the amendment said that by linking the loan to a forgiveness of Iraq's foreign debt, they hoped to provide an incentive for the administration and other countries to reduce Iraq's burden of payments. The amendment essentially says that if other countries forgive Iraq's debt, the United States will forgive repayment of the $10 billion.
A similar amendment in the House, sponsored by Representative Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, was ruled out of order by the Republican leadership. On a 200-to-226 vote, the House rejected an amendment by Representatives David R. Obey and Tom Lantos, Democrats of Wisconsin and California, that would make half the $20 billion a loan, with no conditions.
Administration officials and supporters, who say they hope the House can persuade the Senate to drop the loan plan in negotiations next week, argued that loans would be too burdensome for Iraq, and would make it hard to raise money at a donors conference in Madrid next week.
"They have inherited a country that was so ignored by Saddam Hussein, so devastated by his terrible plundering of the country for frankly military purposes, their ability to pay back debt is almost nonexistent for some time," said Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma.
The debate about loans versus grants, however, could not obscure the administration's overall success in persuading both chambers to endorse the basic framework of its postwar Iraq policy. The president is virtually certain to command solid majorities in both houses for a vast majority of what he is asking for -- and a mandate for a strong role in overseeing Iraq's future.
By linking billions of dollars for the troops to Iraq's reconstruction, the administration forced lawmakers to either support a huge, unpopular spending bill or be branded missing in action in the war on terrorism.

HEADLINE: Clinton Officials Attack Bush on Environment 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
A group of Clinton administration officials, including former Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Carol M. Browner, onetime E.P.A. administrator, have joined with environmental advocates to raise money for an election-year campaign critical of the Bush administration's environmental record in swing states.
 The four states that the group has decided to study first, for insight into the leading environmental issues of each, are Florida, New Mexico, New Hampshire and Oregon. In the 2000 election, the outcome in all four was extremely close -- Florida and New Hampshire tipped to George Bush, New Mexico and Oregon to Al Gore -- with Ralph Nader of the Green Party getting more votes in each than the margin of victory there. 
 But the campaign, called Environment 2004, is also looking at Minnesota, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Arizona and Iowa.
"We're a small, nimble organization," Ms. Browner said in an interview. "We want to focus our resources in the places where we can make a difference in the outcome of the election." 
Environment 2004 will buy commercial advertising, conduct voter education campaigns and schedule speakers in local communities.
While it is trying to raise $5 million from membership donations -- and seeks $1 million by the end of the year -- it currently has only $500,000 in pledges or actual contributions.
A memorandum that the Republican pollster Frank Luntz issued to his party before last year's elections warned, "The environment is probably the single issue on which Republicans in general -- and the president in particular -- are most vulnerable." 
Ms. Browner, who is now a principal at the Albright Group, a Washington-based global consulting firm, would not disagree.
"This is simply the worst environmental administration ever," she said, "and the American public needs to know this so they can make a choice in the upcoming election."
The environment is expected to be only an ancillary theme in 2004, however, with national security and the economy overshadowing all other issues. 
"Not every voter puts environment at the top of their list," Ms. Browner acknowledged. But she added, "There are certain voters -- especially among women and swing voters -- that this issue is an important issue, and it can certainly frame their opinion about the election."

HEADLINE: Class With the 'Ph.D. Diva' 

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. 

 BODY:
Tricia Rose's imitation of a white girl acting like a black girl -- hand on hip, an exaggerated swivel of her neck -- sent cascades of laughter through the class. It was Ms. Rose's first lecture of the year in an introductory African-American studies course, and her departure from professorial decorum was welcome after nearly an hour of sober statistics about slavery and rapid-fire provocations about race.
 "What's the difference between minstrelsy and black behavior, black culture?" Ms. Rose asked the class of about 125, waving her hands as she paced, her dark curls shaking. The students were crammed into a careworn auditorium with high wooden beams and minimal lighting. You would have no idea that the setting in this city was a sunny, hilly campus, dotted with redwood trees. 
 Can you buy "Puerto Rican pants" or an African-American dress to be racially transformed? Professor Rose asked the students, who were mostly white. Is culture a set of practices or has it become so commodified that it can be acquired like clothing? Ms. Rose's performance was prompted by an article in The New York Times about a new television sitcom starring Whoopi Goldberg, in which a white female character adopts the mannerisms, speech and dress of a black woman steeped in hip-hop culture. 
But here in the flesh is Tricia Rose -- native New Yorker, prep school and Ivy League graduate, biracial child of working-class parents -- a woman who really knows hip-hop culture. Ms. Rose is widely recognized as the first person in the country to write her Ph.D. dissertation on hip-hop. (That was in 1993 at Brown University.)
Her dissertation morphed into a widely acclaimed first book, "Black Noise: Rap Music and Black Culture in Contemporary America" (Wesleyan University Press, 1994). That year Ms. Rose was also co-editor of a book on youth music and culture. Her articles and lectures have earned her the moniker of rap's reigning "Ph.D. Diva"' as she holds forth on black culture, politics and sex in places as diverse as the Op-Ed page of The Times and Essence magazine. 
Ms. Rose moved to the University of California at Santa Cruz last year and in July was named chairwoman of its American Studies department, after teaching for nine years in the Africana Studies program at New York University.
This spring she published her second book, "Longing to Tell: Black Women Talk About Sexuality and Intimacy" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), the first compilation of black women's oral histories about all aspects of sexuality. It has been applauded by scholars like Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of African and African-American Studies at Harvard. Mr. Gates said black sensitivity to stereotypes of hyper-sexuality has too often meant silence on sexuality or excessive policing of it in popular culture and among scholars. 
Ms. Rose, 41, said her second book is not simply a departure from hip-hop but a continuation of her fascination with representations of black women and men. In the same way that "Black Noise" brought together the social criticism, history and aesthetics reflected in the music of the post civil rights generation, "Longing," has a bigger mission than publicizing women's sexual experiences: losing virginity, sexual abuse, love.
"This book began as an attempt to answer a scholarly question: how has the history of race, class and gender inequality in this country affected the way that black women talk about their sexual lives?" Ms. Rose wrote in the foreword.
She herself interviewed the 20 women featured, choosing them from a range of ages, classes and experiences. Using pseudonyms, they discuss how skin-color distinctions among blacks shaped their lives, as well as discrimination and sexual harassment by men of all colors.
The only general conclusion that Ms. Rose draws from the stories is that many of the issues the women discuss, like being considered "exotic," cannot be untangled from the larger context of economic and sexual exploitation of black women and men, sexism and sexual myths. 
"The stories we know help us see who we are," Ms. Rose said in her fast, urgent way, her gaze never drifting from behind metal-rimmed glasses. She was sitting over a mug of coffee in a funky, fashionable downtown restaurant. "If we don't take those stories seriously and understand them as part of our social and political formation, then we may be increasingly manipulated in ways we may not want to be."
From her perch, the stories are bleaker than ever. She still listens to a lot of hip-hop, a genre she deeply appreciates despite its warts and contradictions. But straying from the music's roots in alienation, the narratives and videos of today's best-selling commercial hip-hop are more misogynistic and more infected with brutal images of black masculinity, she said. The pimp is a recurring trope, reflecting black needs for power and control of women and white fantasies about black sexuality and violence. 
Hollywood is no better. She was particularly appalled and baffled by Queen Latifah's performance this year in "Bringing Down the House," in which she plays a convicted bank robber who utters lines like "Who dat?" and is a vulgar mess overall. Ms. Rose lauded Queen Latifah in "Black Noise" for her independence and talent.
Halle Berry and Denzel Washington won historic Oscars in 2002, but it was no coincidence, Ms. Rose said, that Ms. Berry played "a pathologically dependent dsyfunctional mother who's sexually excessive in many ways" and that Mr. Washington portrayed "a cracked-out renegade cop who's basically a gangster."
Ms. Rose concedes that some lovely representations seep through hip-hop, mentioning, for example, those of the singer and performing poet Jill Scott. Still, she is concerned about those images driven by a legacy of "scholarly, cultural and political representations around black sexual dysfunction, around violence, around deviance," she said. "So when we play those roles, it seems real." Because they feel authentic and familiar, they are reproduced over and over, even when black artists have some creative control, she added.
Ms. Rose said she believed that many rap artists had the talent to take on more positive and nuanced themes but that they feared that those images wouldn't be as popular. 
George Lipsitz, one of Ms. Rose's Ph.D. advisers, recently joined the American Studies faculty at Santa Cruz, largely because of his admiration for her. Mr. Lipsitz said he was intrigued by her ambitions to develop a graduate program called Comparative United States Studies and to create "research clusters" of students and faculty members to work on intellectual questions.
"She has an extraordinary ability to mix social criticism, social history and cultural criticism and an advanced study of aesthetics, and to see how they all fit together," Mr. Lipsitz said. "She understood that hip-hop was the most valuable archive of what happened to black youth in the 70's and 80's." 
Tricia Rose spent the first years of her life in Harlem, the child of a courageous marriage of a white legal secretary and a black bus driver. (They wed in the 1950's.) Her mother's white skin prompted curiosity, at the very least, and Ms. Rose recalls that she never met another biracial child until eighth grade, when she entered Dalton, the elite Manhattan prep school. There she was different because of class and race, with a two-hour commute each day from Co-op City in the Bronx. But she was also popular. 
While her time at Dalton and then as an undergraduate at Yale were intellectually stimulating, Ms. Rose said she was always aware of how complicated it was to be among the few blacks at such places. It helped that her parents made her and her older brother (also a college professor) feel emotionally secure and challenged them to excel and be independent. 
For now, Santa Cruz, with its temperate climate and slower pace, allows Ms. Rose and her husband of six years, Andre C. Willis, "to develop more of our inner lives," she said. They live downtown, among more than a few transplanted New Yorkers. Mr. Willis is completing a dissertation on the study of religion at Harvard and teaching at San Jose State University. 
Although Ms. Rose's latest work has focused on black women's sexuality, she finds that she is still frequently asked to talk about the music, the artists and the video images of hip-hop. And she takes satisfaction in that. After all, she remembers when some of her professors at Brown warned her that hip-hop was fleeting and certainly not intellectually serious. Now, she said, "it is the lingua franca for talking about race and popular culture."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 2, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article in Arts & Ideas on Oct. 22 about Tricia Rose, chairwoman of the department of American studies at the University of California, Santa Cruz, misstated the precedent for Ph.D. dissertations on hip-hop. Ms. Rose's, written in 1993, was not the first. Several earlier ones included that of Cheryl L. Keyes, in 1991; she recently e-mailed The Times to point out the error.

HEADLINE: Home Construction Up 3.4% As Builders Work on Backlog 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The rate of home construction rose in September to its second-highest level since 1986 as Americans sought to lock in low mortgage rates and construction companies worked to fill a backlog of orders, a government report showed yesterday. 
 Builders started work on 1.888 million homes at an annual rate last month, up 3.4 percent from the revised 1.826 million started in August, the Commerce Department said. The September figure exceeded the median forecast of a 1.83 million annual rate in a survey of economists by Bloomberg News. 
 "The housing economy continues to surprise everyone but the builders," said Joel H. Rassman, chief financial officer of Toll Brothers Inc., the largest builder of luxury homes in the United States. "There's a huge pent-up demand that has yet to be satisfied." 
Demand is increasing in part as Americans gain confidence in the economy. The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for October increased to 89.4 from 87.7 in September, beating the median forecast. Yesterday, economists at Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch raised their estimates for third-quarter growth to 6 percent, which would be the fastest growth in almost four years. 
Economists had forecast a reading of 88.2 for the consumer sentiment index, based on the median of 57 estimates in a survey. They also estimated that housing starts would rise from the previously reported 1.82 million in August.
Building permits, an indicator of future production, slipped 2.2 percent, to 1.86 million. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has risen less than a percentage point from a record low reached in June. 
Homebuilder optimism this month was the highest in almost four years, according to the National Association of Home Builders. The group's housing market index rose to 72 in October from 68 in September. 
Residential construction accounts for 5 percent of the value of goods and services produced in the United States and has been supporting economic expansion. 
Starts of single-family homes climbed 3.1 percent in September, to a rate of 1.52 million after a 1.47 million pace in August. Starts of apartment buildings and other multifamily homes rose 4.5 percent, to a 368,000 rate in September.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Shares Decline Again on Disappointing Earnings News

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wall Street extended its pullback yesterday after downbeat forecasts from companies like eBay prompted investor worries that the market had risen too far. The three main indexes finished mixed for the week.
 "The marketplace is a little too sanguine, and expectation levels might have to be tempered going forward," Stephen Massocca, president of Pacific Growth Equities, said. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 69.93 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 9,721.79, for a three-day loss of 91 points.
Broader stock indicators also finished lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.75 points, or 1 percent, to 1,039.32, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 37.78 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,912.36.
For the week, the Dow rose 0.5 percent, the Nasdaq lost 0.2 percent, and the S.& P. edged up 0.1 percent.
Poor earnings reports from several companies late Thursday, including Sun Microsystems and DoubleClick, weighed down technology shares yesterday.
EBay reported a 69 percent surge in profits, but analysts said the period of rapid growth might be fading for the company, which conducts online auctions. Shares of eBay dropped $2.64, to $54.86.
"I think a lot of the expectations are already priced in the numbers," Neil Massa, an equity trader at John Hancock Funds, said. "Companies not only have to do better, they have to guide higher. But earnings over all have been fine, and the economic numbers point to a recovery."
Sun Microsystems fell 7 cents, to $3.56, in heavy trading on the Nasdaq after reporting a wider-than-expected loss. The company, a network computer maker, is struggling with weak demand and questions about its strategy.
DoubleClick, the online advertising company, plunged $2.98, to $9.26, after the company it gave an outlook for its fourth-quarter performance that missed Wall Street's estimates.
The American depository receipts of Royal Ahold, the Dutch-based global food retailer, dropped 50 cents, to $9.56, after the company offered a grim outlook, the first time it has discussed performance since a recent accounting scandal.
Gainers included Micron Technology, which rose 2 cents, to $12.85, despite a downgrade by a UBS analyst.
The disappointing corporate news outweighed several encouraging economic indicators. The Commerce Department reported that residential construction rose in September from August, climbing to the second-highest level so far this year.
The report reinforced hopes that a strong housing market, which is being fueled in part by low interest rates, is helping to drive the economy out of its doldrums.
A separate survey from the National Association of Home Builders found that builders were optimistic about sales prospects for October and for the next six months, yet another positive sign for the sector.
Also, the widely watched consumer sentiment index from the University of Michigan was higher than analysts expectations, rising to 89.4 in mid-October from 87.7 in September. Economists had been expecting 88.2.
"We'll probably trade sideways for a while until earnings are out," Mr. Massa said. "I think we're looking at a very good year for the markets over all. It's all in the guidance going forward. Will companies be buying more? Will capital expenditures go up?" 
Treasury prices climbed yesterday as recent rises in rates enhanced the allure of government debt.
The 10-year Treasury note gained 18/32, to a price of 98 28/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.39 percent from 4.46 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed 22/32, to 101 24/32. The bond's yield dipped to 5.25 percent from 5.31 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: The Netherlands: Warning From Grocer 

BYLINE:  By Gregory Crouch (NYT)

 BODY:
 The Dutch grocer Royal Ahold warned investors that its 2003 results would suffer as a result of the $1.1 billion accounting scandal still plaguing the company. Ahold, which reported a 4.33 billion euro ($5 billion) net loss in 2002, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that accounting fees and legal costs would have a "significant impact" on 2003 results. 
The company added that competition in its home markets along with a worldwide economic malaise was cutting into sales, too. Some analysts speculate that Ahold will announce a sizable equity issue in the coming weeks as part of a drive to reduce debt. Ahold also said it had completed the sale of its Golden Gallon convenience store chain in the United States to the Pantry Inc. for $187 million. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Samsung Posts Profit Rise And Exceeds Predictions

BYLINE:  By SAMUEL LEN and KEN BELSON

DATELINE: SEOUL, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Propelled by robust sales of memory chips and liquid crystal display screens, the Samsung Electronics Company reported a 6.6 percent rise in quarterly profit Friday compared with the year-ago period, beating market forecasts.
 Also, a Samsung executive said on Friday that the company might be close to a deal with another of the world's biggest electronics makers, the Sony Corporation, to co-produce next-generation flat-screen displays for televisions and computers. 
 The companies would each contribute 100 billion yen ($909 million) to the 50-50 venture, which would operate in South Korea and be run by a Samsung executive, according to a report in Nihon Keizai Shimbun in Tokyo. The new factory would start operations by the end of 2004, the paper said. 
The venture, which could be arranged as early as next week, would give Sony access to one of the fastest- growing segments of the electronics business, where it has no production of its own. Samsung in turn could benefit from Sony's industry-leading television technology and its global brand and marketing network.
On Friday, Samsung reported a net profit for the third quarter of 1.84 trillion won ($1.57 billion), on sales of of 11.26 trillion won ($9.6 billion), a 15 percent rise from the period a year ago and a quarterly record for the company. Operating profit rose to 2.05 trillion won from 1.82 trillion won in the third quarter of 2002.
Samsung said that its fourth-quarter earnings would probably set a company record.
"The forecast for the fourth quarter is for continued recovery in the U.S. and global economies and for the industry," said Chu Woosik, vice president for investor relations at Samsung Electronics.
"We are very confident about the fourth quarter," he said. "Our dominant position in the market enables us to especially benefit from improvements in external conditions."
Samsung also said on Friday that it would revise upward its capital spending this year to more than 7 trillion won, almost $6 billion, including investment to increase production of semiconductor chips and liquid crystal displays. The company had originally earmarked 6.78 trillion won for capital spending.
Greatly aiding earnings, the average selling price of Samsung's dynamic random access memory chips, used in a range of electronics products, rose, and remained above $6 during the third quarter.
"At this point, it looks possible for chip prices to continue rising, at least until mid-November," said Chin Yeong Hoon, an analyst at Daishin Securities. "And there's the seasonal rise in demand for personal computers during the Christmas season." 
Sales are booming for Samsung's flash memory chips, used in the latest camera cellphones, MP3 players and other portable devices. Samsung, the industry's largest supplier of NAND flash-memory chips, has said demand is outstripping supply.
Samsung, ranked No. 3 after Nokia and Motorola in global sales of cellular phones, sold 15 million mobile handsets in the third quarter, a 25 percent rise from the April-to-June period. Samsung raised its cellphone sales goal for this year to 55 million units from an earlier projection of 52.5 million units.
Sales of liquid crystal display screens, viewed among the next wave of products propelling Samsung's growth, rose to 5.2 million units, up 19 percent from the previous quarter. 
"We are positively considering a tie-up with Sony," Mr. Chu of Samsung said. "This means that we can share both profits and burdens with Sony."
By pooling their resources, the companies will try to reduce the growing financial burden of producing larger liquid crystal displays. With prices for flat-panel displays falling by about 25 percent a year, manufacturers are having a hard time recouping their investments in new technology and bigger, more complex factories.
"Samsung's a leading L.C.D. panel maker and Sony is a great television company, so it's a great combination for them to work together," said Kazuharu Miura, a consumer electronics analyst at the Daiwa Institute of Research in Tokyo.
Still, Mr. Miura and others warned that the cost of building factories, coupled with the rapid decline in retail prices of flat-panel televisions and computer screens, has made it harder for companies to turn a profit even though sales are growing.
And prospects for flat-panel displays are bright. According to DisplaySearch, a research company based in Austin, Tex., shipments of L.C.D. monitors and L.C.D. personal computers jumped 44 percent in the second quarter compared with the period last year.
Samsung was the second-biggest producer of branded L.C.D. monitors, after Dell, and the largest producer of panels overseas, according to DisplaySearch.

SUBJECT: ELECTRONICS (93%); COMPANY PROFITS (93%); COMPUTER & ELECTRONICS MFG (90%); BUSINESS FORECASTS (90%); MONITORS & DISPLAYS (90%); INTERIM FINANCIAL RESULTS (89%); MEMORY TECHNOLOGY (89%); MEMORY CHIPS (89%); COMPUTER CHIPS (89%); SEMICONDUCTORS (89%); COMPANY EARNINGS (89%); ELECTRONIC COMPONENT MFG (89%); ANNUAL FINANCIAL RESULTS (89%); FINANCIAL RESULTS (78%); AUDIO & VIDEO EQUIPMENT (78%); MICROPROCESSORS (78%); MARKET SHARE (78%); CONSUMER ELECTRONICS (78%); TELEVISION EQUIPMENT (78%); AUDIO & VIDEO EQUIPMENT MFG (78%); INVESTOR RELATIONS (78%); CAPITAL EXPENDITURES (77%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (73%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (73%); PERSONAL COMPUTERS (71%); MANUFACTURING FACILITIES (69%); PORTABLE MEDIA PLAYERS (67%); MOBILE & CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS (66%); CHRISTMAS (60%)

HEADLINE: In a State Once His, Gephardt Labors Hard 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS

DATELINE: MUSCATINE, Iowa, Oct. 14 

 BODY:
In 1988, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri roused this struggling industrial town on the Mississippi River with his tough talk on trade and went on to a victory in the Iowa caucuses that temporarily made him a top contender during his unsuccessful bid for the presidency that year. 
 This week, Mr. Gephardt returned with his sights set again on the White House and was welcomed with hearty handshakes and warm applause. But this time, his supporters admitted, they feel anxious about how he will fare. 
 Nowhere is the political challenge more important for Mr. Gephardt than in Iowa, the state that put his career on the national stage and propelled him to the leadership of the Democratic Party in the House. Then, as now, his aides believed he had to win here to win the Democratic presidential nomination.
But after spending months at the top of local polls, Mr. Gephardt is now running neck and neck with former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, and his future is hanging in the balance. After 26 years in Congress, Mr. Gephardt is fighting what may well be the final battle of his political career.
"I'm hoping that Gephardt has a good showing in Iowa, but I'm worried," said Betty McMahon, who is the co-chairwoman of the local Democratic Party and has supported Mr. Gephardt since 1987. "This one is going to be a battle. I think it's going to be darn close."
The state he has cultivated for more than a decade is a place he cannot afford to lose. It will either catapult him toward his party's nomination or toward retirement. (He says he will not run for re-election to the House of Representatives.) And as he darts across Iowa, from union halls to senior citizen centers, he is dogged by the inevitable question: Can he win again?
"I believe we're going to win here," Mr. Gephardt, 62, told cheering union supporters during a weekend swing through 10 cities. "I believe we're going to start the march to the White House right here!"
Mr. Gephardt still remembers the thrill of victory in 1988, the moment that brought him tantalizingly close to his dream of becoming president. But he shrugs away questions about history and the comparisons between then and now. "That was a long time ago," he likes to say.
Still, in this campaign, there is no escaping the echoes of the past.
During almost every trip to the state, Mr. Gephardt steps into union halls where he shouted his throat raw during the first campaign, and meets old acquaintances who wait patiently to shake the hand of the man they have supported for years.
Mr. Gephardt no longer stays in the spartan apartment that he and his family rented during the campaign summer of 1987. ("Stark, empty, just enough furniture to get by," recalls his daughter Chrissy Gephardt.) But he has kept the same campaign focus on jobs, trade and middle-class families and has reassembled much of his original campaign team.
Steve Murphy, who was his Iowa campaign director in 1988, is now his campaign manager. Bill Carrick, whomanaged the campaign in 1988, is now the media consultant. Ed Reilly, who served as the campaign pollster, is the campaign pollster again. And as in 1988, the strategy calls for an Iowa victory that propels Mr. Gephardt to a strong finish in New Hampshire and elsewhere.
Joe Trippi, Mr. Gephardt's deputy campaign manager in 1988, is now the strategy chief for Dr. Dean and he criticizes Mr. Gephardt for relying on what he describes as the same Iowa-dominated strategy the campaign pursued in 1988. 
Even so, Mr. Trippi says, it would be a grave mistake to take his former boss lightly.
Mr. Trippi pointed to Mr. Gephardt's penchant for working until his body gives out.
"I would never underestimate him," Mr. Trippi said, sizing up the challenge Mr. Gephardt poses to Dr. Dean. "They're both going to fight with everything they've got."
Mr. Gephardt is more seasoned now and has spent years mastering issues in the Congressional Democratic leadership, but many voters say they want a fresher face. And they say they also want a more pointed critic of the war in Iraq than Mr. Gephardt, who helped negotiate the Congressional resolution authorizing force and stood with President Bush in the Rose Garden last year in a ceremony dedicated to the resolution.
Still, Democrats in Iowa say Mr. Gephardt's call for universal health insurance, his opposition to trade deals with Mexico and China and his commitment to Medicare and Social Security still resonate in a state where 40 percent of Democratic caucus participants are elderly and a third come from union households.
But Dr. Dean has made inroads even in labor households, where Mr. Gephardt has traditionally had strong backing.
Mr. Gephardt's supporters say Dr. Dean has outspent the Gephardt campaign and visited Iowa more often than any other candidate, running the first television advertisements of the political season and leaving small towns awash in Dean posters and T-shirts. Meanwhile, Mr. Gephardt has had to work harder than expected to raise money and garner union support.
Dr. Dean has made such inroads that Mr. Gephardt's union supporters addressed the issue at a Teamsters meeting last weekend that drew hundreds of workers from across the state to support the Gephardt campaign.
Mike Mathis, the Teamsters' political director, told the crowd in Des Moines: "Some of you in this room I know have talked to your local unions and said, 'Yeah, you know he's a great guy for us; he's always been there for us, but can he win?' " 
Mr. Mathis said the answer is yes. Though the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided against an early endorsement, Mr. Gephardt has support from 19 unions nationally, more than any other candidate. Already, hundreds of workers have begun fanning across the state to support the campaign and Mr. Gephardt has begun stepping up his presence.
In recent weeks, Mr. Gephardt has sharpened his attacks on Dr. Dean and on President Bush's handling of the war in Iraq and the economy. Voters say his spirited performance in debates has captured attention. He has also livened up his speaking style since his last presidential campaign. He often punctuates his words with a jabbing finger and a shaking fist, and peppers his speeches with personal anecdotes. 
He tries to turn his experience into an asset, promising an experienced hand in dangerous times. 
"He's got a great message; he comes across very positively," said Bob Meredith, a financial consultant, who said he was still uncertain about whether Mr. Gephardt could win the caucuses, which will be held on Jan. 19.
These days, Mr. Gephardt likes to compare himself to the tortoise that ultimately beats the hare.
"Things change fast," he said, dismissing the polls.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Richard A. Gephardt with Teresa Kelly at a campaign stop in Coralville, Iowa. His victory in the state in 1988 propelled him onto the national stage. "That was a long time ago," he says now. (Photo by Associated Press)
