HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Two More Business Incubators Are in the Works

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
TWO business incubators -- developments that combine commercial real estate, government-supported economic development and academic research -- are being added to the eight that have already been developed on Long Island over the last decade.
 In eastern Suffolk County, an incubator that would relate to the farming and fishing industries is near completion. Situated in Calverton on a heavily treed portion of the former Grumman plant, where military aircraft were once assembled, the 15,800-square-foot building will include new businesses in the agricultural, aquaculture and environmental technology industries. It will be managed by Stony Brook University, which has operated an incubator for fledgling companies in the high-technology and biomanufacturing industries on its campus since 1992. 
 Another incubator, which is in the planning stages in western Nassau, will serve the bioscience industry. It is to be at I.park, a 1.4-million-square-foot office and industrial complex in Lake Success. 
In the past 20 years, incubators have become a popular economic development tool aimed at helping new businesses survive until they can become profitable, with a long-term hope that they will enhance a region's economy by staying in the area as they expand. The incubators offer space at below-market rents and are usually situated in an academic setting, where the companies have access to research.
Of about 950 incubators operating in the United States, 75 are in New York State, according to the National Business Incubation Association, a nonprofit group based in Athens, Ohio. 
That group and the Long Island Incubator Council list eight different incubators on Long Island, including six operating under state-assisted programs, like the one at Stony Brook and another at Farmingdale State University. In 2002, those six incubators had a total of 57 tenant companies, 699 employees and $72 million in revenues, according to Ann-Marie Scheidt, chairman of the Long Island Regional Incubator Council. 
The Calverton incubator is expected to benefit local industry on the East End, said State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, a Republican from Selden, who was instrumental in securing the $3.5 million in state grants paying for the construction of the incubator. "There is a symbiotic relationship with the farming and fishing communities, and the companies that establish here would use the sea and land plants, for example, for pharmaceuticals," he said.
It is hoped that once a company is ready to expand and leave the incubator space, it would find a home in the adjacent Epcal industrial park, Senator LaValle said. 
He added that there are "sufficient incentives to locate there because it is an Empire Zone" -- a state-designated economic development area that offers its tenants such benefits as tax abatements, reduced utility rates and sales tax exemptions.
The building, which could accommodate 20 tenants, was designed by Ehasz Giacalone Architects, based in Farmingdale. It will have eight aquaculture labs, 269 to 600 square feet; seven environmental labs with a salt water supply, ranging from 290 to 1,200 square feet; and five 150-square-foot offices. There will also be a 1,226-square-foot lecture hall that could be partitioned off into four classrooms and a conference area. The building has been designed to allow for a 40,000-square-foot expansion, Mr. LaValle said.
Tenants will have access to all Stony Brook University facilities and personnel, local Cornell Cooperative Extension research farms and the nearby Brookhaven National Laboratories.
Once an advisory board is created for the Calverton incubator, the rents, leases and criteria for tenancy will be established, said Monique Gablenz, executive director of Riverhead's Industrial Development Agency. When construction is completed, the state will receive title to the property. 
So far, there have been five applicants, Ms. Gablenz said. They include a company that plans to grow European sea bass in indoor tanks and an ornithologist who is interested in office and outdoor space for recording birds and other wildlife, in the interest of developing acoustic monitoring projects for the Department of Homeland Security.
THE incubator is on a 50-acre portion of the sprawling 2,900-acre Grumman site, which was owned by the Navy until it gave the property to the town of Riverhead in 1998.
In 2001, the property's 491-acre industrial core was sold for $17 million to an East Meadow developer, Jan Burman. It included 18 industrial buildings totaling 900,000 square feet on 225 acres, which have since been sold, according to Jack O'Connor, a senior vice president of CB Richard Ellis, the real estate services company that is marketing the property.
Currently, Riverhead is in the process of approving the subdivision of the entire industrial property. The undeveloped section is zoned for a building on five acres.
Of the industrial site's remaining undeveloped 267 acres, 60 have been dedicated as a conservation area, 75 are in contract, and the other 132 acres will be divided into 12 lots, including one that is 95 acres.
The West Babylon developer Robert Birnbaum, who purchased one of the existing buildings, is planning to construct up to five buildings on 35 acres totaling 300,000 square feet of industrial space for 60 to 65 tenants. The spaces would range from 2,500 to 10,000 square feet. "This wouldbe the perfect place where companies at the incubator could expand to," Mr. O'Connor said. "Once the subdivision is approved, we expect other developers will look to the same theme."
Rental space that could be divided into smaller units is also available in some of the existing buildings, he added.
Land at the site sells for $125,000 an acre today compared with $60,000 an acre in 2001, he said. Market rents for industrial space in the area -- for an average 5,000-square-foot unit -- is about $6.50 to $7 a square foot a year.
About 35 miles west at I.park, the 35,000-square-foot $6 million incubator and a training center are being developed by a nonprofit public-private partnership called Bio Partners Initiative, which involves Nassau County, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System and I.park.
The training center would "train and retrain workers to support the life science and biotechnology industry in Nassau County," said Peter Sylver, Nassau's deputy county executive for economic development. And the incubator would offer start-up space for companies in the bioscience, clinical-trial and pharmaceutical industries. Annual rents are expected to be about $19 to $21 a square foot, Mr. Sylver said.
Long Island's established incubators include Stony Brook University's Long Island High Technology Incubator, which has "graduated" more than 20 tenants. At least 15 have remained on Long Island, including the Collaborative Group, which makes ingredients for the cosmetic, personal care, pharmaceutical and biotechnical industry. 
According to Dr. Scheidt, who is the university's director of economic development, Collaborative began more that 10 years ago with less than 1,000 square feet of space and two part-time employees. It has grown to a company with 200 employees and four subsidiaries.
These units' sites include the incubator's entire 30,000-square-foot wing, added in 1994 to the original 42,000-square-foot one-story building, which was built in 1992. "It is good to have successes as anchor tenants for the other companies to model themselves after, and network with," Dr. Scheidt said.
In Farmingdale, the 63,500-square-foot incubator at Broad Hollow Bioscience Park, which is on 20 acres on the campus of the Farmingdale State University, is planning to add a new 50,000-square-foot building. It would have space for six start-up companies and for the school's new bioscience program, according to Greg Blyskal, the park's executive director.
The three-year-old incubator, which focuses on bioscience companies, is a collaborative venture of the school and the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, a leading biological research institution. 
About three miles west, at Briarcliffe College in Bethpage, a 17,556-square-foot technology incubator is managed by the nonprofit Long Island Software and Technology Network, known as Listnet. Four years ago, the state paid $500,000 for the creation of the incubator, which is on the college's second floor. It is fully occupied, with 17 tenants, which pay $15.50 a square foot in rent and have free Internet access. Six companies have graduated since the incubator was created, according to Pattie Simon, the manager.

HEADLINE: 99-CENT SONGS; 
McMusic

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thanks to Amy Harmon "What Price Music?," Oct. 12 , I have written my first food article, "What Price Meat?" In it I expose restaurants like Peter Luger for charging $20 to $30 for a pound of meat when McDonald's sells a pound of the stuff for a few bucks and manages to throw in bun, lettuce, tomato and pickle. 
 An original copy of "Revolver" may have cost $4.50 in 1966, and adjusted for inflation that might equal $26, but were you to buy a clean, original British copy today it might set you back well over $100. Why? You'd have to hear it played back properly, look at it and touch it to understand. Thirty-seven years from now, what do you think those MP3 files will fetch? 
 I've taken an absurdist tack here, but consider what reducing recorded music to an undifferentiated commodity does to the musicians and the recording, mixing and mastering engineers who produce it (not to mention listeners who appreciate the difference between quality and convenience). Don't get me wrong: I use and enjoy my iPod, and I eat fast-food burgers, but I never confuse them with a gourmet meal.

MICHAEL FREMER
Wyckoff, N.J.

The writer is a contributing editor to Stereophile magazine.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
$870 Million Development Under Way in Hartford

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: HARTFORD 

 BODY:
ADRIAEN'S LANDING, the roughly $870 million riverfront development that was perceived for years as a quixotic idea, is at last under construction in downtown Hartford. 
 As the centerpiece of a broader plan by Gov. John G. Rowland for sparking a downtown renaissance, Adriaen's Landing replaces a brownfield site with three major components: a convention center, a hotel and a retail-entertainment-apartment complex. 
 "Our Hartford program," said Governor Rowland, "is all about generating this economic ripple effect. We set up the authority to strategically invest public funds to leverage new private investment in the market -- from hotels to apartments to jobs." 
The 30-acre tract, bounded by Interstate 95, Whitehead Highway, Prospect Street, Grove Street and Columbus Boulevard (excluding the Travelers Plaza), overlooks the Connecticut River and a five-mile park where people picnic, attend concerts and festivals and board riverboat cruises named for the city's favorite son, Mark Twain. 
The program is administered by the Capital City Economic Development Authority, whose chairman, R. Bartley Halloran, described its method of attracting investment. "A private developer is building the Hartford Marriott," he said, "because we are building the Connecticut Convention Center. Private developers are building retail because we're helping build apartment units and bringing in conventioneers. A private developer renovated half the G. Fox department store because we turned the other half into the Capital City College campus. As soon as the steel started to rise on the Convention Center, we saw entrepreneurs jumping in." The rest of G. Fox has been turned into a complex of offices, stores and restaurants.
In recent weeks, passers-by along Columbus Boulevard, which runs through Adriaen's Landing, have paused to gape at the steel skeleton delineating the massive bowed facade of the 500,000-square-foot Convention Center under construction. The $190 million glass-sheathed building, which already has 12 advance bookings, will have a 140,000-square-foot exhibition hall, a 40,000-square-foot ballroom and 65,000 square feet of meeting space. The remainder will be circulation areas, kitchens and utility and technology systems. Underground parking and a new garage behind the center will accommodate 2,360 cars of the 3,400 spaces in Adriaen's Landing over all.
While the center will have its own entrance, it will also have a common entrance with the $77 million, 22-story Marriott Hotel, which broke ground on Sept. 25. Initially, the hotel will have 409 rooms and eight luxury suites, but it is designed so that an ell could be added to raise the room count to 700. An enclosed indoor swimming pool and fitness center will be on the roof, and there will be two restaurants and a bar and 13,500 square feet of meeting and banquet space. The buildings are expected to open simultaneously in mid-2005. 
THE project is named for Adriaen Bloch, a Dutch explorer who sailed up the Connecticut River in the early 1600's and landed near the area that is now being developed.
Adriaen's Landing "is our subsidiary and owner of the hotel," said Len Wolman, chairman and chief executive of the Waterford Group, master planners of the development. "We will manage the hotel, and we have a contract to manage the convention center for the state. The hotel will be a few notches above anything else in the city and a bit more expensive." 
Waterford Group provided $22 million for the hotel construction, with the rest coming from loans from several banks and the Connecticut Development Authority. The Waterford Group developed and operates the Mohegan Sun Casino in Montville, Conn., and 29 other hotel properties in 12 states.
The third component of Adriaen's Landing is Market Square, the new name for Front Street, a nine-acre marketplace that flourished a century ago with immigrants who opened barbershops, saloons, grocery stores and other small businesses. It was razed in the 1950's and will be resurrected by Capital Properties of New York with 150,000 square feet of shops, night clubs, restaurants and 200 market-rate rental apartments in several buildings. 
Excavation of the lot has begun. The rear of the defunct Hartford Times building will be demolished, but the imposing stone front will be preserved and the remaining structure will become office space. Construction is to begin early next year. 
According to Daniel S. Matos, a principal, Capital Properties is investing up to $150 million in Market Square, and the state is contributing $50 million to build two roads through it and two garages. His company is also rehabilitating Constitution Plaza, outside Adriaen's Landing on State Street. Built in the 1960's, it required the razing of a number of ethnic neighborhoods but never fulfilled its promise as an office, retail and hotel complex. "We bought a partnership interest in it in 1999," Mr. Matos said, "and now that there is a market for those things, we are upgrading it."
The idea for Adriaen's Landing goes back to the 1990's, when Hartford, like the state's other largest cities, Bridgeport and New Haven, was extraordinarily beleaguered. From the 1950's to 2000, an exodus to the suburbs caused Hartford's population to shrink from 175,000 to 129,229, reducing the residential tax base and worsening the burden for retailers, restaurants and businesses, causing many to leave. Even the insurance companies, heavily invested in real estate, became victims of the real estate meltdown of the 80's and early 90's.
In 1997 Robert Fiondella, president of the Phoenix Insurance Company, suggested to the heads of the Travelers and Connecticut Natural Gas that an urban development by the river would be good for the city. The two insurance companies are adjacent to the Adriaen's Landing site, and the gas company, which was later demolished, was on it. 
The plan became part of the governor's proposals to aid downtown Hartford. Last year the State Legislature authorized issuing $645 million in bonds, of which $92 million paid for building Rentschler Field, which opened in August as the stadium for the University of Connecticut for outdoor sports and concerts. Another $425 million was allocated to Adriaen's Landing property acquisition, environmental remediation and building the Convention Center. The remaining $148 million is for renovating the Hartford Civic Center and developing 100 units of housing on Trumbull Street.
The Landing's location makes it part of awalkable city center, near several prestigious institutions. Across Prospect Street or within a block or two are the Wadsworth Atheneum, America's oldest art museum; the award-winning Hartford Stage Company; Center Church, founded in 1636, and its ancient burying ground; the Old State House, built in 1796; and Bushnell Park, America's first public park. 
Creating housing that will bring people back to live is the No. 1 priority of Mayor Eddie A. Perez, a Democrat, formerly of New York City and originally from Puerto Rico. He looks forward to the completion of 3,000 units of housing now in the pipeline or under construction and retail establishments to serve them. 
"The first grocery store downtown is planned for Front Street," he said. A "gap" program is intended to increase home ownership in some of the worst neighborhoods surrounding downtown, including Mortson Putnam and Frog Hollow, where the Latin Kings and Solidos gangs once reigned. Subsidies from HUD and the Connecticut Housing and Finance Authority are filling the gap between a private developer's cost of, say, restoring a two-family house for around $230,000, and a sale price of $130,000. 
Owners must occupy one unit for 10 years, and each year a tenth of the mortgage loan is forgiven. Corporate commitments totaling $1.97 million are dedicated to Hartford's home ownership program. 
Ken Greenberg, an international urban planner in Toronto, was a consultant and recommended some of the initiatives Hartford is taking, like "getting people down on the sidewalks." Hartford has a number of pedestrian skyways between buildings. 
Other new housing includes the renovation of the Hartford Civic Center by Northland Investments of Newton, Mass. The arena will have market rate apartments on two sides. College Street L.L.C. of New Haven is converting the Southern New England Telephone building into 55 on the Park, with 135 apartments, and 77 have been rented. Prices range from $942 to $1,600 for spacious one- and two-bedroom units.
William Farley, a Hartford real estate executive since 1961, now president of the New England region of CB Richard Ellis, drives by the emerging convention center every day. "It represents a whole new layer of activity," he said, "but apartments will drive commercial development. It's a matter of getting residential density downtown. As young people move in, employers are saying downtown is more favorable as an office location."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 22-story Marriott Hotel, with more than 400 rooms, and the nearby Convention Center, covering 500,000 square feet, are to open in 2005. (Photo by Waterford Development) Map of Connecticut highlighting Adriaen's Landing and surrounding area.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Luisa Angrisani, Marcelo LaFleur

 BODY:
Luisa Judith Angrisani, the daughter of Maria and Antonio Angrisani of the Bronx, was married on Friday to Marcelo Thomas LaFleur, a son of Maria do Socorro LaFleur and James R. LaFleur of Arlington, Va., and Maputo, Mozambique. The Rev. 
Robert Norris performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Lucy in the Bronx.
 The bride and bridegroom, both 28, met at Fordham University, from which the bride received an undergraduate degree. Both she and Mr. LaFleur received master's degrees in international political economy and development from Fordham. The bridegroom, who also holds a master's degree in economics from Fordham, is a candidate there for a Ph.D. in economics and is a distinguished presidential fellow. 
 Ms. Angrisani LaFleur works in Manhattan as the Latin American editor for commerce and finance reports published by a unit of the Economist Group, the London-based company that also publishes The Economist magazine. Her father retired as an electrician in Flushing, Queens, for Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Her mother, who retired as a school aide at Christopher Columbus High School in the Bronx, owns Calandra's Cheese, an Italian cheese shop in the Bronx.
Mr. LaFleur graduated from St. Mary's College of California. His mother is an independent translator of Portuguese and English in Arlington, and was a founder, in 1989, and the program director of the Brazil-America Association, an English-language training institute in Recife, Brazil. His father, an economist, works as a consultant in Maputo for Booz Allen Hamilton, the accounting and consulting firm, where he is the American liaison for business-sector development projects developed by the United States Agency for International Development for the Mozambique government.

HEADLINE: Here Come The Glamour Gumshoes 

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN

 BODY:
FOR a seasoned private investigator like RichardDietl, it was a standard case. A wealthy Greenwich, Conn., executive was desperate to find his 15-year-old daughter, who ran away to follow the band Phish. Mr. Dietl knew that the easiest way to track her down was to go undercover as a tie-dyed Phish fan. But for someone his age (52) and sartorial tastes (pinstripes with white collars and French cuffs), blending in wasn't an option.
 So Mr. Dietl called upon a 24-year-old associate, Sean Lanigan. Mr. Lanigan flew to Las Vegas, where Phish was playing. He disguised himself as a hippie, hit the parking lot party scene and soon found the girl -- selling peanut butter and jelly sandwiches from the back of a Volkswagen van. By nightfall, her father was on board his private jet, on his way to pick her up. 
 "You send in a 40-, 45-year-old retired police officer, he looks suspicious," Mr. Lanigan said. "When you see me, your first impression is not 'This guy's a cop.' " 
In the old days, private investigation firms were staffed mostly by former police officers supplementing their pensions with a little gumshoe work. But times, along with the investigation and security industry, have changed. Private investigators now devote themselves to corporate background checks, high-tech surveillance, retrieving deleted e-mail messages from company hard drives and, of course, the occasional old-style sleuthing, like trailing cheating spouses. 
These new snoops are more likely to have liberal arts or computer science degrees than experience walking a beat. They're much more likely to pack iPods than .38 Specials. And unlike Jake Gittes, the reluctant P.I. played by Jack Nicholson in "Chinatown," who urges the suspicious wife Mrs. Mulwray to "let sleeping dogs lie," today's young sleuths comb through databases to learn the particulars of private lives with the same sense of eagerness with which they might Google their next dates or play the latest edition of Grand Theft Auto.
"It's exciting and voyeuristic to be looking into people's lives." said Amy Gray, 28, a graduate of Brown, who wrote about her three years as a private investigator in "Spygirl" (Villard). "The work intrinsically has a satisfying quality of solving a puzzle or playing a video game. There's a 'getting the bad guys' kind of feeling."
In recent years the number of college students studying forensic science has boomed, in part because media portrayals of private eyes and crime solvers in shows like "CSI" and "Cold Case" have glamorized the field, especially its computer-driven technical side. Where in the past P.I.'s were portrayed as "fumbling, bumbling people," said Robert J. Louden, a professor of science and protection management at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, "more and more they're showing digital video and the use of electronic devices, which portrays it as high-tech and exciting."
Another reason is simple economic opportunity. Although there are no statistics about employment in the risk management industry -- as private investigation companies now call themselves -- many firms say that in the wake of last year's corporate scandals and the threat of terrorism, the paranoia business is booming. Revenues at Kroll, a 2,300-employee company with offices around the globe, were up nearly 40 percent in 2002, to $289 million, compared with 2001. Robert Tucker, 33, who is the chairman and chief executive of T&M Protection Resources, one of New York City's largest security and investigations firms, said his company now has 800 employees, six times as many as it had in 1999. 
"If you're good at it, there's an untold amount of work," he said.
Perhaps the biggest change has been in the industry itself, which has come to favor computer-savvy database wizards over the old-school door-knocking detective. Mike Pattishall, 26, a researcher at Corporate Risk International in Fairfax, Va., said that by searching the online services his company subscribes to, he can get the skinny -- court records, motor vehicle information, property filings, even photographs -- on almost anyone.
"Where in the past it required sending a field agent out to gather information," he said, "now 9 times out of 10 you can find it online."
A walk around the Midtown office of Beau Dietl & Associates, Mr. Dietl's firm, paints a vivid picture of this new way of sleuthing. While former police officers occupy the corner offices -- law enforcement plaques on their walls, pistols on their desks -- a group of people in their 20's with "Law & Order" looks sit in a row of cubicles, clicking away at computer terminals and checking resumes of potential hires of Fortune 500 companies to see, for example, if they really graduated from the schools they list. 
Around town, other investigation firms have similarly youthful staffs. At BackTrack Reports, a background checking firm with offices in a Flatiron district loft, most of the staff members are in their 20's, according to the company's president, Chris Manthey, 37, and no one is older than 40. Mr. Tucker of T&M Protection said that his company employs perhaps 100 people in their 20's, mostly as researchers, to work alongside former F.B.I. agents and police officers.
At Kroll, only about 5 percent of the employees are former police officers, said Jules B. Kroll, the company chairman. The rest, he said, "are the same people who go for analyst positions at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, consulting positions at McKinsey or paralegal positions at top law firms."
At Beau Dietl & Associates, the young researchers are supervised by Frank Renaud, who has a Ph.D. in economics and whose desk is neatly stacked a foot high with color-coded case files. Mr. Renaud said he is less interested in the educational backgrounds of job candidates than in their curiosity.
"I like people who play chess and do crossword puzzles, people trained to ask questions," he said. Starting salaries at a large firm can range from $35,000 to $50,000, depending on experience and expertise. Top-notch investigators can make well into six figures.
Jennifer Elliott, 24, a researcher on Mr. Renaud's team, said that in the course of her computer searches, she had found executives at prominent companies who lied about their college educations. ("We got 'em," she said.) She has been on a couple of surveillances and has found she is good at what the industry refers to as "pretext calls" -- calling people under false pretenses to get information from them. 
"People will tell you anything about themselves," she said.
Ms. Elliott said there is an additional benefit to her job -- telling dates what she does for a living. "I guess you could say they're impressed," she said.
A few desks over, Stephen Heskett, 27 a graduate of the American Musical and Dramatic Academy -- "My formal training," he says -- is working on behalf of a businessman who says he was wrongly accused of attempted murder by a jilted former spouse. Mr. Heskett is out to establish that the accuser is unstable, and he says he is well on his way.
"I don't have a gun and we never jump on cars," Mr. Heskett said when asked if the job lived up to its television billing. "The only weapons we have are laptops."
About 1 of every 10 background checks shows something negative in a person's past, said Peter Turacek, 35, a managing director at Kroll. Many times, he said, the company that asked for the background check ignores alarming information. Mr. Turacek once discovered that a subject was a "bag man" in a murder for hire, but his client was unfazed.
"They said, 'It was 15 years ago,' " he said.
While the majority of P.I. work takes place on a computer, there is still the occasional need for old-school sleuthing, and even that pursuit has been made easier by technology. Mr. Lanigan, the surveillant, has a trove of electronic eavesdropping gadgets, including a pair of sunglasses with a pinhole video camera mounted in the bridge. (He also has a more traditional implement: a gun.) Mr. Lanigan has gone undercover at a nursing home as a janitor; he once caught a 78-year-old woman being unfaithful to her 80-year-old husband; he tailed a rabbi recovering from sex addiction to make sure he had not reverted to his old ways (he had not). And more than once, Mr. Lanigan has had to tell a tearful, suspicious wife that her husband is cheating. "You never like to tell anybody that their worst fears are confirmed," he said. "But it's part of the job."
Mr. Dietl said he is careful to give recruits a reality check about what they can expect if he senses they've been watching too much "CSI."
"A lot of young people are getting the idea from TV that this life is more glamorous than it really is," he said. "The majority of it is tedious work." Even surveillance can be dull, he said. "You're out there for 12 hours looking at a freakin' door."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Is There Still Growth On These Menus?

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
IN the post-Sept. 11 world, many Americans have made it plain that eating away from home should no longer be considered discretionary.
 Despite concerns that people would stay home because of anxiety over their safety or the economy, spending at restaurants has held up well during the last two years, in what is now a $300 billion to $400 billion industry. 
 This year, a Bear Stearns unweighted index of 26 restaurant stocks has been up 19.2 percent. A number of companies, like McDonald's, up 50 percent, have increased much more than that. 
Joseph Buckley, a restaurant analyst at Bear Stearns, discussed whether there is still some sizzle in the stocks. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. Why didn't people stop going out to eat after 9/11?

A. Eating away from home has become such an important part of everyday life. Currently, close to half the dollars spent on food are spent on meals away from home. That is a dramatic shift over the last three or four decades.
 The move to two-wage-earner families, and the fact that baby boomers have grown up with the chains, many of which are about to celebrate their 50th birthdays, are other reasons. 
 In short, dining out has become so ingrained in the American lifestyle that it is cut back very begrudgingly, if at all.

Q. Is the restaurant business still growing?

A. Some parts of it are. In the casual dining sector, which is defined as an average check of $10 to $20 with full service and having alcohol as an option, growth has been great. As America has shifted its food budget to spending more and more away from home, they have become more sophisticated in their spending.
 But the quick service sector is a mature business. For most of these companies, cash from existing stores is far greater than what they can reinvest in the business in general, including new stores.

Q. Why have restaurant stocks done so nicely this year?

A. There has been a resurgence in the fast food sector.
 Last year sales were aggravated due to very intense price discounting, led by McDonald's. Prices softened in the middle of 2002, and they stayed soft until about the middle of this year. So many of these stocks started their move upward from pretty low levels.

Q. Have healthier menu choices helped the quick service companies?

A. Over the last year or so, salads have played a significant role in driving sales at McDonald's and Wendy's. It will be interesting to see if the consumer continues to buy them.

Q. Have events of the past couple of years had an adverse effect on international sales of fast-food chains?

A. Very few of these companies have a significant international business. McDonald's is by far the biggest. Yum Brands, which owns Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, has a presence, and Starbucks is trying to develop an international business.
 McDonald's international business has been soft, but I don't think it is because of what has happened since 9/11. 
 Of their three major European markets, the United Kingdom, Germany and France, France has been the best. And there has been more tension between the United States and France than the others. International business at Yum, which is much more skewed to Asia, has been very strong.

Q. Will restaurant chains pay bigger dividends?

A. There will be much more significant dividend payments. Last month, McDonald's raised its dividend by 70 percent, to 40 cents from 23 cents. The reason they are going to do it is because now they are more mature businesses, they don't need the cash flow.
Yum doesn't pay a dividend now, but we think they will initiate one in the next 12 to 18 months. Wendy's pays a small dividend now, and we think it is likely to increase it. The same is true for Applebee's.

Q. Which individual stocks do you especially like?

A. We like McDonald's and Yum in quick service, and Applebee's and Brinker, which has an investment banking relationship with Bear Stearns, in the casual dining area. We are looking for improved sales at McDonald's and Yum.
 We think consensus sales estimates for McDonald's are too low. As a result, we think there is further upside to the stock. Yum has transitioned from a financial restructuring story to an operating story. Investor perception has lagged that change. 
 Brinker has a very broad restaurant portfolio, which includes Chili's, Macaroni Grill and On the Border. They can grow units at 10 to 12 percent, which is well above average for the industry. 
 We like the franchising model at Applebee's. And their takeout business has been a catalyst for growth.

HEADLINE: The Two Worlds Of Justin Moore 

BYLINE:  By LAUREL GROSS

 BODY:
JUSTIN MOORE, a 27-year-old transplant from Florida who came to New York nearly three years ago, talks about his goals as if he has already achieved them. All he has ever wanted to be is a rock star, and he may have what it takes. Slinky and lean, with silky dark hair and a mysterious scar on his left cheek, he radiates charm and a certain bad-boy mystique. There is something sweet about him, too. 
 Leaning across the counter of Mail Boxes Etc., the package and mailing store on Eighth Avenue near West 12th Street in Greenwich Village where he has worked for about 15 months, he folds his hands across his chest and looks eager to please. He believes in doing a job well, even a job that involves making a prodigious number of photocopies and drowning in bubble wrap. 
 By night, he is every inch a rock 'n' roller. And even in these tight quarters, it is easy to imagine him on a stage electrifying an audience, his long hair whipping across his face while the music rips, his entire body vibrating as intensely as the strings of his own guitar. 
 For almost three years, Mr. Moore and the band Orange Park have been making the rounds of clubs on the Lower East Side like Arlene Grocery, Don Hill's, Sin-e and Mercury Lounge, as well as Brooklyn night spots like Galapagos in Williamsburg and Southpaw in Park Slope. On Saturday, Orange Park will perform at Luna Lounge on Ludlow Street as part of the annual CMJ Festival. 
 That the band's first gig was atop the World Trade Center, at a party and rock show at Windows on the World, is in some ways deeply telling. The attack of Sept. 11, 2001, combined with a punishing local economy and housing costs that are prohibitive for most young people, have made it ever tougher to chase a dream to the big city. 
 Yet every New York minute, another young hopeful arrives in town yearning to write the ground-breaking novel, to score the hit role, or even the part in the chorus. Even in hard times, it seems, everyone wants to eat breakfast at Tiffany's. 

Heading North in a U-Haul
 The band's journey began in Orange Park, the Jacksonville, Fla., suburb that gave the group its name and the place where Mr. Moore and his three band mates grew up. Justin and his older brother, Jeff, wanted to be rock stars ever since they were little children using hairbrushes as stand-in guitars. Although Justin's only musical training was a year of guitar lessons when he was a child, he was raised in a house filled with music; an uncle was a gospel singer and another relative was a jazz pianist. 
 The Beatles and especially John Lennon were an important influence. 
 "I remember me and my brother sitting on the living floor when we were kids," Mr. Moore said, "and my aunt gave Jeff the Blue and Red albums of the Beatles. We used to lie on the floor and listen to them. I think it was "Sergeant Pepper," where the music gets really crazy at the end and it goes on and on, and we used to just twirl around in circles and get really dizzy and lie down and close our eyes to that last part. And it's like I'll never forget that." 
 By age 15, Justin, along with brother Jeff, a cousin, Jaye Moore, and a high school friend named Chris Harvey, who even back then went by the name Harv, formed a band called the Lysergic Garage Party that performed in local clubs and bars. But the two brothers eventually had what Mr. Moore calls a falling out over who would call the shots in the band, and the group, minus Justin, came north in 1997. 
 The two brothers talked only a few times over a couple of years, Justin recalls. But one night around 3 a.m., he got a call from Jeff, who was living in Williamsburg with the other two band members: Would Justin consider coming to New York to see if they could all work together again? 
 Several weeks later, Justin was heading north in a rented U-Haul with his longtime girlfriend and all his stuff. He arrived the day he left, driving straight through to the city on New Year's Day 2001. Three weeks later, reborn as Orange Park, the four musicians did their first gig together, at Windows on the World. It is weird, Mr. Moore says, to think of it now. 

I'm George, You're Paul
 As with their beloved Beatles, each member of Orange Park has a different persona. There's the angry but sensitive young man (Justin), the quiet one (Harv), the artistic one (Jeff) and, well, the drummer (Jaye). The two brothers share lead vocals, guitar and songwriting duties, and fastidiously alternate their songs in performance and on their two self-produced CD's. 
 These days, the band members perform wearing jeans and T-shirts, and they play as a tight, controlled unit, with a bouncy, melodic sound that is reminiscent of the Beatles; The Village Voice described their music as "enthusiastically dreamy vocal-and-guitar harmony power-pop." Other reviewers have likened Orange Park to Cheap Trick, the Foo Fighters and Dinosaur Jr.
 But in the old days, they used to let it all hang out, almost literally. 
 Mr. Moore once appeared in a show in Jacksonville wearing nothing except his guitar and one of those little aprons that waitresses wear to stash tips. Harv used to wear dresses. 
 "It was partly an excuse to party, you know, drink beer and alcohol and make music," Mr. Moore said. "We always had songs back then, but we were also about going nuts." 
 "You have to keep back a little to actually play well," he said. "It's hard to do that when you're jumping around and freaking out." 

Master of the $2 Expenditure
 Much as Mr. Moore glories in his life as a musician, the personal costs are high. Since coming to New York, he has lost one apartment after another. He has lived in four different places; his last room, in a shared apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, was turned into somebody's darkroom. At the moment he is what he calls "in between homes," staying downtown with a friend. 
 Mr. Moore isn't the only band member with an unlikely job that helps pay the bills. His brother trucks apples from orchards outside the city and delivers them to fancy-food shops. His cousin waits on tables at the Ginger Man restaurant on East 36th Street near Fifth Avenue. Nobody's sure what Harv does for a living. "You have to ask Harv," they say. At least with strangers, Harv doesn't talk much. 
 Mr. Moore might as well have a master's degree in frugality; it seems that no one could make so much of so little. He is master of the $2 expenditure: The $2 meal. The $2 bar beer (Pabst Blue Ribbon). The $2 thrift-shop T-shirts he wears on stage. 
 He is also a master at making several meals out of what most people would consider one. Eight dollars buys spaghetti four times a week. All you need, he says, is "Ragu and three different kinds of pasta shells, and you fool yourself that it's a different meal each time." Other menu options involve turkey sandwiches and cheese. "I like cheese," he says. 
 He is immensely inventive. He used a portable tape recorder to record his songs whenever inspiration struck. When the recorder broke, his solution was phoning in the lyrics and music into his girlfriend's answering machine. 
 Still, in his eyes, the desire to perform and to get his music heard is worth the effort; nothing turns him on the way music does. "Nothing ever came close," he said. "There's no other reason to be here, for me, really. I mean really, literally. There's not." 
 For him, chasing this dream is like being a trapeze artist flying without a net. There's no fallback position, no plan B. Anyway, he added: "This is the only thing that we all thought we were halfway decent at. So we might as well give it everything we have. It's like, what else do we have in this life to do?"

Days Amid the Cartons
 It's a big dream to squeeze into such a small place, and like so many other young people who hold tedious day jobs while trying to make it in the arts, Mr. Moore checks his dreams at the door when he comes to work in the morning. The shop itself is shaped like a mailbox, a narrow sliver of a corridor with a counter at the far end and copier machines flanking the walls. 
 Cartons are stacked up in the window, and from where Mr. Moore stands, it's a long way to the door. Especially at the end of a long day, when the weight of his double life gets the best of him, one gets the feeling that he might like to pack himself into one of those cartons and get himself mailed away, straight to stardom. 
 Mr. Moore is not the only worker at Mail Boxes with a double life; nearly everyone he works with has one; his colleague, Richard Rose, has appeared on television shows like "The Gilmore Girls" and "E.R."; another, Dennis Gereritz, freelances for Latino publications. Jenn Feldman is studying education at Queens College. But most of the customers have no idea what Mr. Moore does when he's off duty. 
 For Mr. Moore, this particular day in midsummer is much like any other. What he wants to do is sing, write songs, play guitar, or all three. Instead he is wrestling with an expensive but ill-behaved modern chair that someone wants to ship somewhere. He has wrapped it carefully in bubble wrap, but it won't fit into any box he tries. 
 What makes this moment more poignant is that Orange Park is about to go on tour, eight cities in 13 days, and Mr. Moore seems edgy. He looks exhausted, from rehearsing and working, and he hasn't been sleeping. For weeks, he has been wired. 
 While Orange Park has been on tour before, often opening for the band Longwave, they have never spent so many days away or gone to so many places. The band will cover 8,700 miles traveling cross country and back; one leg of the return journey, from Montana to Pennsylvania, will require 30 hours of straight driving. At 6-foot-1, Mr. Moore doesn't like long car trips. 
 Meanwhile, he's struggling with that recalcitrant chair. With the help of Ms. Feldman, they finally tuck the thing into a larger box and cut away some of the bubble wrap to reduce the bulk. Mr. Moore takes over the job of pouring in packing peanuts. 
 Even with such a prosaic task, he is a perfectionist, and for good reason: Mistakes that are due to a packer's negligence can be costly; damages can be docked from pay. Mr. Moore takes home $350 a week for working 35 or 40 hours, and every dollar counts. 
 A couple of months after the tour, Mr. Moore was back at Mail Boxes, this time sitting on the curb outside the store. It was a mild September evening, the shop was shut tight for the night, and he was waiting for the band to pick him up in their van. They were going to Luna Lounge to perform, and the boys were running late. 
 Something he had said on another occasion seemed to resonate this evening: 
 "It's like I'm two different people. I feel like a totally different person when I'm walking in with the band, and when I come to work. It's like Clark Kent and Superman. It's just a little hard one night to be signing autographs for fans, and the next day signing a fax for someone." 
 His father, Mack Moore, describes his son's character switch another way.
 "He is a little different when he's at Mail Boxes, or at work," said his father, who works as a headhunter for mortgage banking companies. "He is somewhat reserved, but when he starts performing, it's like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. He really gets into it."

Pyrotechnics in the Performance
 The Justin Moore who played Luna Lounge that September evening was anything but reserved. He was as plugged in as his guitar.
 The band doesn't go in for gimmicky costumes or special effects. The pyrotechnics are in the music and the performances. In the big send-off, for example, Jeff's song "Wouldn't Change a Thing," the two brothers unleashed a let-it-all-go dueling guitar riff that made you fear their strings would pop. 
Audience members on the banquettes along the walls leaned forward on their pillows; others climbed on the backs of their seats to get a better view. The floor in front of the stage was a sea of bobbing heads; a female fan, a regular, danced in the front row. 
 The band performs only its own songs, and Mr. Moore seems to write his as a way of making sense of the people in his life, especially the women. Some of those songs can be heard on the band's Web site, www.orangeparkmusic.com.
 "The song 'Glass' is about a girl I was with at the time," he said, "and I realized that I could never really figure her out, which is so weird to me. When you look at someone and see how they are, and it's like, 'You live your life in a box made of locks' and I could never figure out the combination." 
 "Once in My Life" tells the story of the wrenching breakup of a long relationship. It was inspired, Mr. Moore said, by the end of his affair with the woman who came north with him and with whom he had lived for seven years. 
 What to say and what you said 
 Words have gone and love is dead 
I wish that I would have known 
 What to say and what to do 
 When everything has died in you, 
 I wish that I would have known. 
 At the time of the breakup, he said, he felt pretty hopeless about everything. But, he explained: "Those seven years, and all that I went through afterward, was worth it to get that three minutes of song. No matter how awful life gets, it's O.K. if you get a good song out of it. The situation fades away. But the song lasts forever."

HEADLINE: No Wonder There's Gridlock; 
Why the City Has All Those Cars

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "No Room to Vroom: New Memories of Gridlock Past" (Oct. 12): The return of gridlock to Midtown is not a result of New York's economic recovery, but due to actions taken by the city in the past year that encourage the use of motor vehicles. 
The city looked the other way while the Metropolitan Transportation Authority drastically raised transit fares. It sidelined the plan to replace the 9/11 car pool restrictions with congestion pricing modeled after the scheme used in London. 
 Public transit is already the dominant of mode of travel to Manhattan's central business district, accounting for 88 percent of the 1.3 million people in the area at midday. Mass transit is an acceptable way to travel, and the city ought to help make it more popular by charging a modest fee for drivers and using the proceeds to improve mass transit. With fewer cars, the city could allocate more street space for pedestrians, greatly improving the economic viability of its central business district. 

GEORGE HAIKALIS
Greenwich Village

The writer is president of the Institute for Rational Urban Mobility, an advocacy group on transportation issues.

HEADLINE: HARVESTING POVERTY; 
The Fabric of Lubbock's Life

 BODY:
Lubbock is a rock-solid, conservative kind of place, located where northwest Texas meets the southernmost part of the great American plains. Its citizens like to think of themselves as self-reliant straight talkers. It seems strange, then, to think of this region as a sprawling welfare case. 
 But the cotton farms that give Lubbock much of its identity thrive from huge government subsidies that drain the federal treasury and shelter the industry from the discipline of the market. The rest of the world rightfully regards those subsidies as unfair to poor countries, whose cotton farmers cannot compete against the below-cost prices at which American cotton sells. 
 America's cotton farmers are currently at the center of an international outcry against the way rich countries rig the trade game with protective tariffs or agricultural subsidies. "Judging by what's written in some Eastern newspapers you'd think I murdered my parents or something," says Ronnie Hopper, a cotton grower in nearby Petersburg. Mr. Hopper, 57, grows some of the most coveted cotton in the world on a 2,500-acre high-tech farm. But most years his costs exceed the global price, which is why he has relied on nearly a half-million dollars of subsidies since 1995.
"Why do you want to get rid of me?" asked Mr. Hopper, who works hard and plays by the rules as the government sets them. Like many farmers who receive subsidies -- a glaring exception to America's ostensible free-market values -- he argues that the United States needs some agricultural self-sufficiency and that no cotton farmer could break even at market prices.
Indefensible as the subsidies are, it's impossible not to feel sympathy for his situation. Lubbock is in the heart of the national cotton belt, and the idea that the United States is no longer well positioned to grow cotton at all is shocking in the top-producing cotton state, where in Dallas last weekend, Texas played Oklahoma in the venerable Cotton Bowl.
There is actually no sign that American cotton farmers are going to suffer from anything but hurt feelings in the short run. The 2002 farm bill's complex cotton subsidies will continue at least until 2007, giving farmers the right to a direct payment of 6 cents for every pound of upland cotton, plus loans pegged at 52 cents a pound. Besides helping growers pay off their loans if the price dips below that, Uncle Sam then makes what are known as countercyclical payments to allow farmers to obtain a lofty "target price" of 72 cents a pound. All told, with this web of federal supports -- which can exceed $3 billion in some years -- American taxpayers often end up footing as much as two-thirds of the cost of growing America's exported cotton. 
This helps the United States, among the world's highest-cost cotton producers, rank first in exports. Dumped abroad at below cost, our cotton depresses prices and hurts farmers in poor nations like Mali or Burkina Faso that cannot set aspirational "target prices."
African farmers are aware that they are competing in a fixed game -- many believe, incorrectly, that President Bush is a cotton farmer himself. They are rightfully outraged that a nation that enjoys all the benefits of open markets for its industrial products keeps putting up walls around its farmers. 
At the recent World Trade Organization meeting in Cancun, where attempts to reform the agricultural trade rules ended in failure, widespread outrage against American cotton subsidies dominated the headlines. 
If all protectionism disappeared tomorrow, the poor farmers of the world would not all benefit. Small corn or wheat growers abroad might not be able to compete against the huge, efficient farms of the fertile American Midwest. Peasants with tiny plots of land would inevitably give way to bigger agricultural enterprises. There is no magic fix to a world order in which the rich countries invariably hold most of the cards. But the global community has to start moving in the right direction, giving farmers in the poorest countries an opportunity to compete where they have a chance to do so.
The "cotton-picking truth," as they might say in rural Texas, is that the United States has no business growing 16 million bales of cotton a year. Continuing to deny this reality is patently unfair. If the United States eliminated the subsidies, the world prices for cotton would rise, helping farmers overseas but having minimal effect on consumers (there is only about a dollar's worth of cotton in a pair of jeans). It would save the American taxpayers billions of dollars, and it would allow Americans to strike a very visible blow for fairness between rich countries and poor.
The pain in Lubbock, of course, would be real, as it is in any region where new economic patterns deal a mortal blow to a local industry. The government needs to help such places make the transition to businesses with a future. But it cannot afford to prop up inefficient ventures forever. It is not fair to other regions that were forced to accept change, lost jobs and an end to old ways of life. It is not fair to the poor, cotton-producing countries. The subsidies are a bad deal for everyone but the American cotton farmers, and they leave the United States in an unconscionably hypocritical stance when it faces the rest of the world. Free trade cannot work a la carte, only for those sectors where we stand to win.

Harvesting Poverty: Editorials in this series remain online at nytimes.com/harvestingpoverty.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Wal-Mart, Driving Workers and Supermarkets Crazy

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
IN February Wal-Mart will open its first grocery supercenter in California, offering everything from tires to prime meats, and that could be a blessing for middle-class consumers. The reason is simple: Wal-Mart's prices are 14 percent lower than its competitors', according to a study by the investment bank UBS Warburg.
 But not everyone is rejoicing about Wal-Mart's five-year plan to open 40 supercenters in California, stores combining general merchandise and groceries that are expected to gobble up $3.2 billion in sales. California's three largest supermarket chains, Ralphs, Vons and Albertsons, are scared, and so are tens of thousands of supermarket workers whose union contracts have put them solidly in the middle class. The three grocers' fears of fierce competition from Wal-Mart and their related drive to cut costs are widely seen as the main reason behind the week-old strike by 70,000 workers at 859 supermarkets in Southern California. 
 Wal-Mart has already helped push more than two dozen national supermarket chains into bankruptcy over the past decade. That list includes names like Grand Union; Bruno's, once Alabama's largest supermarket chain; and Homeland Stores, formerly Oklahoma's largest. And unionized supermarket workers fear that Wal-Mart's invasion will oust them from the middle class by pulling down their wages and benefits, which, taken together, are more than 50 percent higher than those of Wal-Mart workers. At Wal-Mart, the average wage is about $8.50 an hour, compared with $13 at unionized supermarkets.
"Wal-Mart's superstores are going to have a devastating impact on California's supermarkets," said Burt Flickinger III, a retailing consultant, noting that union wages and prices are higher in California than in most of the country.
Eager to stay competitive against Wal-Mart, Albertsons, Vons (owned by Safeway) and Ralphs (owned by Kroger) have demanded a two-year wage freeze for current workers, a lower pay scale for new hires and greater employee contributions for health coverage. Those employees now pay no health insurance premiums, while Wal-Mart employees often must pay premiums of $200 a month and deductibles of up to $1,000 a year, if they qualify. 
With Wal-Mart in mind, supermarkets have engaged in tough bargaining across the country. That has led to a 12-day-old strike by 10,000 supermarket workers in Missouri and a six-day-old strike by 3,000 workers at 44 Krogers in West Virginia, Kentucky and Ohio. 
It is hard to underestimate the power of Wal-Mart. It has 1.4 million employees and had $245 billion in revenues last year, equaling 2.5 percent of the gross domestic product. Each week 138 million shoppers visit Wal-Mart's 4,750 stores. Last year, 82 percent of American households bought at least one item there.
Wal-Mart sells 32 percent of the nation's disposable diapers, and it is the largest customer for Walt Disney and Procter & Gamble. It has singlehandedly persuaded music companies to issue sanitized versions of CD's. Its 1,397 supercenters account for 19 percent of the nation's grocery sales, making it the largest grocery retailer. With Wal-Mart planning 1,000 more supercenters in the next five years, Retail Forward, a consulting firm, estimates that Wal-Mart's grocery and drug sales will double to $162 billion, giving it 35 percent of the domestic food market and 25 percent of the drug market.
When Wal-Mart goes like gangbusters into an area, as it plans to do in California, competitors often feel panic. In Dallas, its share of the grocery market has soared to 16.4 percent from 8.5 percent in the past two years, according to TradeDimensions International.
"We have been in business for 68 years, and in that period of time, we have seen dozens of competitors come and go," said Jack Brown, president of Stater Brothers, a supermarket chain in the Orange County and San Diego areas. "However, Southern California has never seen as big a competitive threat as the Wal-Mart supercenter." 
Many factors explain Wal-Mart's ability to charge low prices, including economies of scale, the pressures it puts on suppliers and its embrace of imports -- it imported $12 billion in goods from China last year, one-tenth of American imports from China. 
Another big factor is Wal-Mart's relatively low wages. Its sales clerks average about $8.50 an hour, or about $14,000 a year, while the poverty line for a family of three is $15,060. In California, the unionized stockers and clerks average $17.90 an hour after two years on the job. Mr. Flickinger said wages and benefits for Wal-Mart's full-time workers average $10 to $14 per hour less than for unionized supermarket workers.
"The strike out here involves workers who enjoy decent wages, vacations and health benefits," said Kent Wong, director of the Center for Labor Research and Education at the University of California at Los Angeles. "These things were taken for granted, they made them part of the middle class, but now these workers are threatened with having these things taken away."
A big savings for Wal-Mart comes in health care, where Wal-Mart pays 30 percent less for coverage for each insured worker than the industry average. An estimated 40 percent of employees are not covered by its health plan because many cannot afford the premiums or have not worked at Wal-Mart long enough to qualify.
"What this means is, if I'm a Wal-Mart employee and I hurt my hand and go to the emergency room, who's going to pay for it? The taxpayer is," said Mr. Brown, the supermarket executive. "Wal-Mart's fringe benefits are being paid by taxpayers."
Wal-Mart officials say that their expansion will be a boon for California consumers and that their wages and benefits are competitive. Why else, they ask, would 600,000 workers take jobs at Wal-Mart each year?
Greg Denier, chief spokesman for the United Food and Commercial Workers, said the fear of Wal-Mart's supercenters is the main cause for the California strike, but he argued that the supermarkets have exaggerated the threat as a strategy to squeeze their workers. 
"They keep saying they have to do this because Wal-Mart is bringing supercenters to California," he said, "but it's part of a national program to ratchet down wages and benefits." 
Yet Wall Street analysts and retailing consultants say the California supermarkets, like others across the country, risk being stomped by Wal-Mart.

HEADLINE: U.S. OVERCAPACITY STALLS NEW JOBS 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: CINCINNATI 

 BODY:
Much of the public outcry over America's failure to generate jobs has focused lately on a surge in the outsourcing of work to China and India. But another dynamic closer to home is weighing on job creation -- the slow process of working through a glut of boom-era investment that continues to litter the economy with underused factories.
 Procter & Gamble, for example, has been dumping its weakest brands and the plants that produce them. At its Ivorydale industrial complex here, in Procter's hometown, the company has sold factories that make Crisco shortening, Olean fat substitute and Ivory soap to three manufacturers, each with plans for squeezing efficiencies from the operations. Hiring more workers is the last item on their agendas. 
 "As long as there is extra capacity available in manufacturing, there is going to be room to move work around among companies without having to add workers," said Thomas A. Kochan, a labor and management expert at the Sloan School of Management of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
That is true with a vengeance today. Not since the severe recession of the early 1980's has capacity use in manufacturing stayed so low for so long, government data show. Production as a percentage of total capacity fell precipitously in the aftermath of the last recession, which ended in 2001, and 23 months into the recovery, the upturn has still not come. On average, manufacturers are using less than 73 percent of their capacity. 
Struggling to get rid of this costly glut, many companies continue to shut plants and lay off the workers, as the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is doing in Huntsville, Ala., where it is closing a tire plant that employs 1,100 people. Or they have consolidated operations in one or two sites instead of a dozen, as Procter itself has done in the production of detergents, eliminating workers in the process. Other companies, notably the nation's automakers, have discounted prices and offered rebates to sustain production at respectable rates of capacity -- a tactic that squeezes profits and discourages hiring.
And now some companies, Procter among them, are selling or leasing plants to others who gamble they can make a profit by finding buyers for the excess output. Whatever success the newcomers have in this endeavor contributes to the nation's sharply rising productivity growth rate, by increasing output without adding workers -- a dynamic that prolongs the "jobless recovery." 
"We overbuilt capacity; we hired too many people," A. G. Lafley, Procter's chairman, said in a speech last spring. The company invested in the 1990's in anticipation of reaching $50 billion in annual sales, but Procter's managers now find themselves rattling around in a company with $43.4 billion in sales. Cutting back, Mr. Lafley has focused resources on the largest, most profitable brands -- Pampers diapers, for example -- and freed cash from lesser operations. 
Procter still markets soap under brand names like Ivory, Old Spice, Camay and Olay. Marketing, after all, is the company's core competency, as Mr. Lafley puts it. But manufacturing the soap bars themselves in Cincinnati is not considered a good use of resources -- certainly not in a plant operating at only 50 percent of capacity, as the factory here is. 
"We could have consolidated the Ivorydale production at our bar soap factory in Mexico," said R. Keith Harrison Jr., the Procter vice president in charge of product supply. But the consolidation would have required a $40 million to $45 million investment, he said.
Instead, Procter sold the brick-and-concrete Ivorydale plant last spring to a 10-year-old company, Trillium Health Care Products, which specializes in operating soap factories. As part of the deal, Trillium supplies 235 million pounds of soap a year to Procter and hopes that it will eventually be able to sell another 235 million pounds elsewhere.
For Procter, the supply contract "offered the same cost structure that we could get if we consolidated in Mexico" -- minus the investment, Mr. Harrison said. 
But the arrangement forces Trillium to squeeze labor costs until it can line up more customers and benefit from the rising returns of a factory finally operating at full capacity.
"P.&G. would never bring a direct competitor into this plant to fill up volume, but as a contractor we can do that," said Alan Wedgeworth, a spokesman for Trillium, which is based in Newmarket, Ontario, just north of Toronto.
Trillium hired 165 of Procter's 230 employees, maintaining their old wage of $21 to $24 an hour. But new hires replaced 50 other Procter employees at wages $5 to $8 an hour less. Trillium also brings in more temporary workers than Procter did to handle upward fluctuations in production, Mr. Wedgeworth said, rather than adding to its staff. 
The Employees Representation Association, an independent union that represents Procter's Ivorydale workers, now has contracts with Trillium and three other companies that have bought or leased Ivorydale operations over the last 20 months. Each contract sets a wage scale for new hires that is lower than the old Procter scale.
New hiring, meanwhile, is still in the future for Trillium, which took possession of the soap plant on April 1. For now, "P.&G. is our only customer," Mr. Wedgeworth said. 
Twin Rivers Technologies, another contract manufacturer, has had better luck, although starting from a much lower base. The one newer plant at Ivorydale produces Olestra, a zero-calorie fat substitute that Procter developed in the late 1990's and markets as Olean for use in snack food like Fat-Free Pringles.
Procter listed a value of $150 million for the seven-year-old plant, whose collection of cooking vats and piping makes it look like a high-rise refinery. But a health warning from the Food and Drug Administration, only recently lifted, held down Olestra sales, and the plant was operating at just 10 percent of capacity when Procter sold it to Twin Rivers in February 2002. 
Twin Rivers has since doubled output to 20 percent, said Paul J. Angelico, the company's president -- but not because Procter has increased its purchases of Olestra, or because other buyers have signed up in significant numbers.
Rather, Twin Rivers has managed to market a different form of the ingredients in Olestra as a food additive, Mr. Angelico said. And his engineers are producing another product, partly refined glycerin, at the Olestra plant. But that, in turn, allowed Procter -- which makes glycerin at Ivorydale for use in hair- and skin-care products and in toothpaste -- to shift some of the processing to Twin Rivers, eliminating more than five jobs, Mr. Angelico said.
"You take over a process that used to take place there," he said. "It reduces output there, and we did not have to add any staff to increase output here."
Twin Rivers employs 34 people at the Olestra plant, two-thirds of them technicians hired from Procter, and the rest new people hired at lower wage rates. The payroll will not grow, Mr. Angelico said, until capacity use climbs to at least 50 percent.
Procter took a different approach with Crisco, the shortening first made at Ivorydale in 1911 and now produced here in Cincinnati in a highly automated factory surrounded by 30 acres of processing facilities and storage tanks.
Crisco and Jif peanut butter, made at a Procter plant in Lexington, Ky., had fallen far down Procter's list of priorities. They were "not going to be part of our long-term strategic fit," Mr. Harrison said. So in June 2002, the company sold the brands and their factories to the J. M. Smucker Company, the manufacturer of jams and preserves. 
Smucker paid in stock -- one Smucker share for every 50 Procter shares, a handsome bonus for Procter's stockholders. Without incurring any additional costs, Smucker doubled its annual revenue overnight, to nearly $1.4 billion. And while Smucker took on 190 workers at the Criscoplant and 150 in Lexington, no jobs were created by the transaction.
"We are organized to operate at multiple plant locations; even our sales staff has not grown," said Stephen Landry, the Crisco plant manager, who now says "we" in referring to Smucker. "We were already calling on the jam and jelly buyers at the supermarkets, and they are the ones who also often buy peanut butter and Crisco," he said.
Procter, meanwhile, freed marketing personnel to work on more profitable brands. It has also shrunk its work force, mainly through early retirements, which were an option for some of the displaced Ivorydale workers, including several who had worked at the complex's steam and electric power plant. Procter got rid of that, too, leasing the plant a year ago to Cinergy, a utility company. 
Within six months, the 34 boilerhouse job slots had been cut to 17, and a big portion of the maintenance was turned over to employees already on the Cinergy payroll. The 17 survivors all came over from Procter at their existing pay of nearly $25 an hour, but new hires, if any, will start at $16 an hour. 
Procter & Gamble is not done with this sort of cost cutting. "I intend to not see any cost increase," Mr. Harrison said of the manufacturing and supply operations he oversees. "In fact, I'm looking for about another 10 percent cost decrease over the balance of the decade."

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
A Family Problem Prompts a Career

BYLINE:  By Abby Ellin; This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Until a few months ago, Sam Williams never really thought of himself as a career man. Instead, he worked at odd jobs that required no specific skills: as a visiting nurse's escort; a mailroom clerk at a local hospital; a day laborer on various construction sites. But nothing spoke to him except one thing: asthma prevention.
 East Harlem, where Mr. Williams lives, has one of the highest asthma rates in the United States. A 2002 study conducted, in part, by Harlem Hospital and the Harlem Children's Zone, a nonprofit advocacy group, found that 25.5 percent of children under 13 living in a 24-block area in central Harlem were asthmatic. 
 These statistics hit home for Mr. Williams: his daughters, 8 and 17, have battled asthma since infancy. "I wanted to learn more about it so I can help my kids," said Mr. Williams, 38. "They each get hospitalized at least twice a year. They need steroids to open up their lungs."
 Dr. Suzanne Gaynor, assistant professor of community and preventative medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the co-founder of the East Harlem Asthma Working Group, an organization dedicated to combating asthma, points out that "East Harlem has the highest rate of pediatric asthma hospitalization in the country."
 Last year, Dr. Gaynor received a one-year grant from the Environmental Protection Agency and a three-year grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to develop a program to alleviate Harlem's high asthma rates and to provide long-term asthma management. In the hope of hiring East Harlem residents to help her improve home environments, she called Strive, a 19-year-old nonprofit job training and placement agency that focuses on socially and economically disadvantaged individuals.
 Around the same time, Mr. Williams, who has one year of college under his belt, returned to Strive, with which he had been involved off and on since its inception.
Lawrence Jackson, director of Strive's Career Path program, knew about Mr. Williams's asthma concerns, and told him about the organization's relationship with Mount Sinai. Mr. Williams was intrigued, and enrolled in Strive's Brownfields training program, an eight-week course that teaches students how to monitor the air for pollutants and toxic waste as well as how to clean up affected areas. On completion, participants receive OSHA certification and become proficient in First Aid, CPR and lead abatement.
 After Mr. Williams graduated, Strive helped him land a position as a technician with Microecologies, an indoor-environmental consultancy in Manhattan that was one of Mount Sinai's contractors. He spends his days cleaning mold-infested walls, repairing underlying pipes and installing safe molding. "I've got all these new skills now," Mr. Williams said.
 "The goal is to remove any asthma trigger in the home: roaches, rodents, dust, mold," said Dr. Gaynor, who oversees the project. "We go in and do a hands-on approach, working with mothers to clean the homes properly." More than 50 apartments have been inspected and cleaned in the six months since the program began.
 Although no one knows for certain why the asthma rates are so high in East Harlem, experts believe that mold, mildew, fumes from gas stoves, dust and cockroach droppings play a large role. Cigarette smoke doesn't help. Nor, for that matter, does air pollution.
 In September, hundreds of East Harlem residents and Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton demonstrated against the opening of a bus depot on East 99th Street. According to environmental experts, diesel exhaust can also contribute to high asthma rates.
 If Mr. Williams has his way, he will be part of the team helping to fight asthma for a long time to come.
 Dr. Gaynor is equally hopeful that Mr. Williams will continue to be involved. 
 "He'll have 18 solid months of employment in a specialized-skills area, and it's possible there will be a permanent job for him with Microecologies," she said. "Unfortunately, this kind of work is very much in demand."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sam Williams, who was cleaning the ventilation ducts at a Manhattan apartment building, has been trained to rid the environment of pollutants and toxic waste. (Photo by Alan Chin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Some Stories Are So Jarring They Don't Go Away

BYLINE:  By FRAN SCHUMER

 BODY:
ON the last Monday in September, about 5 p.m., my son and I were driving past the Short Hills train station when we noticed four men placing a white sheet over the tracks. We had just come from the orthopedist's office, which is why I had a book with me. For the third time, I was reading "Anna Karenina," whose grim ending -- in which Anna throws herself in front of a train -- we had recently discussed. Perhaps that's why we guessed instantly what had happened.
 Richard Josephs, an unemployed banker, apparently threw himself in front of a train, and the body of his 7-year-old son, Eric, was later found at home with marks on his neck. An official said the boy had probably been strangled. 
 By now the story is old news, but some stories don't go away, no matter how hard you wish they would.
 Every time I drive by the white Tudor house with red trim and a picket fence, I think about how a person could have found himself in such despair that he was willing to sever what psychologists call his social contract, his connection with the human race. And I wonder if anyone else I know, a colleague, a relative, could find himself in that position.
 In the United States, a person commits suicide every 17.2 minutes. Women attempt it three times as often as men, but men succeed by much larger numbers. The ratio of male to female suicides in the United States is currently four to one, a figure that holds for other countries with some exceptions. In China, the suicide rate is highest among rural women for reasons experts are still trying to fathom.
 Within the United States, depending on the year, New Jersey, Massachusetts and New York generally trade places as the state with the lowest rate. In 2001, the last year for which statistics were available, New Jersey ranked 49th, which sounds hopeful until you consider that even at the bottom of the list, it lost 588 residents to suicide. The greatest frequency is in Nevada, Wyoming, New Mexico -- the mountain states -- and for two main reasons: firearms are more available -- suicides by firearms are by far the most common -- and the population is less dense. Lanny Berman, executive director of the American Association of Suicidology, says that in those states, "the distance between the person in trouble and the persons who can help them is great."
 Richard Josephs was 53 when he, presumably, took his life -- midlife crisis, people are apt to assume. But among men, the rate dips slightly in middle age. Among women, the reverse it true: women from 45 to 54 have the highest rate. Hormones and the emptying nest are the main reasons psychologists cite, but the sad truth is, suicide among the middle aged is wildly understudied.
 "I know personally experts on suicide and seniors and suicide and adolescents," says Dr. John Kalafat, an associate professor at Rutgers and a past president of the suicidology group, "but off the top of my head, I couldn't name an expert on middle-aged suicide."
 Despite New Jersey's low rate, the state has a highly regarded network for survivors. Groups for friends or relatives of suicides exist in Madison, Dumont, Jersey City, Piscataway, Fair Haven, Hamilton, Brant Beach, Lakewood and Somerdale, said Peggy Farrell, chairwoman of the state chapter of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. 
 Ms. Farrell, who is also a facilitator of the Piscataway group, lost a son, an assistant district attorney in New York, to suicide. When she and her other son and three daughters first approached the survivor's group, she thought, "these people aren't going to be like us," she said. "Then you walk in and there they are, just like us."
 Survivor groups function as life rafts, says Karen Dunne-Maxim, a founder of the foundation, who lost a brother to suicide. "Grief is like a sea and you initially feel you're going to drown. You have to try to tread water, but in the water, you are thrown life preservers -- family, friends, reading, talking to other survivors -- and you just need to hang on to those to get to the other side."
 Coping isn't the same as achieving closure.
 "It's a bad word for us because there is no closure," says Ms. Farrell, who adds that even now, a visit to a survivor can stir up old pain. But there is also recovery. "If I can remember Michael now with more joy than sadness, then I can say I've healed."
