HEADLINE: Holding Their Ground 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT

 BODY:
THEY mark off their goals with trash cans, call their own fouls and play without any real sidelines. They each bring two jerseys -- one red and the other yellow -- so they can split up into two teams and play no matter who shows up.
 "This is the longest-running pickup game in America," said Joe Stepien, a regular at the four-times-a-week soccer game, which has made its home in Essex County's Brookdale Park since at least 1981. 
 But two weeks ago, on a Sunday morning, their game was stopped and the 26 soccer players were ushered off the field by a county police officer who arrived with lights flashing. A group of men playing a pick-up football game nearby were also ejected. The confrontation set off a firestorm of emotions, as well as phone calls and e-mail messages to the Essex County executive, Joseph DiVincenzo. 
 "It was quite a scene," said Michael Aron, a political correspondent for New Jersey Network, who was one of the soccer players. "My guys were getting furious at the enormous injustice."
 Although it rarely happens so dramatically, tension is growing across the state because of the shortage of playing fields. At its root is a simple imbalance in supply and demand. The number of organized youth sports leagues has sharply increased over the past two decades. And although the state has added to its reserves of parkland through the Green Acres program, fields of green are still at a premium, particularly in the more developed areas.
 As Bradley M. Campbell, commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental protection, put it, "There are unmet park needs across the state."
 New Jersey Youth Soccer, to name just one sport, now has 167,000 players, compared with about 100,000 only 10 years ago, according to the organization's executive director, Jeanine Willis. At the same time, every year development in the state gobbles up another 28 square miles of open land, according to New Jersey Future, an anti-sprawl group based in Trenton. 
 "We're using up land over three times faster than we're adding people," said Barbara Lawrence, the group's executive director. "It's estimated that we'll be the first state to build out. That means that all the developable land will be developed." 
 Forget about "if you build it, they will come." If a farmer turned his cornfield into a baseball diamond and Shoeless Joe Jackson came back from the dead, he would have to wait in line for a turn to play.
 In real time, the shortage of playing fields pits sport against sport, league against league, residents against non-residents and, as in the case of Brookdale Park, organized teams against weekend scrimmagers.
 "The groups are always in a constant state of negotiation," said William Foelsch, executive director of the New Jersey Recreation and Park Association, a trade group for park administrators. "It does become, in some respects, a turf war."
 Ashley Hammond, president of the Montclair-based Ashley Soccer Camps, which is also a big user of Brookdale Park, agreed with Mr. Foelsch. "There's no question there's a turf war," said Mr. Hammond. "We fight with rugby. We fight with football. There are turf wars everywhere." 
 Only a few miles from Brookdale Park, in nearby Passaic County, a battle is shaping up over Clifton's Littari Park, where the Board of Education there wants to build a middle school. On the gate of the eight-acre community park, which features an adult softball field, tennis courts, a basketball court and a playground, an orange poster declares: "Save our Park. Say No to School. Why Waste Open Space." 
 "It's a tough issue," said Marilyn Laguna, a Clifton resident who on a recent Saturday, was watching her 9-year-old daughter Megan in a recreational tennis clinic at Littari Park. "There is definitely overcrowding in the school. But on the other hand, you have activities like this."
 Even before Littari Park was fingered for possible extinction, Clifton's recreation director, Debbie Oliver, seemed distraught trying to schedule all the games.
 "We're very land-bound," said Ms. Oliver. "There's really no place to grow. If your garage only holds two cars, you can't buy four." 
 Like recreation directors across the state, Ms. Oliver schedules her fields for almost nonstop play, even though she knows it is bad for the resources. "We can't let our fields rest," she said.
 Nor is recreational congestion limited to Clifton. "You could call any town in the state of New Jersey," said John Roberts, executive director of the Recreation Department in Princeton. "Every time we make progress, there are more organized sport groups coming out of the woodwork."
 As a result, municipalities, counties and sports organizations are resorting to unusual, creative and sometimes unsavory, solutions -- like building ball fields on top of former dumps. "We're looking at a capped landfill area as a site for soccer and Little League," Mr. Roberts said.
 Don Murphy, president of the Pop Warner football league in Jackson, said his league is finally leaving a landfill field.
 "We've had such a growth in the township that we basically had to practice on top of a dump," Mr. Murphy said. 
 The league is now midway through building a $750,000 field complex on land leased from the town, he said. He blamed "poor planning" for the shortage of fields, complaining that municipalities issue building permits for new housing but do not require developers to add recreational facilities.
Another solution is to erect lights for night games and practices, though as Ms. Oliver said, "it does put a burden on the neighbors."
 But even if games were scheduled 24 hours a day, satisfying the appetite of every league and pick-up team, there would still be the problem of overuse. Athletic fields, like farmland, should be rested periodically. 
 As for artificial turf, one possible solution, Mr. Roberts of Princeton said: "It's an alternative we're all looking at. But it's unbelievably expensive."
 When the current crop of baby boomers was growing up, the main sport was baseball, and it was all boys, and it usually started at age 8. But Title IX, the 1972 law that prohibited gender discrimination in schools, brought girls onto the playing field. 
 Since then, soccer and, more recently lacrosse, has become hugely popular. Even more exotic sports popularized by recent immigrants -- like cricket and rugby -- have begun to take hold in New Jersey. In addition, parents have demanded sports opportunities for even younger children. New Jersey Youth Soccer, for example, has "micro mini" leagues for children as young as 3, and T-ball starts at 4. 
 And all these children need playing fields.
 This is the demand side of the equation - fueled by a potent combination of expert marketing and parental insecurity.
 Greg Heinzman, director of the Rutgers Youth Sports Research Council, an organization that trains volunteer coaches across the state and studies trends in the field, says that youth sports suffer from an overabundance of parental angst. "The pressure on parents to get their kids signed up is extreme," Mr. Heinzman said. "They're hardly out of their superhero underwear."
 Even more troubling, according to recreation experts, is the way children are being pushed by parents and coaches to specialize in sports -- often with college scholarships in mind -- and playing the selected sport year round. Mr. Heinzman says children's bodies are not built for this kind of activity, and that young athletes are beginning to suffer from the kinds of repetitive-motion sports injuries that were once the province of collegiate and professional athletes.
 "They're specializing to the point of lunacy," said Mr. Roberts.
 One result of specialization is that specific sports are no longer satisfied with a single traditional season. Instead, many have spread their calendar to include two, three and sometimes all four seasons.
 These days, traditional fall sports like soccer are played in the spring too. In Montclair, an indoor soccer facility has extended the season to the winter and the summer. Spring sports like lacrosse have added fall seasons. And baseball is played spring, summer and fall.
 The calculus is undeniable. Add girls, pre-schoolers, new sports and then extend their calendars and the result is teams queuing up like airplanes waiting for a runway.
 Fields do not rest, nor do recreation directors. "You used to have fall soccer and spring baseball," said Ms. Oliver of Clifton. "Now there's fall baseball and spring soccer. It's ruining the fields."
 Pity the poor recreation director, who has to satisfy everyone. "No disrespect to anyone, but if you're a soccer program, that's all you care about," Ms. Oliver said. "You go back to the organization and try to get them to understand that we just can't keep growing seasons. Soccer would play right through the winter if you let them."
 Too much youth sports? Not according to everyone. A few weeks ago on a Saturday, the Clifton Wildcats, a champion travel baseball team that plays three seasons, was on the Eddie Mayo Field in Clifton. Fall baseball only started there in the mid-1990's, one father said, but already it is a proud tradition.
 "It keeps them off the street," said Jack Gomez, the manager of the team.
 Given the rise in childhood obesity, it is hard to argue with children running around on fields. "A whole generation is just exercising their thumbs on video games," Mr. Foelsch said.
 The supply side of the equation is more complicated. In a town like Clifton, for instance, it is not hard to understand why playing fields are scarce. Like many of the older inner-ring suburbs that surround New York City, Clifton is one of the first stops in the western migration of immigrants. Townhouse communities -- some dating from the mid-20th century and some new - are crammed between strip malls, medical complexes and schools. And like most urban areas, the town is people rich but land poor.
 In nearby Paterson -- much more of an urban setting -- the deserted Hinchliffe Stadium, a former high school football field, stands as a symbol of decaying recreation resources. 
 Covered with graffiti, its artificialturf worn thin, and with trees actually sprouting from its bleachers, the eerie relic looks like an ancient coliseum or the setting for a bleak futuristic movie. Although the stadium was earmarked for preservation, there are no signs of it.
 The truth is that concrete-clad stadiums dedicated primarily to high school football are dinosaurs. "The reality of those stadiums is that they're aged," said Mr. Foelsch. "I don't think you're going to see many high school arenas built like they used to be." 
 But the statewide picture of supply -- what lands are available for athletes to run around on -- is not completely bleak. The New Jersey State Outdoor Recreation Plan, published every four years, says in the current issue that the state has almost 200,000 more acres of what it calls "public parkland" than it did in 1994.
 In 1999, Gov. Christie Whitman established the Garden State Preservation Trust with the lofty goal of spending $1 billion to preserve a million acres of open space in the state by 2008. The McGreevey administration is trying to stretch that money further by taking advantage of low interest rates. On the Nov. 4 ballot, voters will be asked to allow the state to borrow an extra $150 million -- capitalizing on the lower interest rates -- for purchasing open space.
 In addition, the McGreevey administration is using state Green Acres funds to renovate parks in the state's denser areas. Earlier this month, Essex County received a $6.9 million state grant to revamp its parks. Part of the money will go toward artificial turf for a playing field in Brookdale Park -- the same one where the pick-up football players were booted off.
 All this is laudable, groups like New Jersey Future and the New Jersey Recreation and Park Association say, though not enough.
 While the state may be preserving open space and parkland, that does not necessarily translate into more playing fields. Much of the land saved is in remote areas and protects aquifers, or as Mr. Foelsch said, "lands that are not conducive to active recreation -- steep slopes, wetlands."
 Mr. Foelsch also believes that other methods besides land acquisition are needed to counteract development. "I don't think there's a balance yet," he said. As a result, his organization recently asked for an additional $50 million in the state budget to improve services in state parks, and it also wants the state's land-use law changed so developers can be assessed "impact fees" to pay for park and recreation space.
 Ms. Lawrence of New Jersey Future thinks that the state will run out of money before accomplishing Mrs. Whitman's goal of buying up a million acres. In the meantime, she is worried about that areas that now seem land-rich -- the rapidly developing towns in the state's exurbs -- will end up in the same land-locked state that inner-ring suburbs now find themselves. "They can't imagine what's going to happen to them," Ms. Lawrence predicted.
 On idyllic fall days when the air is crisp and the trees are crimson, soccer fields look like they have been painted by God. Weather and sports combine in a conspiracy of outdoor delight. That is, unless, you are playing ball under the lights in a climate-controlled environment.
 Rex Plex, a 200,000 square foot "recreational megaplex," as it calls itself, opened three years ago in Elizabeth. Comparable to Chelsea Piers in Manhattan only smaller, Rex Plex offers four indoor soccer fields, a roller hockey rink, a paintball field, two basketball courts, a skate park, a rock-climbing wall as well as the kind of coin-operated entertainment fare found in a Chuck-E-Cheese. Adult soccer leagues and bar mitzvah parties compete for space. There is also an artificial turf outdoor field.
 "I was always looking for places for my kids to play, especially in the fall and winter months," said Randy Taylor, the chairman of Rex Plex. "It's a direct response to what initially was a need for soccer facilities. There's just not enough quality recreation facilities out there." 
 In short, Rex Plex offers a 21st century, for-profit version of the old-fashioned sandlot. Children are dropped off by their mothers and pay $10 or $12 for a session of the sport they're interested in. 
 "Everything is more structured now than it used to be," Mr. Taylor said. "And all these things are organized."
 Mr. Taylor is convinced that Rex Plex is the future of recreation in America, and that the Elizabeth location is just the "beta site" of what will become a large empire.
 Throughout the state, indoor sports complexes dedicated to single sports are also cropping up. Mr. Hammond, of Ashley Soccer Camps, has a 30-year lease on the Soccer Domain, a year-round soccer bubble in downtown Montclair. He uses the field for his own programs, or rents space for as much as $300 an hour to organizations ranging from the Las Vegas Gladiators, a football team that used it for recruiting recently, to the pick-up soccer team that got booted from Brookdale Park.
 "We'd love to find another place to build another facility," Mr. Hammond said. "Everyone and their mother wants to build an indoor facility."
 If Paterson's crumbling coliseum, Hinchlilffe Stadium, is the ghost of Recreation Past, places like Soccer Domain and Rex Plex are the specter of Recreation Future. The same imbalance of supply and demand that has recreation directors pulling out their hair becomes - in a market economy - highly profitable. What could be more American? 
There is only one problem. What to do when the weather is good?
 Even Ashley Hammond appreciates the conundrum. "Who wants to play indoors," he asked, "in the middle of June?"

HEADLINE: THE LAW; 
In New Jersey, Rogue Lawyers Are on the Rise

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
DAVID JOHNSON has seen some strange cases in 27 years of chasing bad lawyers, but the rogue members of the New Jersey bar always find something new to surprise him.
 Take the lawyer who stalked his girlfriend, practiced without a valid license, falsified evidence and lied to a court. Or the attorney who hired a private investigator to snoop on a federal judge presiding over his case. 
 "Who knows why people do what they do," Mr. Johnson said. 
 As director of the state's Office of Attorney Ethics, Mr. Johnson leads 58 investigators and auditors who track down the lawyers who steal from, lie to or otherwise abuse their clients. And it is a job that is getting busier every year, he said.
 Last year set a record for the number of complaints and lawyers disciplined by the courts. The two previous years also saw increases in the number of complaints.
 "It is hard to draw conclusions in year-to-year changes," Mr. Johnson said. "But if you look over the last five years, clearly the trend is up."
 In 2002, the office filed disciplinary charges against 1,472 attorneys. While the number represents a small proportion of the state's 57,484 practicing lawyers, it is enough to leave Mr. Johnson's staff digging through a backlog of cases.
 The most outrageous offense, in Mr. Johnson's opinion, was an attorney who repeatedly called opposing lawyers as witnesses to try to disqualify them, berated judges and accused the court system of conspiring against her. She was suspended, but kept practicing. The court finally disbarred her.
 Most cases are not so spectacular. The majority of lawyers seriously disciplined mishandle or misappropriate their clients' money; just over one-third of all disciplinary cases involve client funds.
 "There are a lot of reasons for it," Mr. Johsnon said. "Certainly the economy does not help. Lawyers, like everyone else, can get financially stressed."
 To many, the words legal and ethics fit together like an elephant in a bikini, but state courts take attorney discipline seriously. After a report criticized the lengthy backlog of cases in 1995, New Jersey poured money into the discipline system, adding staff and strengthening a unit that randomly audits lawyers' business accounts. 
 As for investigating and disciplining lawyers, "New Jersey is considered one of the more aggressive states," said Mark A. Armitage, president of the National Organization of Bar Counsel and a member of the American Bar Association's committee on professional discipline. 
 Mr. Armitage, who is associate director of the legal disciplinary board in Michigan, said New Jersey's reputation for stringent discipline comes from its random financial audits and harsh penalties. He said New Jersey was one of only 10 states that permanently disbar lawyers; most others allow offenders to apply for reinstatement. 
 "New Jersey has the reputation of being very, very tough," he said. 
 Still, the system has its critics. John Paff, president of Citizens for Justice in New Jersey, an advocacy group, said there was too much secrecy involved in the disciplining of lawyers. Currently, the Office of Attorney Discipline screens out about 95 percent of the complaints without filing charges, most of which involve such minor complaints as speaking rudely to clients or failing to pay the office rent on time. 
 But Mr. Paff said there was no way of knowing what the complaints involved because they are kept secret by the Office of Attorney Discipline unless formal charges are filed, and in fact the forms used by the office instruct complainants to keep charges confidential until formally evaluated. 
 Mr. Paff criticized the policy as a restraint of free speech that effectively bars oversight of the discipline system.
 "We are concerned that mistakes might be made on some of them," he said.
 Another complaint about the system centers around the the time it office takes to investigate some cases. Mr. Paff, whose group maintains a list of New Jersey lawyers charged with disciplinary infractions on its Web site -- www.cjnj.org -- said the Office of Attorney Discipline recently filed charges against a lawyer accused of misconduct in September 1996. 
 "What could take seven years to investigate?" Mr. Paff asked.
 The failure to resolve cases speedily was a concern also expressed by lawyers. 
 "I think there are cases that take an astoundingly long time to reach a resolution," said state Senator John Adler, a Democratic from Cherry Hill who is co-chairman of the Judiciary Committee. "Some cases take three, four, five years before they reach a decision."
 Mr. Adler, who has been a lawyer for 19 years, said professional oversight has become more important as the pool of lawyers has expanded. According to the state court, New Jersey had only 11,408 people licensed to practice law in 1970 as against 77,958 last year. (Of those, the state considers 57,484 to be active practitioners based on payments to legal funds.) 
 "As society gets bigger, there is less accountability," he said. "Years ago, you knew who the dishonest lawyers were and you could deal with them by snubbing them professionally. As our society gets bigger, it is harder to keep tabs on who the bad actors are."
 Walter K. Olson, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute who writes frequently on legal issues, said the culture has changed as the law has become more of a business.
 "The idea that was inculcated not that long ago was that lawyers had special obligations that other businesses did not," Mr. Olson said. "Lawyers were officers of the court."
 On the other hand, defenders of the legal profession say the bar has tried to keep up with the changes by strengthening disciplinary boards and by requiring ethical instruction for new lawyers.
 John Leubsdorf, who teaches legal ethics at Rutgers in Newark, said that when he attended law school in the 1960's, ethics was mentioned in passing, and that most states did not begin to require formal instruction until the 1970's. 
 Now, law students are supposed to receive instructions on matters like handling their clients' money or dealing fairly with opponents. 
 "One thing that has happened to the subject in general is it has become less a subject of moral aspiration and more a matter of enforceable law," Mr. Leubsdorf said. 
 Howard M. Erichson, a professor at Seton Hall Law School, said the number of sanctions handed out for unethical conduct was "impressively low."
 "Despite a vigorous attorney discipline process in New Jersey, the total number of sanctions handed out was 237, which is about one-third of a percent of the number of lawyers," Mr. Erison said. "The real question is to what extent is there unethical conduct that does not enter into the system."
 Both Mr. Luebsdorf and Mr. Erichson said it was impossible to measure the effectiveness of an enforcement system simply by looking at the number of sanctions meted out. They said it would be unrealistic, for example, to say that lawyers are behaving better simply because the number of ethics charges decreased without knowing how efficiently the system was working.
 Several years ago, Mr. Leubsdorf said, he studied the legal discipline system in France and found that very few lawyers faced discipline charges in any given year.
 "Is that because they are behaving better, or because they have a weaker discipline system?" he asked.

HEADLINE: A Choice That's Close to Home 

BYLINE:  By Barbara Whitaker

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER has been a happy place to live for a number of small and medium-size companies, including Cybersettle, an online dispute resolution service for insurance companies.
 When the company was getting its feet on the ground, it chose Manhattan for its office. At the height of the technology craze, the company occupied nearly 10,000 square feet on the 16th floor of the MetLife building, paying about $54 a square foot in rent. 
 But in 2000 the world changed. Charles S. Brofman, co-founder and president, started looking for ways to scale back. One of the first things he did was pare staff and move his business to Mount Kisco, closer to his home in Waccabuc. 
"I think when we first started we kind of perceived that in order to make it you have to be in the center of the universe, which is Manhattan," said Mr. Brofman. "Although I love Manhattan and go there all the time, I think that has changed."
The high cost of doing business in the city forced him to look around. By moving to Mount Kisco he cut his rent to $22 a square foot.
"I could have moved to Dutchess County, Rockaway or Long Island," said Mr. Brofman. "But I wanted to be closer to home and I wanted to support Westchester."
Now the county is helping to support him. He recently signed a long-term lease and moved to a building in White Plains where he pays $16 a square foot. The county gave him sales tax breaks to buy office equipment.
Another representation of the strength of the Westchester economy can be seen at Terra Tile and Marble, the ceramic tile distribution business Manuel Gasch started about 15 years ago in a small showroom in Ossining. 
A native of Spain, he built his business on importing tiles from around the world, primarily from Spain. When he started, high-end decorative tiles accounted for only about 25 percent of his business. Today the high-end tiles account for 75 percent and he has moved well beyond tile into marble and granite, which is fabricated for flooring, counter tops and walls. 
"The high-end tiles, they have been raising our business continually," said Mr. Gasch, whose business has moved to Briarcliff Manor. It is positioned near wealthy suburbs in Westchester and Connecticut where customers are not afraid to spend money. 
"We are in a place where the price doesn't count," said Mr. Gasch, whose business has been growing 15 to 20 percent in each of the past three years. "You have what the client wants and that's it."
Recently, the county agreed to exempt the business from some sales and mortgage taxes to help him build a $1.3 million fabricating plant in Millwood. 
His expansion did not stop there: he recently opened a showroom in Manhattan.
But life, of course, is not universally rosy for businesses in Westchester. Tony Philip's Vision Quest music and sometimes electronics store has been through any number of hard times in Yonkers.
Vision Quest started in 1992 inside a downtown discount store selling a variety of music and electronics, then hit tough times in the mid-90's and downsized to a smaller shop down the street. Within two years it was getting back on their feet and moved across the street to 102 New Main Street, where it stayed for a few years, until the building was condemned. 
Mr. Philip recently opened a 10,000-square-foot business at 24 Main Street in Getty Square, where he receives a variety of tax breaks as part of the downtown revitalization effort. Sales are mediocre at best right now, he said, and the future is challenging as file swapping and bootlegging take a toll on the music and film industry.
But, he said: "I'm trying to focus on the positive. We're still a work in progress." Barbara Whitaker

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Who's Smiling Now?

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
EVERYBODY knows the economy is down, but you can't prove it by Manuel Gasch. His tile and stone business, Terra Tile and Marble, based in Briarcliff Manor, has been growing 15 to 20 percent in each of the last three years, with special strength in high-end imports. Business is so good that he has just opened up a new store, in Manhattan. 
 Times are also good for Pete Khader, owner of the Waterfront Deli in Yonkers. He has just moved his downtown restaurant around the corner from a 166-square-foot space to a spacious new site on Larkin Plaza, across the park from the new library and just down the block from the newly refurbished train station. His business has tripled in six weeks at his new location. 
 Both men have reason for optimism. The economies in Westchester County and other New York City suburbs are stronger than the economy in New York City, which continues to struggle. Housing prices remain strong in Westchester, unemployment in most areas is falling and construction is booming. 
It's a far cry from what followed the recession of the early 1990's, when the Hudson Valley was the last area in the metropolitan region to show improvement.
"When this all started, I remember everyone thought the boom was going to fall and we were faced with a repeat of the early 1990's," said Marc M. Goloven, senior regional economist with J.P. Morgan Chase. "Quite the contrary, that never did occur and you have to ask yourself why that is."
The answer, according to Mr. Goloven and others, lies in efforts to retool Westchester's job base from one reliant on major corporations to one catering more to small and mid-size businesses. Also, the suburbs benefited from some other economic news: low interest rates that bolstered the housing market, for example, and a tendency of jobs to leave New York City after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001. 
One of the clearest measures of success is in jobs. For the most part, Westchester, as well as Rockland and Putnam Counties, has been able to hold the line on job losses during the recent recession. In August, the jobless rate in Westchester was 4 percent compared with 6.2 percent for the state (5.8 percent for the nation) and 8.1 percent for New York City, according to the State Department of Labor. In Putnam County, the unemployment rate was even lower at 3.4 percent and in Rockland County it was 4 percent, the same as in August 2002.
In the 12 months that ended in August, Westchester added 2,100 jobs, a gain of 0.5 percent while Rockland added 1,700, a gain of 1.5 percent, and Putnam added 100 jobs, or 0.4 percent. While that news is good, the area still lags from where it was before the recession of 2001. Westchester added only 300 total jobs for a gain of 0.07 percent in the period between August 2001 and August 2003, when the private sector lost 3,500 jobs, a drop of 1 percent. (The county gained 3,800 government jobs, including 2,500 in local education.) In contrast, however, New York City lost 193,700 jobs during the same period, a drop of 5.2 percent.
"This recession hit New York City particularly hard," said Chris Jones, vice president for research at the Regional Plan Association, a private nonprofit research and planning organization. "The decline on Wall Street was the biggest factor of this recession and although that's an industry important to the entire region, it clearly hits New York hardest."
In addition, the city's economy was obviously harder hit by the 9/11 attack. The buildings collapsed, and suddenly the jobs that were there were gone. Businesses small and large that depended on those jobs, from restaurants to copy shops to retail stores, struggled. High technology continued its swoon. The financial industry, which had started its slide, began to send even more jobs outside the city as part of businesses' planning for another similar disaster. Some of those jobs landed in Westchester and other counties in the Hudson Valley, with Morgan Stanley moving some operations to Harrison and New York Life doing the same in Mount Pleasant.
Still, the picture in Westchester isn't entirely rosy.
"In general things are hopeful, but there are still lots of challenges out there," said Thomas J. Morley, regional director of the Westchester Small Business Development Center. "Basically, the rich are richer but the poor are poorer, and I think that is particularly noticeable in Westchester."
While some homeowners in the county have been able to enjoy increases of more than 10 percent a year in property prices, those without such assets have continued to struggle. With an office based in Yonkers, Mr. Morley contrasts development around the waterfront with some neighborhoods in other parts of the city that have no grocery store, leaving residents to rely on more expensive bodegas. The number of Westchester families living in poverty rose 41 percent from 1989 to 1999, to 15,173 or 6.4 percent of all families, according to the Census Bureau. Westchester's Department of Social Services listed 690 homeless families and 410 homeless individuals in January 2002.
IN addition, while there is job growth in some sectors, those looking for work say the kind of jobs available has changed.
Harold J. Plaut, 32, an information technology specialist whohas been out of work since July, said the jobs that are available are paying tens of thousands of dollars less than what they did just a year or two ago.
"I remember the days of $80 to $100 an hour," he said, sitting at a state job center in Yonkers. "Today it's $30 to $50 an hour."
Joseph Conigliaro, 41, also in information technology and unemployed since December, chimed in. "I've seen as low as $12," he said. "I'd rather go work in Kmart."
Although he made it clear that Kmart was not a serious option, his comment hit one of the most common complaints about the retooling of the economy in Westchester: many of the new jobs are in retail sales paying only about $8 an hour.
The information industry, which lost 300 jobs between August 2002 and August 2003, continued to struggle. Other problem areas, according to state labor statistics, are manufacturing, with a loss of 1,400 jobs in that same period, and finance, losing 600 jobs.
In contrast, 600 jobs were added in construction, 600 in retail and 300 in leisure and hospitality. Another 2,600 jobs were added in the category that includes services like nail and beauty salons, appliance and automotive repair and laundry services.
Another issue confronting Westchester is that nearly 37 percent of the work force commutes outside the county to jobs in New York, primarily Manhattan, making the area vulnerable to continuing economic problems there, said Frank M. Surdey, regional administrator for the State Labor Department in the Hudson Valley.
Still, the economy in the Hudson Valley has been able to rebound more quickly than it did after the recession of the early 1990's.
"The recession of the early 90's was almost like the perfect storm for the region and the Hudson Valley in particular," said Mr. Jones.
Wall Street fell, military spending cutbacks hit some parts of the region, and major corporate restructuring played a big role in weakening Westchester's economy.
As jobs at the likes of I.B.M., Kraft Foods and AT&T disappeared, the unemployment rate went up and the office vacancy rate soared, in some areas to more than 30 percent. To make matters worse, the real estate market went dormant until it began to rebound in the mid-1990's, with housing sales peaking in 1998 and 1999.
But other parts of the economy were not as fortunate. Office vacancy rates and unemployment remained a problem.
"Westchester's reputation was absolutely terrible," said Salvatore J. Carrera, looking back to 1998 when he became director of economic development for the county. "There was a stigma. There was office vacancy, high unemployment and no deal making."
These days the picture is changing, with White Plains at the forefront.
Cranes hover over downtown where just weeks ago Fortunoff opened an $85 million, 180,000-square-foot retail complex that includes a Cheesecake Factory and a soon-to-open Morton's steakhouse and Whole Foods market. Nearby at the old Macy's site, the City Center is being constructed at a cost of $350 million with a just-opened Target discount department store and a 15-screen movie theater, Circuit City, Legal Sea Foods, Applebee's and Barnes & Noble not far behind.
The center is also supposed to have 600 units of residential housing, just part of the 1,800 residential units, most of them apartments, under construction downtown today.
"Ten years ago it was a rough scene," said Paul Wood, a spokesman for the city who heads economic development in White Plains. "Basically downtown was dominated by vacant stores."
Easing zoning restrictions and streamlining the building process were two factors the city credits with stimulating growth, a formula county officials are also using along with incentives like sales tax breaks to attract businesses.
A consultant was hired to evaluate the county's strengths and weaknesses. A full-time employee was brought in to deal with real estate and economic development issues.
"We found in everything we do the real key to economic development is growing your own companies," said Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano. "It's a fallacy to believe that attracting large companies from the outside is the key."
At the heart of that philosophy is jobs, he said: "If everybody's working, I've got less crime. I've got less everything to deal with. Jobs are the key to the economy and the social fabric."
Sean MacDonald, regional economist for the State Department of Labor's Hudson Valley region, said that in contrast with the economy during the recession 10 years ago, the economy of the Hudson Valley had become much more diversified. There has been expansion in distribution, warehousing, financial businesses, small banks and mortgage companies, as well as biotech jobs and health care.
For example, New York Presbyterian Hospital is planning a biotechnical research and development project in White Plains, which is expected to create 900 jobs. Morgan Stanley is relocating part of its Manhattan operation to the county, bringing with it 2,500 jobs. New York Life is bringing part of its operation to Mount Pleasant, with 1,000 employees. 
The county has also had success recently retaining midsize companies like Fuji and Heineken, both of which were shopping around for new locales before expanding their operations.
While White Plains has garnered attention for its business development and residential growth, other cities have also been experiencing redevelopment, including Port Chester and Yonkers along their waterfronts.
"I think in this region we've been seeing some pretty good numbers over the past year, and the losses in manufacturing have at least stabilized," Ms. MacDonald said.
At the same time, the real estate market has remained strong through much of the recession. The median price of houses in Westchester has continued to climb, hitting $570,000 in the second quarter of 2003, a jump of 9.6 percent or $50,000 over the second quarter of 2002. Meanwhile, the median family income in the county has reached about $60,000.
"If I was only looking at the home prices I would think this would be the best of boom times," said Mr. Goloven of J.P. Morgan Chase.
Greg Rand, a managing partner with Prudential Rand Realty in White Plains, said one of the biggest differences between the recession of the early 90's and the most recent one was that real estate helped bolster the economy this time. People turned away from Wall Street and toward real estate for their investments.
In addition, he said, the economy remained fine for many Westchester households. There weren't huge layoffs.
"The first thing we saw was just an incredible wave of demand of people that wanted to upgrade," he said. "They bought bigger houses."
Housing sales in Westchester have remained strong throughout the recession. The housing market in Putnam County, north of Westchester and with long commuting to the city, heated up, another indicator of growing demand and strong prices. The trend has continued, although it has cooled somewhat in recent months.
"We did 4,000 real estate transactions last year," Mr. Rand said. "The ones who were buying were climbing all over each other to get their bids accepted." The scene was even more frantic a few years ago, he said.
The housing market has had a strong ripple effect. Low interest rates and a flight from the stock market have brought a wave of refinancings, allowing homeowners to trade up or work on their homes, providing business for contractors, financial institutions, and businesses like home furnishings.
"I think much of what is happening is real-estate driven," Mr. Jones said. "As housing prices go up it stimulates a lot of industries." 
Real estate agents say they are also seeing a trend toward seeking investment properties. John E. Durante is among them. He started buying condominiums in White Plains in late 2001, first renting them as he waited for them to appreciate. He has now started selling them at a price about $60,000 over what he paid. Last year he bought several storefronts and apartments a few blocks from the train station in Mamaroneck followed by a 14,000-square-foot building in New Rochelle.
He hopes to close on an eight-family apartment building in Yonkers next week. "I think Westchester has everything to offer," he said, noting the easy commuting into New York City. 
Several residential developments around White Plains, once planned as apartments, are now going to be as condominiums, which economists cite as another indication of an improving economy.
While it remains to be seen if those ventures will be successful, economists say that Westchester's success could bring some problems. "Westchester's challenges, as I see them, are what I call the challenges of prosperity," Mr. Goloven said.
If the labor market continues to tighten, where will workers come from? What about housing for people of modest incomes? What can be done about traffic congestion that is worsening around major thoroughfares?
"Those are the types of impediment that could eventually stifle economic growth," Mr. Goloven said.
On the ground, the economic strength Mr. Goloven sees looks good for Philip Leggio, just a few blocks away from Mr. Khader's new deli in Yonkers. 
In a ragged area, where efforts at revitalization are starting to grow stronger, Mr. Leggio has opened a high-end white-tablecloth restaurant called Zuppa. After 26 years in the restaurant supply business, Mr. Leggio is banking on economic strength in Yonkers for his new venture, and on success in drawing a fine-dining clientele to an urban-pioneer area -- in other words, on factors that he knows are beyond his control. Yet he remains optimistic.
"I'm taking a gamble," he said. "But the harder you work the luckier you get."

HEADLINE: Corruption and Despair Choke Zimbabwe 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe 

 BODY:
The Herald, the relentlessly sunny pro-government newspaper in Zimbabwe's threadbare capital, insists on its front page that life here is on the mend. But the classifieds suggest otherwise. 
 An enterprising merchant named Zariro advertises 260-pound concrete slabs for mourners to cover and protect the fresh graves of departed loved ones. 
 "These days when you bury your dead, you have to spend the night there," Preston, a 27-year-old who supports his family through black-market currency trading, explained on a recent day. "If you don't look after the grave, the next morning you'll come back and find the body lying on the ground, and the coffin gone." 
Many here might call that a good analogy for Zimbabwe itself.
This nation was once one of Africa's most prosperous states. But it is prostrate today, its vital signs flickering, asphyxiated by ever-tighter governmental curbs on the economy and basic freedoms. Driven by desperation, greed or simply a sense that the end is nearing, its rulers and citizens are methodically stripping the country of its assets.
Zimbabwe has been officially off limits to foreign journalists since February, when President Robert G. Mugabe's government pushed a law through Parliament effectively banning outside reporters as tools of European and American critics. But a low-profile tour of the country for 11 days this month found no shortage of domestic critics, both black and white, and an outright glut of human misery. 
Desperate citizens here have become dark-of-night scavengers of coffins, copper electrical cable and even aluminum street signs, now in such shortage that finding an address is a trial.
Zimbabwe's nights are dark indeed: here in Harare, downtown street lights are turned off for lack of foreign currency to pay South African and Zambian power suppliers. 
If the nights are black, the days often exude an eerie surface calm. In Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city, the handful of Western-style supermarkets remain bustling and half full of goods, though prices rise so fast that any three bottles of ketchup are likely to bear three different price stickers. Inns reflexively hand out candles and matches to visitors to address power failures. 
But much of the calm is government-enforced, courtesy of a domestic intelligence organization and a rural youth militia, the Green Bombers, widely feared for its brutality.
Although it went widely unreported, hundreds of factory workers in Bulawayo and Harare clashed violently with the police recently after trying to protest the cruelest of ironies: Zimbabwe's soaring inflation has pushed them into the 45 percent tax bracket once reserved solely for the rich. 
A better measure of life is the fenced-off compound of the British and South African High Commissions in Harare's suburbs, where crowds of Zimbabweans camp out nightly, hoping to be first in line when visa offices open the next morning. 
At 7 a.m., a half-block-square area outside the South African commission is jammed with hundreds of applicants. The crush is so great that South Africa now requires Zimbabweans to post a bond of about 160 American dollars for a mere two-week visa, a sizable sum intended to guarantee their return. 
"I haven't had a job in two years -- nobody here has a job," a 27-year-old man, a onetime roofer who identified himself only as Moses, said as he waited to pick up his visa recently. "I'm going to Pretoria to try to find something." 
He is one of the lucky ones. In a ramshackle open-air market south of Victoria Falls, hard against two camps of hundreds of shacks of scavenged planks and cardboard, Sibangisiwe Masuku, 19, buys corn kernels at the equivalent of $1.44 in American currency for 2.2 pounds, grinds them into flour and sells them for $2.24. On a good day, she makes well under a dollar in profit. 
Her parents are dead -- of what, she would not say. She moved in with a sister, who died of tuberculosis last month. Now she stays with a second sister, living on corn porridge and tea.
The ravages of hyperinflation, 455 percent a year and rising fast, are evident everywhere. It now costs 234,000 Zimbabwean dollars to spay a dog. Chicken feed is anything but: $91,500 for a 110-pound bag, more than twice the price a week earlier.
A gallon of gas costs $11,000, but is only available on the black market. In Victoria Falls, for example, most people go to nearby Botswana to fill up their tanks.
Trying to cope with an inflation-induced currency shortage, the government is churning out new $500 bills. Because the paper and ink are imported, each bill now costs more than $1,000 to print. 
(Not that $500 is a princely sum: today, it is worth about 8 American cents. Five years ago, the same bill was worth more than 9 American dollars. The average per-person income is probably about 90 cents a day, down one-third in five years.) 
"This country is truly in a crisis," said Collen Gwiyo, the 38-year-old first secretary general of the Zimbabwe Coalition of Trade Unions, a locus of opposition to Mr. Mugabe's government. "It's a political crisis, leading to an economic crisis, feeding a humanitarian disaster." 
The nature of this journalist's visit made it impossible to speak to representatives of the government, but in the past Mr. Mugabe has blamed white colonial powers, particularly the United States and Britain, for his country's problems. These countries, he says, are trying to punish Zimbabwe for its policies. 
Since 1998, when Mr. Mugabe began seizing white-owned farms, capping prices and fixing exchange rates in a populist scheme to revive his fading popularity, Zimbabwe's economy has been slowly choking. In the last year, foreign investment has vanished, and only 1 in 10 workers now holds a steady job. Agriculture, the economic mainstay, is in precipitous decline.
In a nation that exported beef and wheat only three years ago, four million people -- one in three -- now subsist on foreign food donations. Four in 10 children are stunted or wasting away from malnutrition, according to the United Nations.
Hunger, however, is not just an abstract statistic: in the Matabeleland South Province, near Botswana, the United Nations reports, the regional hospital in the town of Shangani closed in mid-September because it lacked even corn porridge to feed patients.
Members of the country's elite, critics here and elsewhere say, are scooping up the country's real wealth. They have taken control of Zimbabwe's best farmland and game parks, played the currency market with government money and channeled billions of Zimbabwean dollars in government spending through companies they or their relatives own. 
Mr. Mugabe has criticized those diversions of land and money, but there is little evidence that either has been returned. To the contrary, many here say, the scramble to get a scrap of Zimbabwe's remaining riches seems to have accelerated.
The government floated a bond issue last year, ostensibly to finance resettlement on the seized farms. Of the 7.2 billion Zimbabwean dollars raised, $4 billion went to a company owned by the nephew of the Parliament speaker, Emmerson Mnangagwa, who many say is the anointed successor should Mr. Mugabe, 79, retire or die.
Mr. Mugabe is putting the finishing touches on his own 130,000-square-foot, 25-bedroom retreat north of the capital, a $9 million palace with a Chinese tiled roof and ceilings adorned by the work of Arab craftsmen. 
A few miles farther north, at a 15,000-acre farm once nicknamed Little England, government forces evicted 1,000 settlers in September to clear the way for occupation by Mr. Mugabe's relatives and a handful of other families. 
Transparency International, the anticorruption watchdog, pegged Zimbabwe this month at No. 106 -- among the worst -- in a ranking of corruption in 133 countries. Zimbabwe was No. 71 just one year ago.
Zimbabwe's troubles began when Mr. Mugabe's government, facing rising discontent among supporters of the guerrilla movement that carried him to power in 1980, began allowing the so-called war veterans to occupy white-owned commercial farmland. 
Since then, in a period of five years, the government has confiscated 25,000 square miles of farmland, all in the name of compensating black Zimbabweans for a century of oppression under British rule.
Officials once claimed that they had resettled 300,000 families on the farms; a new government report, still unreleased, reduces that figure to 127,000. 
Mr. Mugabe and his supporters say Zimbabwe suffers largely because white leaders in Europe and the United States, angry over the land seizures, are plotting its failure. 
Both America and the European Union have cut off economic aid, blacklisted top officials and frozen some foreign bank accounts in disapproval of Zimbabwe's economic and human rights conduct. The Harare government also has blamed a yearlong drought for this year's disastrous harvests. 
The drought has hurt. But many outsiders and Zimbabweans alike blame the government for the country's woes.
The seizure of commercial farms, it turns out, kicked away the legs of the economy. With property rights no longer assured, foreign money fled.
With no foreign money, Zimbabweans could no longer buy imports. Without imports -- fertilizers, spare parts, gasoline -- large-scale agriculture has collapsed, and with it most of the industry that supported farmers.
At the same time, the ousting of all but about 600 of the nation's 4,500 white farmers also uprooted nearly 300,000 black workers on those farms, almost all of whom are now jobless. 
"They came to us and said, 'You have 10 minutes to leave this farm' -- 10 minutes -- that's it," said Edson, a 29-year-old foreman on what was once the Shrewsbury farm 40 miles south of Harare. Fearing reprisals, he spoke on the condition that his last name not be used. "We lost all our money, all our property -- everything." Since then, he said, the 600-acre tract has lain fallow. 
That is a recurring theme in conversations with local Zimbabweans of all races and economic levels. They say many of those who have taken over farmland were never farmers, but in fact were local backers of Mr. Mugabe's party who elected to reap quick profits by selling off seized assets instead of plowing and sowing crops. 
Others simply lacked the ability to run a farm -- or, because the government has yet to give them legal title to the land, had no collateral for the loans needed to buy seed and tend crops. 
The choicest farms were awarded to senior government officials and party leaders. "Of the people who got good, arable farmland, 99.2 percent are cabinet ministers, wives, political cronies, relatives, girlfriends," Barnabas Thlondlan, the associate editor of the recently banned Daily News on Sunday, said in an interview. "We call them cellphone farmers -- all they do is call every once in a while and ask, 'How's everything on the farm?' " 
Bad would be the only answer. Corn production has fallen by nearly half from its peak. Harvests of wheat, a profitable commercial crop, are down by 90 percent.
A white commercial farmer from Bulawayo who, with three other farmers, lost 50,000 acres of land to Zimbabwe political kingpins, said of those enriching themselves: "They're making their own bed to sleep in. But I tell you what: they're going to starve there."

HEADLINE: Daily Choice Turned Deadly: Children Left on Their Own 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Last Sunday, as her night shift neared, Kim Brathwaite faced a hard choice. Her baby sitter had not shown up, and to miss work might end her new position as assistant manager at a McDonald's in downtown Brooklyn.
 So she left her two children, 9 and 1, alone, trying to stay in touch by phone. 
 It turned out to be a disastrous decision. Someone, it seems, deliberately set fire to her apartment. Her children died. And within hours, Ms. Brathwaite was under arrest, charged with recklessly endangering her children. 
The investigation is continuing, and an arrest in the arson may soon overshadow the criminal charges against Ms. Brathwaite, who is not a suspect in the fire, investigators say. But she is now facing up to 16 years in prison for a decision that, surveys and interviews with experts suggest, cuts uncomfortably close to some choices made every day by American families.
Nationwide, parents themselves report leaving more than 3 million children under 13 -- some as young as 5 -- to care for themselves for at least a few hours a week on a regular basis, according to a recent study by Child Trends, a nonprofit research organization in Washington, D.C., that analyzed census information and other data.
And so the Brooklyn case highlights a much broader debate, one with few fixed legal guideposts. For state statutes typically set no age under 18 when a child is legally considered old enough to stay home alone. Thus parents are left with many case-by-case judgments, and prosecutors with vast discretion when something goes wrong.
The cases that surface are almost always the notorious failures, like the story of the 9- and 4-year-old cousins in Little Ferry, N.J., who went joy-riding in a leased S.U.V. or the former welfare mother in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, who was afraid to lose her night job processing checks at a bank, and instead lost her unsupervised toddler in a fall from a ninth-floor balcony.
But how those cases are treated, and whether they result in prosecutions, can vary widely. Several years ago, after two grand juries in Santa Fe, N.M., refused to indict parents when they had left young children at risk -- one child was left freezing in a car while her father drank in a local bar -- the local district attorney altered his policy for arresting and prosecuting parents in such cases.
"The grand jury is reflective of a community standard," the district attorney, Henry Valdez, said after his second failed prosecution.
A professor of family law at New York University, Martin Guggenheim, said that the ambiguity in criminal laws on the "home alone" question made wide discrepancies in the handling of cases inevitable.
"It puts all parents at peril in making parental choices, without warning them that certain choices are forbidden," he said.
Brooklyn prosecutors argue that no matter what, Ms. Brathwaite should not have left her children, 9-year-old Justina Mason and 1-year-old Justin Brathwaite, alone in a basement apartment in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, especially children as vulnerable as hers.
Both had sickle cell anemia, a blood disorder that often requires hospital care. And though prosecutors concede that Justina and her mother were talking by phone as late as 10 p.m., when the baby sitter had still not arrived, such conversations fall far short of the adult supervision needed in an emergency.
"She knew they were at risk," said Ama Dwimoh, the chief of the Crimes Against Children Bureau in the Brooklyn district attorney's office. "I'm not trying to do a rush to judgment, but this is why you can't leave kids home alone -- because it can result in death.
But others, from Ms. Brathwaite's lawyer to researchers of family life, say her case needs to be seen in a broader social context.
She was, they note, a single mother -- by some accounts quite devoted -- living a life of complicated choices. 
Recently promoted to assistant manager at the McDonald's, Ms. Brathwaite was required to work a rotating mix of morning, midday and nighttime shifts that made reliable child care nearly impossible to keep on her modest wages. Nor could she leave early, since she was responsible for securing the day's receipts. When desperate calls to the missing sitter and a neighbor went unanswered, her lawyer said, she was afraid of losing the job that supported her children.
"She is guilty of nothing more than being a single mom working a 12-hour shift," said her lawyer, Douglas Rankin.
Richard Wexler, the director of the National Coalition for Child Protection Reform who has compiled research on children left at home, said many parents take similar risks, often because better options are not available. "Although news stories repeatedly say there is 'no firm rule' concerning when a child can be left alone, actually there is one," Mr. Wexler said. "It's the rule of fate. If something goes wrong, then you are a bad parent and you will be charged. If nothing goes wrong, you won't."
Ms. Dwimoh, of the Brooklyn prosecutor's office, was not swayed. "Just because everybody does it doesn't make it right," she said. And a spokesman for the district attorney's office, Jerry Schmetterer, argued that tragic results cannot be disregarded.
"The case will be presented to a grand jury and the people of Brooklyn will speak," he said. "But our position is we had to charge -- two babies are dead."
Of course, the decision by parents whether to leave children alone usually depends on many factors besides age, such as the capabilities of the children, the ability to pay for care, cultural traditions and the perceived safety of the neighborhood.
Linda Gordon, a history professor at New York University who has written extensively on America's shifting definition of child neglect since the 19th century, said that in an immigrant nation with wide economic inequalities, beliefs and customs differ.
"This may have been an extremely competent 9-year-old," Professor Gordon said, referring to the older child in the Brooklyn case. "There are all kinds of societies where 9-year-olds take care of children. And what would have happened if the mother had been there? It's not so obvious that it would have been different."
The Child Trends researchers found that higher-income children between 6 and 9 were actually more likely than poor children to be left unsupervised for several hours, even after controlling for the fact that the better-off parents were more likely to have jobs. 
The authors of the report, "Left Unsupervised: A Look at the Most Vulnerable Children," warned that leaving children under 13 routinely on their own may put them at risk for injuries and developmental problems. But they also hedged, writing: "Self care is not always harmful. Children typically become more independent as they mature, gradually spending more and more time alone and taking increasing amounts of responsibility."
When unsupervised children become notorious, the legal system may feel extra pressure to hold parents accountable, even when the case did not end in tragedy.
In the case of the child joy riders in the S.U.V. in New Jersey, an elderly pedestrian who was knocked over suffered no lasting injuries.
Lawyers for the mothers of the two cousins said they were hard-working single moms in their 30's who were juggling responsible jobs, one at a bank during the day, the other in a hospital at night. By their account, the lack of supervision was just the result of a misunderstanding with a 22-year-old niece who was also in the patchwork child care mix.
But six weeks later, the children are still in New Jersey foster care while the State Division of Youth and Family Services investigates. And criminal charges of endangering their children are pending against the two mothers, said Dolores Aretsky, the lawyer for one, last week.
In the Ohio case of the toddler falling to his death, the 23-year-old mother, Tanisha Gill, was charged with involuntary manslaughter for choosing to leave for her job when her baby sitter did not show up. She had said the child's father promised to be right over, to watch the sleeping boys, Charles, 2, who died, and his 4-year-old brother. The father denied it.
In the end, a judge placed her on probation for three years after she pleaded guilty to reckless homicide.
Yet in other strikingly similar cases, parents were not prosecuted.
In one of the cases in Santa Fe that were rejected by grand juries, an illegal immigrant, the mother of seven, had gone to work at McDonald's, leaving a 6-year-old daughter in charge of siblings aged 3 and 1. The frightened girl had called 911. But supporters -- including the sheriff who bailed the mother out of jail -- saw her as a desperate single mother fearful of deportation who was doing the best she could in poverty.
A district attorney in Greeley, Colo. declined to prosecute Jennifer Farrell, a more affluent mother who left her six children home alone for 17 days while she vacationed in Italy. He found no evidence that the children - aged 6, 8, 10, 11, 12 and 14 - were harmed or faced imminent danger when the single mother left them with a stocked kitchen, a debit card for buying more food, and a list of friends and relatives to call if they needed help, The Denver Post reported.
Annette Lareau, a Temple University sociologist who has studied the child-rearing practices of poor, middle-class and affluent parents, said of the Brooklyn case, "You could say this family had very bad luck."
Professor Lareau said that among the well-off families she followed for her new book, "Unequal Childhoods: Class, Race and Family Life (University of California Press, 2003), were a pair on an out-of-town trip to a soccer championship who left two 10-year-olds, two 8-year-olds and a 5-year-old alone in a hotel room while the two sets of parents went out to dinner a mile away.
"They left the kids with cell phones, pizzas and videos saying to each other, 'They'll turn us in,' " she recalled. The children did not turn them in, however, and no fire broke out.

HEADLINE: City Pension Fund Is Venturing Into Real Estate 

BYLINE:  ByJOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
The largest pension fund for New York City employees has decided to invest in commercial real estate for the first time, committing up to $100 million to it. 
 Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., the investment adviser to the fund, the New York City Employees Retirement System, said on Friday that its action was a "prudent investment" for its members "and one that supports the growth and redevelopment of our city's economy." 
 The stock market's fall over the last three years has combined with mandated pension benefit increases to reduce the system's assets to $31.2 billion from $44.4 billion in 2000. The assets of all city pension funds have fallen to $74 billion from $105 billion in that period, said a spokesman for Mr. Thompson, Scott Taffet. 
The Employees Retirement System provides pensions to 130,000 retirees, while 200,000 current employees contribute to it. Its $31.2 billion in assets is largely invested in stocks and bonds, though it has also invested in residential real estate, Mr. Taffet said. He cited a project involving the rehabilitation of four apartment buildings in Harlem.
The system covers city employees except police officers, firefighters, teachers and other school employees, with each group having its own fund. The other funds are not part of the commercial real estate investment program, Mr. Taffet said. 
The pension money earmarked for the program will be used in ventures to "develop, redevelop and acquire premium commercial property throughout the five boroughs," Mr. Thompson said. During the next three to five years, the money will be turned over to a realty investment group, Tishman Speyer/Travelers NYC Real Estate Venture V, L.P., and the group will invest it for the pension fund. No projects have been designated yet, Mr. Taffet said.
Though the other pension funds are not participating in the commercial realty program, all but one, the fund for nonteacher school system employees, have also decided to diversify their assets more, Mr. Thompson said.

HEADLINE: J.F.K. Project Would Reopen Famed Terminal 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
JetBlue Airways and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have agreed on a plan for the airline to build a modern 26-gate terminal adjacent to Terminal 5 at Kennedy International Airport, the historic Trans World Airlines Flight Center designed by Eero Saarinen, officials said yesterday.
 After intense discussions in recent weeks, JetBlue and the Port Authority, which operates the airport, reached a consensus and submitted their final comments to the Federal Aviation Administration last week. The agency has final approval on airport projects and is expected to make a decision within a month. 
 Richard J. Smyth, vice president of redevelopment at JetBlue, said all parties "feel pretty good" that the plans will be approved.
"We finally arrived at a consensus and made a formal recommendation to the F.A.A. with an approach that seems to be the best plan for everyone," he said.
If approved, the $600 million project would be a bold, ambitious move during a dismal economic time in the airline industry and would help JetBlue, the largest domestic carrier at Kennedy, greatly expand its operations there.
The deal would also revive Terminal 5, famed for its distinctive modern style but closed since October 2001 when Trans World Airlines ceased operations.
"With the building empty, it continues to deteriorate," Mr. Smyth said. "This plan saves a historic building and allows the appropriate upgrade for a modern airline, so we can grow at J.F.K."
The 41-year-old terminal is a city landmark. But after it closed, several New York preservation groups feared that it might be declared obsolete by airport officials and demolished. They began fighting for a development project that would include it as a functioning terminal, rather than a museum piece.
Frank E. Sanchis III, executive director of the Municipal Art Society, which was involved in the discussions, called the final recommendations a "happy solution."
"The plan provides a functional use for one of the most wonderful buildings ever designed to board an airplane from," he said.
Alan Hicks, a Port Authority spokesman, said the agency was working with all parties, including JetBlue and the Municipal Art Society, to make sure that Terminal 5 remained in use. "It is a magnificent work of art, and we are very proud of it," he said.
Mr. Smyth said the existing terminal would serve as an alternative entrance to the proposed terminal behind it and would have automated JetBlue ticket kiosks. The Port Authority would control the older terminal, he said, and evaluate proposals for uses, which could include a conference center, restaurants, shops and offices.
The new terminal would be connected to the existing one by its two well-known tubular passenger walkways, which were used in the 2002 film "Catch Me if You Can" as the setting of a climactic encounter between Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hanks.
Under the current recommendations, at least one original walkway would be preserved, with the other possibly modified or rebuilt to contain a moving walkway.
JetBlue operates 80 flights per day out of Terminal 6, but wants to triple that number by 2010, which the proposed 26-gate terminal would allow the airline to do, Mr. Smyth said. JetBlue hopes to finish it by mid-2007, and to pay for much of the cost through the sale of bonds, Mr. Smyth said.

HEADLINE: A British Import at the Shubert 

BYLINE:  By DAVID COTE

 BODY:
FOR its nearly 90-year history, the Shubert theater of New Haven has been reinventing itself.
 In 1914, when it opened, it was described by the local press as the jewel in the Shubert brothers' crown. In the 1940's and 1950's, it became famous as the out-of-town tryout theater for many hit Broadway plays and musicals, among them "A Streetcar Named Desire," and many Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein II productions, including "Oklahoma!" in 1943 and "The Sound of Music" in 1959. 
 In the 1960's and 1970's, the Shubert's fortunes went the way of the troubled economy, and in 1976, the theater was shuttered and threatened with demolition. 
But it survived, through the persistence and passion of city officials and citizens, and was reopened in 1983 as the Shubert Performing Arts Center, a nonprofit arts, education and community institution. Its decor was restored to the original design, understated alabaster walls with muted gold highlights. In 1997, further renovations upgraded the sound and lighting systems and made the space wheelchair-accessible.
Today, the programming is a multicultural, family-friendly mix of dance performances, pop concerts, and theatrical presentations and productions by local groups as well as touring Broadway productions.
Now the Shubert's management hopes another chapter may be opening as the theater welcomes the American premiere of "As You Like It," directed by the eminent Briton, Sir Peter Hall. The production, which has toured England, has a 11-day engagement at the Shubert beginning on Thursday, the first stop on a tour of the United States. It is the first major production from Europe to play at the Shubert since its 1983 reincarnation. So far at least, it has no other dates booked in the metropolitan area.
Bill Conner, the Shubert's president and chief executive officer, whose company took over the theater's management two years ago, would like it if New Yorkers trekked to New Haven to see the play. He also mentioned plans, but no specific details, for the Shubert to broaden its repertory by bringing in more shows from overseas.
"We're looking for shows next season that could come over from Europe," Mr. Conner said. "Ideally, we'd have an 'As You Like It' in our season every year." 
Sir Peter's shows have played the Shubert before; he worked at the theater in 1957, when he directed Morton Wishengrad's "The Rope Dancers" there before its Broadway run, in a production that starred Art Carney. 
"Back then, of course, you didn't need to be a huge hit to be successful on Broadway," Sir Peter said, in a telephone interview from London. "You could have a medium hit." 
At 73, Sir Peter is celebrating 50 years as a director this year. His illustrious career includes the leadership of England's Royal Shakespeare Company in the 1960's, and National Theater in the 1970's.
He has directed plays and operas in most major American cities. In 2000, he directed the world premiere of the epic "Tantalus" at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts.
But although he has directed most of Shakespeare's plays, he never tackled "As You Like It." He explained that the reason was that he could not find an actress who could compete with Vanessa Redgrave's 1961 rendition of the heroine, Rosalind, a character who combines the verbal dexterity of Hamlet with the sexiness of Juliet. 
Forthis show, he found his Rosalind, close to home, in his daughter, Rebecca, 21, who earned strong reviews for her work in a London production of George Bernard Shaw's "Mrs. Warren's Profession." 
Sir Peter says his modern-dress approach to the play emphasizes the melancholy in the romantic comedy. When the production opened in August in Bath, The Guardian's Michael Billington hailed Ms. Hall's Rosalind as "groundbreaking." The London Times called the production "moving, funny, sexy and lyrical."
Meanwhile, the Shubert's days as a tryout house are not entirely over. In recent years, the composer Frank Wildhorn tested out "Jekyll & Hyde" and "The Civil War" there, and next March the Shubert will present a pre-Broadway run of a musical version of "Little Women," directed by Susan Stroman. 
Dani Davis, one of the producers of "Little Women," acknowledged that trying out a show so close to New York is risky.
"The pressure will be on," she said.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 2, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 19 about a production of "As You Like It" at New Haven's Shubert Theater misidentified the director of a musical version of "Little Women," which will have a pre-Broadway run there. She is Susan Schulman. (Susan Stroman is the director of "The Producers" on Broadway, among other works.)
