HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN; 
New Lures on Caribbean Shores

BYLINE:  By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS; FRANCES FRANK MARCUS writes frequently about travel.

 BODY:
EARLY on a September morning in Old San Juan, guests on a breeze-swept terrace at the elegant Hotel El Convento sipped coffee and ate freshly sliced mangoes, papayas and pineapple. A reception desk clerk stayed busy answering the phone, a honeymoon couple checked out and, behind a terrace door, guests admired the cozy library. September is the depths of the doldrums in the Caribbean, but on that day, El Convento was bustling, thanks in part to bargain room rates.
 Caribbean travel is showing signs of resurgence, though not on every island, with help from the bargain prices many tourists have enjoyed in the past couple of years, as hotels responded to post-Sept. 11 fears of flying, continuing economic worries in the United States, and war. 
Last winter was promising, said Alec Sanguinetti, director general and chief executive of the Caribbean Hotel Association, with increases in air arrivals over the previous year. When the Iraq war started, he said, "There was not a rash of cancellations, but advance bookings just fell off the radar completely." 
 Bookings this summer rose in response to off-season bargains -- like El Convento's $125-a-day rate in September for rooms that go for $345 in winter -- but the lower prices cut profits. "It's a tough market out there," said Mr. Sanguinetti. "Everyone is still watching the economy. It's the No. 1 problem right now."
 But for people craving a Caribbean getaway, there are new and newly redone rooms in hotels, inns, cottages and villas in many price ranges. Add to that a flurry of new amenities: increased air service; spas; lures for honeymooners, couples and families; activities; and luxury touches. 
 Puerto Rico, which has the region's busiest airport, actually saw a rise in its hotel occupancy of 3.7 percentage points over the previous year, to 78.2 percent. This season the island is welcoming its first all-inclusive hotel, the 490-room Paradisus Puerto Rico, part of a large Spanish hotel chain, scheduled to open Dec. 15. Puerto Rico's satellite island, Vieques, recently gained its first large luxury hotel, the 156-room Wyndham Martineau Bay Resort -- and lost a major sore point, maneuvers by the United States Navy. But a 506-unit hotel, Hyatt Regency Cerromar Beach, sister to the more upscale Hyatt Dorado Beach, closed July 15. (The popular river pool, children's club and other attractions are still open along with the Hyatt Hacienda del Mar, a time-share property on the Cerromar's grounds.) A corporate announcement gave as reasons "the general business climate and the proliferation of newer and more modern competitors."
 In a new marketing plan, Puerto Rico is urging visitors to venture out from the island's North Coast and historic Old San Juan, bustling with stylish restaurants, shoppers and strollers, to the less-traveled western side, where surfers have ridden winter's waves for decades. The coast is now called the Porta del Sol for its spectacular sunsets.
 There are many lures in this part of Puerto Rico, diving, hiking and bird watching among them. At certain periods during the winter in Rincon, a west coast surfing town, people gather by the hundreds to watch whales swimming close to shore in the Mona Passage, between Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. February is high season for whale-watching. The main vantage point is the Rincon Lighthouse Park. 
 Built on a secluded beach in Rincon, the elegant boutique hotel Horned Dorset Primavera recently grew to 53 units with the addition of 22 spacious villa suites with private plunge pools; the new suites start at $890 a night, rooms at $600, including breakfast and dinner but not the service charge on meals and the 9 percent government tax. The new Blue Room restaurant decorated with Italian tiles is an alternative to the imposing formal dining room. It is open for breakfast now and, starting Nov. 15, will also serve bistro fare for lunch and dinner. The new 70-foot lap pool overlooks the sea.
 "We've found all these rooms rent first," said Wilhelm Sack, general manager and co-owner, on a tour of the new suites. 
 A new 112-room hotel, Rincon of the Seas Grand Caribbean, opened this year and unlike the Horned Dorset welcomes children under 12. Decorated with blue and green print fabrics, guest rooms have off-white tile floors and balconies. Winter rates start at $225. Among the island's more affordable hotels, the charming beachfront Casa Islena has nine rooms brightened with Mexican furniture and winter rates starting at $115. 
 In other parts of the Caribbean, visitor numbers increased early this year in the Turks and Caicos, Antigua, the Bahamas, Barbados, Bonaire, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Dominica, Jamaica, Saba, St. Lucia and St. Maarten. Visitors to Aruba surged by 15 percent in August over August of last year because hotels there offered some attractive package deals.
 In the U.S. Virgin Islands visitors from January through June decreased very slightly from the previous year, but some resorts have been busy. At the palatial, newly expanded Ritz-Carlton St. Thomas with 200 rooms and suites, each with a private balcony or terrace, and a plush new spa with an inviting lounge on a scenic terrace, occupancy rates in July reached 90 percent. Some low-season guests have gotten rooms for $189. High-season rates, starting at $489, have not risen this year. "We're being conservative," said Jamie Holmes, the general manager, "because we feel the market is still a little bit fragile."
 In August, responding to dismal bookings, and competing with newer, spiffier hotels, the 65-room friendly Bolongo Bay Beach Club on St. Thomas, which has two popular restaurants and simple rooms facing a 1,000-foot crescent-shaped beach, dropped its $145 a night autumn rate to $79 until Nov. 23 for reservations made by Nov. 1. Bolongo Bay is also offering 20 percent discounts on all hotel packages and activities from Jan. 3 to 31, pricing rooms at $172 a night.
 On St. John -- more than a million people visited the popular National Park in 2002 -- snorkelers ply the blue-green waters along beautiful beaches, and hikers walk scenic trails. The Cinnamon Bay Campground and the resort Maho Bay Camps within the park have been thriving. From high season through April, occupancy rates at the 114-unit Maho Bay Camps were 85 to 90 percent, bolstered by family and yoga groups. The resort's "real gem," said Maggie Day, the general manager, has been the Art Center, where guests learn how to blow glass, make pottery and create other hand-crafted pieces. Winter double rates, $110 for a tent-cottage ($115 for February and Christmas and Easter weeks), will stay the same.
 The elegant Buccaneer Resort on St. Croix, on 340 acres with 138 rooms and suites, an 18-hole golf course, a spa and eight tennis courts, is offering a fourth night free for rooms with ocean views Jan. 4 through 24. Winter rates start at $295, including full breakfast and use of kayaks. 
 Tourism on the island has been down, said Joel Tutein, superintendent of the U.S. Virgin Islands Park Group in St. Croix. In 1988, the year before Hurricane Hugo permanently closed four large hotels, the coral-rich Buck Island Reef National Monument, he said, attracted 105,000 visitors, compared with 50,213 in 2002. Carnival Cruise Lines stopped coming in May of last year because of "crime against passengers and crew," said Jennifer de la Cruz, a spokeswoman for Carnival. Later, other cruise lines bypassed St. Croix, causing shops and the cruise ship terminal to close. Now, with surveillance cameras in place and more police, it is possible, according to industry representatives, that at least some ships will return. 
 A well-regarded dive shop, St. Croix Ultimate Bluewater Adventures, has been seeking new divers by giving free scuba demonstrations in hotel pools and last month staged a large underwater wedding. There is a new scuba shop and a new pier for dive boats at the 129-room Divi Carina Bay Resort and Casino, which is offering new nightly bargain rates as well: $174 for a standard room Jan. 4 to Feb. 7, and after that, $190 until April 9, compared with $225 last winter, when the occupancy rate was only 50 percent. Perched along a beach protected by a reef, the hotel expects to open 50 more rooms that can be turned into 25 suites by the end of March.
 The Bahamas, on the other hand, seem to be in a mild upswing. There are 700 Bahamian islands and 22,000 rooms in a variety of hotels, villas and timeshares; the major excitement is in the Outer Islands with the Nov. 15 opening of the 183-room Four Seasons Resort Great Exuma at Emerald Bay. The resort will have a spa and fitness club, Zen garden and 18-hole golf course; a casino will follow. Set on a crescent-shaped inlet, the hotel is British colonial in style with a cluster of three-story pastel stucco buildings with shutters and white tile roofs.
 Through the end of June, Bahamas air arrivals were up 1.2 percent, hotel occupancy rates were 63.9 percent and room rates were up 5.7 percent over 2002, according to the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. "Some resorts have done spectacularly well, like Atlantis," said Vincent Vanderpool-Wallace, director general of tourism, referring to the megaresort on Paradise Island, "and others not so well."
 "We know what the problem is: customers want properties spruced up a bit," he added. "Atlantis has shown us that sun, sand and sea are not enough. People don't buy rooms, they buy an anticipated experience." 
 The 2,300-room Atlantis is popular, said Howard Karawan, executive vice president of Kerzner International, which developed, owns and operates the resort, because of its many activities. The occupancy rate at Atlantis this year through mid-September was 85 percent with no rate decrease, though since 9/11 marketing has increased. Last month the company broke ground on the first phase of a $600 million expansion, luxury villas, at the intimate One & Only Ocean Club, where winter rates start at $695. "This has been by far its most successful year," Mr. Karawan said, referring to the Ocean Club's 80 percent occupancy rates this year. "High-end people are still traveling." 
 Jamaica had an increase in stayover visitors -- 7 percentage points in the first six months of this year over the same months last year, according to the director of tourism, Paul Pennicook. He said that more people were looking for soft adventure, such as swimming with dolphins, possible in Montego at Half Moon Bay Resort, which has a new Dolphin Lagoon. The price for an hour's swim is $155. Within the next year, Mr. Pennicook said, the island will have more than 1,000 new rooms, mostly in new all-inclusive hotels and lodgings. The all-inclusive Riu Club Negril with 450 to 500 rooms is scheduled to open in March near its sister resort, the Riu Club Tropical Bay. Prices for this winter, he predicted, "will inch up but will still not get back to pre-9/11 prices -- I don't think that will happen until 2005."
 On Grenada, a new hotel owner, Susan Fisher, a former fashion executive, recently opened Bel Air Plantation on the southeastern coast. The resort is made up of six villas and five cottages built on a hillside, along with an upscale restaurant, cafe, grocery, art gallery and small beach. Butterfly and bird aviaries will follow next year. With winter rates starting at $295 a night, Bel Air hopes to attract busy people who crave serenity, Ms. Fisher said. To that end, it does not admit guests under the age of 15. For bookings for 2004 made by Nov. 30, seven nights will be offered for the price of six.
 In the Dominican Republic, known for competitive pricing, 223 of 7,000 new hotel rooms this year can be found at the all-inclusive Viva Tangerine, scheduled to open Nov. 1 on a 361-foot beach in Cabarete, a North Coast wind-surfing town. From Jan. 3 through 31, double rates will start at $174, and from February through April 10, $190, including meals, drinks and wine, 24-hour snacks, aerobics, nonmotorized water sports, nightly entertainment, dance lessons, yoga and meditation classes, and programs for children from 4 to 18. Beginning Dec. 1, when the parent company, Viva Resorts, joins Wyndham International to become Viva Wyndham Resorts, the hotel will be called Viva Wyndham Tangerine. 
 Tiny, mountainous Saba in the Dutch West Indies is home to the Ecolodge Rendez-Vous, built to attract nature lovers, hikers and divers, with 12 simple cottages (with bathrooms), most of which sleep four, costing $85 a night in high season. Since it opened in August 2002, occupancy rates have been only about 25 percent, but the Rendez-Vous's Rainforest Restaurant has become popular.
 Near Saba, there are bargains on both sides of the island shared by Dutch St. Maarten and French St. Martin. Hotel packages on St. Maarten have been offering every fourth night free, every fourth day car rental free, and a $50 coupon per room redeemable at restaurants and other places, similar to a program last year when every third night was free. The promotion may go beyond Dec. 15, said Regina LaBega, St. Maarten's director of tourism. Hotel occupancy rates have been averaging 65 percent this year, she said, compared with 48 to 50 percent last year. St. Martin hotels are offering every seventh night free until Dec. 15 and will have other promotions for winter.
 New spas are springing up around the Caribbean like ferns in a rain forest, from St. Kitts in the Leeward Islands to tiny, exclusive Mustique, part of St. Vincent and the Grenadines. "In the old days," said Mark Nooren, managing director of the Renaissance Aruba Beach Resort and Casino, recently upgraded with a $13 million redo, "a resort was all about restaurants, discos and casinos. Now it's about spas, tai chi and yoga." In addition to therapies at its Okeanos Spa, the resort offers massages in a cove on its private island, which is frequented by flamingoes.
 Hot rocks (massages with stones) are showing up at many places. One is Indulgence by the Sea on Aruba, a small new spa at the all-inclusive Divi Aruba, a sister resort to the Tamarijn Aruba. A massage might be needed after a visit to the new 3,000-square-foot activity center, set to open this winter with a 30-foot-high climbing wall and a health club with Cybex workout equipment. A nine-hole golf course is expected to be completed in March or April.
 And there are French-trained spa therapists at the stylish new Cap Est Lagoon Resort and Spa on the southeast coast of Martinique. Thirty-five of the hotel's 50 suites have pools. Winter rates start at $468 and include the breakfast buffet.
 At secluded Little Dix Bay in Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands, a new cliffside spa has a two-tier plunge pool, nine treatment rooms in separate cottages offering views and, among other treatments, a $125 Virgin Gorda goat milk and honey wrap. To the southwest at upscale Peter Island Resort, the old spa has been replaced with a larger one: 13,000 square feet and 10 treatment suites large enough for couples. 
 St. John's genteel Caneel Bay Resort will soon have new activities at its Self Center, which a brochure describes as "a mind body spirit center." Among the new sessions will be the Art of Divine Love for Couples, Planetary Cycles and World Trends, and the Healing Power of Music.
 Coco Kreole on St. Lucia has no spa, but starting at $80 a night ($75 in low season), it is cheap and cheerful. The 20-room yellow and blue boutique hotel, equipped with wireless Internet access, is scheduled to open this weekend in Rodney Bay, near local restaurants and bars. Allen Chastanet, its owner, has plans to build 90 more rooms nearby. 
 Among islands contemplating ways to fill vacant hotel rooms, Dominica, the island with relatively few good swimming beaches but pristine waterfalls, coral reefs, hiking trails, a boiling lake and magnificent rain forests, also shelters large, endangered turtles. By persuading its resident turtle hunters to become turtle guides, the local tourist authority is hoping to add a new activity for visitors -- watching the island's leatherback, hawksbill and green turtles.
 For bargain hunters dreaming of coconut rum punches on a tropical beach, summer's fire sales have vanished. But now that "just in time" bookings are pervasive, last-minute specials seem likely. As Mr. Pennicook of Jamaica said: "We have been our own worst enemy in this industry. We have trained customers to expect bargains."

HEADLINE: Mr. Washington Goes to Mississippi 

BYLINE:  By Nicholas Dawidoff; Nicholas Dawidoff is the author, most recently, of "The Fly Swatter," a finalist for the 2003 Pulitzer Prize in biography.

 BODY:
August afternoons in rural Mississippi are so oppressively hot that even the mule -- prized by local farmers for its ability to withstand the sun -- was traditionally taken out of harness and "shaded" during the warmest hours. For aspiring politicians, however, there is no such relief: they have to take the heat all day long. 
 Which explains why Haley Barbour, the 55-year-old Republican candidate for governor of Mississippi who will challenge the Democratic incumbent, Ronnie Musgrove, in what promises to be a closely contested Nov. 4 election, is walking across a dusty red-dirt parking lot in Leake County toward a livestock-auction barn on an August day when, says Parks McNabb, one of Barbour's many youthful campaign workers, "they've got the heat set on hell." Mississippi is a state that roils with poverty and pride, and gubernatorial candidates who don't at least try to "strike hands" with every voter in the state still risk the dread appellation "uppity." There are now 2.8 million citizens spread across Mississippi's sprawling expanse of 82 counties, and at mud derbies, catfish fries, county fairs and N.R.A. banquets, Barbour has extended his hand and said "How you doin', I'm Haley" to a lot of them. A portly fellow with a looming, affable face and a rigid discus of silvering hair, Barbour has already shed 20 pounds during his summer on the hustings. 
 Now he walks past a farmer selling watermelons off the back of a truck and enters a battered amphitheater where perhaps a hundred slouching men are studying a gangly calf while the auctioneer calls out bids in a fevered chant. Barbour begins slapping backs, introducing himself around. The auctioneer looks annoyed. "We get a lot of politicians in here," he barks at Barbour. And with that he kicks him out of his barn. 
Back in the parking lot, while his wife, Marsha, buys a watermelon, Barbour is unabashed. "Profit's got to be made," he says cheerfully. "Guy's gotta sell cows. It's his business."
Barbour himself has a business. Out on the stump, speaking in a drawl lately grown so sweet and sticky you could pour it on your griddle cakes, the candidate likes to refer to "our little lobbyin' firm up in Washington, D.C." There is, however, nothing down-home about Barbour Griffith & Rogers Inc. Situated in a luxe office building high above Pennsylvania Avenue, B.G.&R. is perhaps the most influential lobbying firm in the country. In a day when some lobbyists wield more power than many legislators, Barbour has been the best connected of them all, "the quintessential creature of Washington," according to The Washington Post. 
Befitting a man to whom some of the world's most powerful corporations have paid many millions of dollars to press their interests in Washington, the office Barbour has left behind is a spacious room with soft green leather furniture, a collection of fine whiskey and wines and walls covered with photographs of Barbour alongside the many Republican sachems he has served over the years: among them Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, Newt Gingrich and George W. Bush, whom Barbour used to call Junior. When Barbour required a little air, he could step out onto his private balcony and gaze upon the Capitol, off to his left, and the White House, over to the right -- each of them mere blocks away and with doors that were very responsive to Barbour's knock. If he desired prandial refreshment, Barbour could stroll down to the Caucus Room, with feasting senators in the lunchtime crowd and a salad on the menu named after him. That's an insider joke. Barbour is prone to prime steaks with his bourbon, and at the Caucus Room there is always a tender cut waiting for him. There had better be: he founded the joint. 
Yet even more intriguing than Barbour's decision to forsake this gilded life for the more rustic pleasures of the Mississippi Statehouse is the mere fact of his candidacy. Lobbyists are by definition the champions of special interests, the landlords of the back room with scant interest in the little guy who cannot afford their costly rents. 
Their infamous reputation is the reason that, through most of this country's history, the mere idea of a man with such a professional background running for governor would have been risible. That Haley Barbour may become the first political lobbyist of his stature ever to win a high elective office, indeed, that he is a viable candidate at all, is a weather vane that points vividly to where we are now as a political nation. 
On a recent Friday morning, a gleaming succession of expensive sedans and S.U.V.'s began turning into the parking lot at the Mississippi Coliseum in downtown Jackson. Eleven hundred prosperous Republicans were arriving to have lunch with Barbour, for which they had paid $1,000 or, if they wanted their pictures to be taken with Barbour's guest of honor, $10,000. That guest was President George W. Bush, one of many Republicans who have traced a path to Mississippi, including Vice President Dick Cheney; Donald Evans and Rod Paige, members of the Bush cabinet; Jeb Bush, Florida's governor; Senator Elizabeth Dole; and Ari Fleisher. When Ed Gillespie, the Republican Party chairman, came to Jackson in August, he promised that the party would "do everything that we're legally allowed to do" for Barbour. As for the other Republican races this fall, Gillespie allowed that "they're all important to us, but Haley Barbour and I go way back."
One of Barbour's political skills is his ability to have things both ways. As a man of means running for office in a disadvantaged state, he has employed a folksy conversational insouciance to leaven his aura of privilege even as he is stressing his high-placed connections. The day before the Bush luncheon, he told The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson's paper, that he and the president were the sort of friends who "talk politics, prop up our feet, walk over somewhere and get lunch." Then, at the Mississippi Coliseum, Barbour listened as the president climaxed his remarks by describing Barbour as "a fellow that when he picks up the phone, the president might just go ahead and answer it." Afterward, Bush went to the airport; the BMW's and Mercedeses departed, too, leaving Barbour with a new campaign-fund infusion of $2.2 million. 
For any candidate that would be an exemplary midday's work, but in Mississippi, where the median household income is $30,161, it is a truly astonishing sum. Barbour is now moving at a fund-raising pace that is expected to more than double the combined $6 million that Musgrove and his Republican opponent spent in their 1999 governor's race. 
He seeks the cash because election politics in Mississippi are really no longer much different than they are everywhere else. Old-style retail handshaking and speechifying may still be necessary for cosmetic reasons, but as Senator Thad Cochran, a Mississippi Republican, says, they are "not nearly as important as having a good television strategy." Importing prestigious national politicians is a time-tested means of getting free television coverage on the news and enables Barbour to raise the money to pay for the television advertisements with which he has been saturating state living rooms since February. It also helps buttress the impression that as a man with access to powerful people he will be a governor with the ability to extract favors for the state. What remains to be seen is whether Barbour can spend himself local. He has, as they say, been away for a while. 
The son of a lawyer, the grandson of a banker, Barbour comes from Yazoo City, a small town on the fringes of the Mississippi Delta, the vast flood plain that contains some of the richest soil and poorest people in the United States. Ignatius Semmes Luckett, who went to the University of Mississippi with Barbour, says that the Delta "was a wonderful place to grow up if you were a privileged white kid. If you had the sensitivity of an anvil, it helped you though."
Mississippians frequently describe their politics as "inbred," and the great incubators are the elite Ole Miss fraternities. Barbour enrolled at the university in 1965, and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi recalls him as "one of the stars going through rush." He pledged Sigma Alpha Epsilon, where the Tara-like columns in front of the house are guarded by gold lions, and soon earned a reputation as a man of access and influence. "He was a big dog," says Candy Barnes, a schoolmate. "Sort of a fixer. If you needed something, Haley could arrange it." 
In 1968, he ran for student-body president. Among the candidates was another Delta boy named Walter Thompson. Less than a week before the election, a Barbour campaign worker mimeographed a one-page anti-Thompson screed and, in the dead of night, distributed what became known as "the smut sheet." "First dirty trick I ever saw in campaign politics," says Ray Mabus, the former Mississippi governor, who is a University of Mississippi graduate and a Democrat. "He was clearly willing to do anything to win." On election day, both Barbour and Thompson were defeated.
That summer, Barbour presided over 30 counties for Richard Nixon's presidential campaign. Republican politics had begun to offer rare opportunities for a young, talented Mississippian. The South had voted Democrat since the party of Lincoln imposed Reconstruction right after the Civil War. Then, in 1964, the Johnson administration's passage of the Civil Rights Act led to the Republican challenger Barry Goldwater's Southern sweep in November. (Goldwater won 87 percent of the vote in Mississippi.) With the party only beginning to field candidates, Barbour became a regional power broker while still in his early 20's. Clarke Reed, a businessman who took on the revival of Republican politics as a personal mission and admired Barbour's efficiency and intensity, says he was "publicly invisible, doing the work, making the contacts." 
With Mississippi suddenly in play on a national political level, Reed and Barbour could get an appointment to see virtually any Republican they wanted, including senators, congressmen, President Nixon and members of his cabinet. "We'd entertain, throw swell parties," Reed says. "We worked the hell out of Washington." 
In the mid-1970's, Barbour joined the family law firm in Yazoo City. It was in those years, Reed says, that Barbour first "evolved into lobbying." Barbour describes that evolution during the one brief interview he granted for this article: "Having been a lawyer, I didn't think being a lobbyist was any worse than what I was used to. Lobbying is just another form of advocacy. It's like trying a lawsuit." 
Seated in his campaign R.V., Barbour says that he "never dreamed" of running for governor until he realized that "we're in the worst financial mess in the state's history." He bemoans the loss of manufacturing jobs, low school test scores, soaring drug-related crime, lawsuit abuses and the fissiparous relationship between the governor and the Legislature. He insists that he will be a persuasive advocate for the state. That "Mississippi's in crisis" is a fundament of Barbour's campaign. But Barbour's lobbying partner Lanny Griffith admits that part of the rationale is, "He's been successful, and it's a way to cap off a career." 
In his campaign office one recent morning looking eerily energized after he had, as usual, permitted himself four hours' sleep, Gov. Ronnie Musgrove regarded Barbour's revelations skeptically. For decades, Mississippi has rated near the bottom in nearly every quality-of-life index, including per capita income. The numbers remain bleak, with nearly 18 percent of all residents living below the federal poverty level. Yet, of late, there have also been some causes for optimism. Barbour is running and raising so hard because he has a formidable rival. 
Musgrove is a man without pedigree, an anti-abortion-rights, bird-hunting conservative Democrat who in many ways embodies the Republican ideal of the self-made man. The child of blue-collar workers, neither of whom completed 11th grade, Musgrove had jobs from the time he was 10, laboring in cotton and soybean fields, roughnecking on oil rigs and selling reference books door to door. With the money, he put himself first through community college, then Ole Miss -- where he was not invited to pledge a fraternity -- and finally the University of Mississippi law school. In 1987, he was elected to the Legislature and was voted lieutenant governor eight years later; he became governor four years ago.
Education, Musgrove's means of personal ascent, has been his political fixation, and he is always holding forth on why"our first priority as a state has to be our schools." Unfortunately for Musgrove, these discourses are delivered in a chirpy hill-country tremolo that genteel Mississippians -- and state legislators -- find oppressive. (For a time, the Barbour campaign considered using "A Strong Voice for Change" as its campaign slogan.) Nonetheless, Musgrove has been a reasonably effective agent of progress. Under his watch, Mississippi has financed substantial raises in teacher pay, has placed a computer in every classroom and has managed to attract a Nissan factory -- and more than 5,000 well-paying jobs -- to Canton. That the plant is the only automobile factory to open in the country this year, and during a time of national recession, when factories have been fleeing Mississippi, is an economic and a symbolic achievement for a state where employers have tended to doubt the capacities of the work force.
Musgrove contends that "this election is not about who can raise the most money, how many ads are put on television, who has the most political friends in Washington." But if Barbour has grasped anything during his life in politics, it's that the Mississippi governor's race may well be about exactly those things. Barbour has always demonstrated a penetrating understanding of the modern process of achieving political power. He put that savvy to such abundant use in the service of so many Republicans after leaving Yazoo City that he may be as responsible as anyone for the current national dominance of the party.
Barbour seems to have always been a student of politics, scrutinizing the men he served and extracting shrewd lessons from their careers about what it takes to be elected. That is to say, he does not seem like an organic politician so much as one sedulously self-formed in the experiences of other people. 
In 1980, he worked for John Connally, the former governor of Texas, a magnetic but flawed candidate who spent $13 million in a disastrous run for the Republican presidential nomination. Barbour says that one thing he learned from Connally was not to be too forthcoming: "I'd say, 'Gee, Governor, we got to get us a stock answer!"'
Two years later, John Stennis, a six-term Democratic senator, came up for re-election. Stennis was such a revered icon in Mississippi that even the 60 minutes a year he spoke to the press were celebrated as "the Hour of Accountability." "Running against John Stennis was like running against John the Baptist," Trent Lott says. Still, when no Republican stepped forward, Barbour announced his challenge. 
Competing against an octogenarian who had lost a leg and tended to ramble when he spoke, the 34-year-old Barbour employed the principle campaign strategy of implying that Stennis was too old for the job while always denying that he was implying any such thing. (Barbour's campaign slogan was "A Senator for the 80's.") Once, when Stennis arrived for a speech, he was greeted by a banner from the Barbour campaign wishing him a happy 81st birthday. A small girl gave him a cake with 82 candles on it. Later, after Stennis refused to debate him, Barbour broadcast an "empty chair" debate splicing in disjointed clips from the Hour of Accountability for Stennis's responses. Lanny Griffith, who managed Barbour's 1982 Senate campaign, explains: "You couldn't just run a positive campaign. Ultimately, we knew we wouldn't win unless people made a conscious decision that Senator Stennis was too old for the job. We had to do things to encourage that process of examination." 
Of the "debate," Mike Espy, a former Mississippi Democratic congressman, says that it made "Stennis seem incoherent and senile, which was clever but doomed Barbour." 
The undignified treatment of Stennis infuriated many voters. John Jameson, a Washington political consultant who was then a Stennis campaign worker, remembers one man telling him, "I'd vote for a yellow dog that had been lying dead in the hot August sun for two weeks before I'd vote for Haley Barbour." Stennis easily won re-election.
One of Barbour's lowest moments of the campaign was when President Ronald Reagan refused to come to Mississippi to campaign for him. Reagan and Stennis were friendly, and Stennis, it turned out, had asked the president to stay in Washington. "That hurt Haley personally," Griffith says. "But things have changed. Now he's pretty much got anybody in the country." 
'The oil of politics is personal relationships," says Alan Simpson, the retired Republican senator of Wyoming, and few men have been more gifted at such lubricating than Barbour. His melting grin and gregarious conversation strewn with local color are seductive enough that he is described by assorted Democrats as "amiable," "easygoing," "irresistible" and "friendly." But for all of his pigs in pokes, dogs that won't hunt and troubles lying in the weeds, Barbour never fell off any turkey truck. Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonpartisan government-watchdog organization in Washington, says: "He's a charming, likable, roguish character who represents despicable clients. Nobody knows who the real Haley Barbour is beneath all the schmooze." 
Barbour served as President Reagan's political director from 1985 to 1986. Ed Rogers, Barbour's other lobbying partner, who was his deputy in those days, remembers the glee with which Barbour networked. "He had the attitude, 'Let's ask for forgiveness not permission,"' Rogers says. In the years after leaving the Reagan White House in 1986, Barbour joined and left lobbying, law and consulting firms -- always, he says, retaining a financial interest -- sat on corporate boards, raised funds, advised campaigns and pursued political connections with a breathless appetite. "He's an entrepreneur," says former Senator Bob Dole. "He's this. He's that. He's everywhere. He's like fog. Get up in the morning, there's Haley, a cloud hanging over somewhere." 
Or at least hunkered in the parking lot. When Dole was Senate majority leader, according to Rogers, Barbour somehow cadged a parking pass so that he could sit in his car until Dole arrived for work. Then, Rogers says, Barbour "would ambush him, walk in with him." People hired him because he gave excellent advice, was, Senator Cochran says, "indefatigable" and made and maintained relationships with powerful people. And what kind of guy is he? His nephew Henry Barbour, who is managing Barbour's gubernatorial campaign, says that his uncle "is a voracious reader." Reader of what? "Memos," Henry says. His singular devotion to his work caused his wife to spend most of her time in Mississippi, saying, "I'd rather be by myself in Yazoo City than be by myself in Washington." 
Barbour, meanwhile, became chairman of the Republican National Committee in 1993. With a Democrat in the White House, Democratic majorities in both the Senate and the Congress and the Republican Party cleaved by conservative and moderate factions, it was another time of opportunity for Barbour. He spent many evenings with the Congressional minority whip, Newt Gingrich, "our coats off, sleeves rolled up," Gingrich says, plotting the Republican agenda. Barbour faxed daily missives exhorting Republicans to heed what were becoming their unifying tropes -- small government, low taxes, mild regulation and relentless outrage at Bill Clinton. Barbour became a catalyst for a more publicly disciplined party that would win historic majorities in both houses.
Barbour's fruitful insight was that electoral politics at the millennium was substantially about who had more money and that a small collection of wealthy contributors could bring the Republican Party control of a very large country. The 1994 and 1996 elections were his great preoccupations as chairman, and he took them on with a military aggressiveness. In particular, he was a cunning and determined fund-raiser, coaxing record-setting donations through all manner of enticements, including invitations to cocktail parties and meals with politicians like Gingrich and Dole. Barbour was reported to be happy to place telephone calls to state legislators on behalf of corporate contributors to the R.N.C. The party created policy institutes with high-minded names like the Coalition for Our Children's Future and then spent the bulk of their financing on campaign issue-ads. 
It was the coming of the Age of the Lobbyist. In 1968, there were 62 lobbyists in Washington; today there are 21,000. Barbour understood that beyond petitioning legislators, lobbyists were now, in effect, their fund-raisers. By soliciting campaign donations from their corporate clients in exchange for access to candidates, lobbyists asserted themselves as essential middlemen. Noting this, as party chairman Barbour was not above a little intimidation; according to The Washington Monthly, executives were warned that there would be consequences for hiring Democratic lobbyists -- a brazen technique now officially known as the K Street Project, after the area in Washington where many lobbyists have their offices.
Not that he was reluctant to make direct requests for donations. "The first rule of fund-raising is, You gotta ask, and Haley ain't afraid to ask," Henry Barbour says. "Second rule is, You've got to ask for a specific amount of money. He does. He asks for a lot. He likes to say: 'You got to flatter 'em. You want the guy to give you 5 grand, ask for 15. Let him give you 5 and make him think he got off easy."' Lanny Griffith says: "He really does enjoy it. He's so neat and orderly about raising money, it's almost like counting votes."
Before his candidacy, Barbour said that he viewed politics as "a game" and, according to Charles Lewis, that "if the terms and conditions are right, I don't have anything that isn't for sale except my wife and children." The jovial candor with which he sometimes discussed his tactics defused the toughness of his methods. Barbour appeared to be a sportsman fencing with his Democratic rivals. One of his contradictions is how such a congenial man can be so blithely capable of behavior that others consider unethical. When he began the job as party chairman, Barbour promised to divest himself of his lobbying concerns, but never did. As a gubernatorial candidate, he has again not severed his financial ties. "You can be sure that everyone in town knows it's still Haley's firm, and sitting lobbyists making millions of dollars influencing government should not be simultaneously running for office," Lewis says. 
Recent disclosures that Barbour's lobbying partners, Griffith and Rogers, are two of the principals in New Bridge Strategies, a company that somewhat impatiently describes itself as brokering "areas of opportunity" for American businessmen in postwar Iraq, has led Barbour to disclaim any real connection to the outfit. Yet, New Bridge Strategies shares an address with Barbour Griffith & Rogers, and Barbour previously served on the advisory boards of two New Bridges affiliate companies. 
In 1997, Barbour completed his term as party chairman and returned to the lobbying trade. Immediately, many of the R.N.C.'s biggest corporate donors signed on with his firm. Added to a client list that already included the Swiss government -- requiring counsel following news reports that its national bank had financed the Nazi government by securing the deposit of looted wartime gold -- were the five major tobacco companies (which gave the Republican Party a reported $22 million between 1996 and 2001), airlines, drug companies and defense contractors. Most lobbying firms in Washington have a bipartisan roster of employees, but B.G.&R. insists on a Republican staff, right down to the receptionists. The advice the firm often gives its corporate clients includes this: Open a Washington office and supply those in-house lobbyists with plump checks for the politicians you want something from.
Those checks can be handed off in person at B.G.&R. For years, night after night there have been elegant cocktail receptions at the firm, where clients stand amid orchids, objets and tables amply spread with food and liquor confiding their legislative desires. Barbour contends that lobbying is only "effective at the margins," but this is vintage self-deprecation. Barbour's friend, Democratic foil and restaurant partner, the colorful lobbyist Tommy Boggs, says that "in the Senate, where it's very difficult to get anything passed, a lobbyist can influence five to seven senators."
The Interpublic Group of Companies, a marketing-services company, made a similar estimation of Barbour's capacities. In 1999, Interpublic bought B.G.&R. for $20 million, retaining Barbour as C.E.O. The next year, B.G.&R. took in nearly $11 million from clients like Phillip Morris, Lockeed-Martin, GlaxoSmithKline and Microsoft. Those businesses were glad to honor Barbour's lavish invoices because they know he can see any Republican he likes and that lawmakers tend to respond to his wishes. 
In 1997, for instance, on behalf of his tobacco clients, Barbour rolled up his sleeves with Gingrich shortly before the balanced-budget agreement was to be passed by Congress. Together, the two former colleagues quietly infused the bill with a $50 million tobacco tax break. Only when it reached the Senate was Barbour's handiwork exposed and denounced by Senator Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, as "midnight madness" that "shines and stinks like rotten mackerel in the moonlight."
Nobody can say how often such ploys succeed, but they do. One of Washington's truths is that legislators frequently don't read bills and that lobbyists often draft them. A most instructive primer as to how government now works is to stand in a senator's office with one of his aides and have him take you line by line through a bill, telling you which lobbyist wrote each sentence. Senators and congressmen spend so much of their time fund-raising that they rely on lobbyists for expertise, trusting that with each side presenting its case just solutions will prevail. 
In 2001, as the Bush administration was contemplating its energy policy, several major utilities contracted with Barbour to lobby against regulations for the industry. During the previous year's election campaign, Bush promised to set limits on power-plant emissions. But in March, Vice President Cheney receiveda pointed letter from Barbour wondering how Cheney intended to distinguish his administration's environmental policy from "Clinton-Gore." Two weeks later, Bush announced that the utilities would get what they wanted. 
Campaigning against "a multimillionaire Washington lobbyist" has proved irresistible to Musgrove. He has drenched radios and televisions with tales of Barbour "helping the big tobacco companies that peddle their products to our children and poison their future" and collecting lobbying fees from the Mexican government and lobbying for free trade, which "cost Mississippi 41,000 jobs." 
And what route does a man with a cartographer's knowledge of the Washington political geography take when he ventures outside the Beltway? During an appearance at a DeSoto County Catholic school, in a somewhat cryptic attempt to express his support for Head Start programs, which help poor children, Barbour said: "Head Start is a godsend for Mississippi. Some of those kids in it would be better off sitting up on a piano bench at a whorehouse than where they are now."
That was the rare unscripted moment. Barbour has conducted the coy campaign you might expect from a man about whom Barbour's brother Jeppie says, "My brother's a politician with more tact than nerve." Barbour offers rhetoric busy with conservative shibboleths -- "For people who choose not to work, those who do work shouldn't have to pick up the pail for you." But such welfare-bashing does little, it would seem, to advance the debate about how to solve Mississippi's chronic poverty.
Barbour's enormous campaign budget and speeches consisting of gestures to patriotism, moral values, low taxes, jobs creation, small government but big law enforcement make clear that it is Barbour who is Junior Bush; he has replicated himself from the presidential template. Barbour, in fact, makes frequent references to Bush's personal affection for him as a fellow C student and is given to denouncing "liberals" with a borrowed dose of bravado. "Bring 'em on!" he cries day after day. 
Barbour's campaign has experienced some unexpected obstacles. In August, his son Reeves was arrested for public drunkenness. There has also been the question of what many Mississippians consider Barbour's belated interest in the state's problems. While Barbour did join a successful Yazoo City effort to bring a penitentiary to his hometown, Gene Triggs, a retired vice president of Mississippi Chemical Corporation, complains that "he made few contributions to Yazoo City." According to Triggs, the once thriving town has never recovered from the period of school integration in the 1970's and 80's, when many whites, like Haley and Marsha Barbour, packed their children off to the private academies that were opening across the state. "Any parent has the right to send their kids where they can get the best education," Triggs says, but keeping your kids in public school "was one positive stand a person could take to make the community better. I felt he should have exerted some leadership, and he never did." 
During the years Barbour was based in Washington, he sought to keep his feet in two places, accumulating, Barbour says, millions of frequent-flier miles. Richard Scruggs, a prominent Mississippi lawyer, remembers Barbour having himself paged at an Ole Miss football game. "Name recognition, you know," Scruggs says. "He doesn't miss a trick." In his efforts to persuade voters that he is just folks, Barbour has been distancing himself from his previous life, including the Caucus Room, saying, "I got nothing to do with thatbut being a name stockholder." This is news to Tommy Boggs, who says that Barbour "conned" him into the venture. "It was really his idea, which is so Haley," Boggs says.
Musgrove has his own personal vulnerabilities. To exploit them, Barbour favors oblique messages, easily deciphered by his audience and potentially devastating to his opponent. "Haley is one of the best at throwing out a seemingly unrelated idea to create an association -- a kind of subliminal effect," says Marty Wiseman, a political scientist at Mississippi State University. In a religious state where issues of "family" are paramount to many voters, Barbour's penchant for beginning his public sentences with the phrase "Marsha and I" helps voters remember that, as governor, Musgrove was divorced two years ago. There has been more acrimony over what some consider Barbour's racial politics. His practice of wearing a Mississippi State flag pin on his lapel is a reminder to a voting constituency lately referred to as "Nascar whites" that in 2001 Musgrove supported removing the Confederate emblem from the Mississippi flag. But the removal was badly defeated, with only 35 percent of voters backing it, in a state that is 36 percent black. Another source of controversy has been the Web site of a white segregationist organization named the Council of Conservative Citizens, which features a photograph of Barbour attending this summer's C.C.C. fund-raiser for private academy schoolbuses. 
Back in 1967, when William Winter, a Democrat, was running for governor, his campaign was smeared by handbills equating a Winter election with "Negro domination." Recently, according to the Musgrove campaign, handbills have been mailed out that say "Some of Ronnie Musgrove's important appointments" and show photographs of his black appointees. Nobody has claimed responsibility, and the Barbour campaign says it knows nothing about the handbills and denies involvement in any divisive tactics. Barbour says that he hopes to win black votes -- he greets the rare black voter at his events warmly. But James Cobb, a Southern historian at the University of Georgia, says that Barbour is "the poster boy for polarization."
Then there is the matter of the lieutenant governor's election. In Mississippi, candidates for governor and lieutenant governor are obligated by the state Constitution to run separate campaigns and often have little politically in common except party affiliation. The incumbent, Amy Tuck, was elected as a Democrat but switched parties once in office. And when a black lawyer and legislator named Barbara Blackmon won the Democratic lieutenant governor's primary, Barbour introduced the novel notion of a "Musgrove-Blackmon ticket" into his speeches. He has since kept it up, warning his mostly all-white crowds that "Blackmon did a great job getting out her supporters." By supporters, he means blacks. Blackmon, if elected, will become the first African-American to hold statewide office in Mississippi history. A laborer's daughter who grew up in inner-city Jackson, Blackmon graduated from college at 19 and subsequently earned three graduate degrees. Her presence on the ballot is expected to energize Mississippi's heavily Democratic black electorate. When she encountered Barbour after a labor meeting at which he made references to her, she told him that he wasn't running against her and requested that he desist. "He told me I was right, and he wouldn't do it in the future," she says. That has turned out to be Barbour's first broken campaign promise. 
While Barbour denies race-baiting, Winter says that Barbour's mention of the ticket is "a nuanced racist message," and Hodding Carter, president of the Knight Foundation and former editor of The Delta Democrat Times, says that Barbour's reference to liberals and tickets "is simply code for nigger-lover, integrationist, supporter of all the changes they've hated since 1964." To Robert Haws, chairman of the history department at the University of Mississippi, the election has become a referendum on progress. "If the subtle way Haley Barbour's using race is rejected by a Musgrove victory, then we may be into a genuine new era of Mississippi politics. I don't know why a middle-class white Mississippian would vote for Haley Barbour when he doesn't represent their interests at all, but race is still deep here."
At the moment, the Mississippi governor's race is too close to call. Should Barbour win, his many connections could well be beneficial to a small, impoverished state. But would this be good for American politics? After all, it was Walt Whitman who described lobbyists as "crawling, serpentine men, the lousy combings and born freedom sellers of the earth." And just 11 years ago, Ross Perot received 19 percent of the popular presidential vote as an outsider inveighing against lobbyists and special interests. That now, Haley Barbour, the consummate Washington insider, merits reasonable electoral consideration for state office is surely an indication of how dominant the roles of money and influence have become in American politics. And Barbour may be only the beginning. If he prevails in November, Alan Simpson says that other lobbyists will soon follow. "They see he can win," Simpson says, "a lot of those guys will say, 'I'm gonna give it a try."'

 CORRECTION:
An article on Page 48 of The Times Magazine today about Haley Barbour, a lobbyist who is running for governor of Mississippi, misspells the name of a company that has been represented by his group. It is Lockheed Martin, not Lockeed-Martin.
An article on Oct. 19 about Haley Barbour, a lobbyist who is running for the governorship of Mississippi, referred incorrectly to Barbara Blackmon, who is running for lieutenant governor. If elected, she would not become the first African-American to hold statewide office there. The first was James Lynch, elected secretary of state in 1869.
