HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
Two Groups Chart the Island's Economic Future

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
TWO organizations that between them represent most of Long Island's leading business executives, academics and scientists have released separate reports that seek to shape regional economic growth well into the first quarter of the century, positioning Long Island to benefit from increasing government spending on defense and security.
 The organizations -- the Long Island Association and a business and academic consortium led by the State University at Stony Brook -- worked separately on compiling their recommendations. The association's recommendations were the more far-reaching, extending into such areas as housing, transportation and work-force development, while the Stony Brook plan focused on specific technologies -- wireless telecommunications, for instance -- and on forging partnerships with investors. 
 There was some overlap. Both reports endorsed designating Long Island as a federal homeland security center, maintaining or expanding financing for research centers and encouraging more collaboration between businesses, schools and research institutions. 
 The Long Island Association, the region's largest business group, formulated its list of nearly 80 goals on Oct. 9, during a day of member caucuses at the State College at Farmingdale. Members, working from a template supplied by the association, recommended easing permit restrictions on power-plant construction, expanding local government purchasing quotas for businesses owned by women and minorities, and creating an emergency evacuation plan for the Island. They also called for development of publicly financed housing in downtown areas and for expanded mass transit.
 The results were publicly presented the next day at the association's monthly membership luncheon at the Uniondale Marriott attended by about 600 people.
 Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the guest speaker, endorsed the group's goals. "There is tremendous opportunity for economic gain," Senator Clinton said, describing increased federal defense and anti-terrorism spending. "I've read your recommendations. They're very impressive and very sensible. They're exactly the way to go about it."
 Matthew T. Crosson, the association's president, said that support from politicians like Senator Clinton was necessary for the organization's goals to be realized. The association, which has historically emphasized political lobbying as the primary means of economic development, is shifting to a more grass-roots strategy, encouraging members to communicate directly to legislators and other politicians. 
 "It's a different way of doing business," Mr. Crosson said. "This is advocacy by numbers. If members want to pursue their recommendations, we'll pay for transportation for them to go up to Albany and see Joe Bruno and Shelly Silver," a reference to Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker. 
 Many of the association's recommendations involved government initiatives, public financing or tax relief. Proposals in this category included reformulating state school reimbursement rates, pegging them to regional cost of living differentials; financing for more local economic development programs; and enacting federal legislation to make government procurement accessible to small businesses.
 Michael DeLuise, an L.I.A. member who is a vice president at Dowling College and the chairman of the Long Island Convention & Visitors Bureau, said he thought the association's effort to widen member participation was successful.
 During the day when goals were formulated, "we had people participating with various degrees of experience in the industry," Mr. DeLuise said. On the education committee, he said, he deliberated alongside a college president and a retired classroom teacher.
 "Everybody was listened to," Mr. DeLuise said. "Anybody who wanted to be involved could get involved. There was really an open door."
 The Stony Brook group, called the Long Island Technology Agenda 2020, was headed by Yacov Shamash, the dean of the university's engineering and business schools. The region's major research centers -- Brookhaven National Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System -- participated, along with representatives from the Long Island Life Sciences Initiative, the Long Island Software and Technology Network, the Long Island Forum for Technology, the Hauppauge Industrial Association and about 50 high-tech business executives, Dean Shamash said.
 The group was formed at the behest of the Nassau and Suffolk county executives after a regional economic summit was canceled last winter because of snow. 
 "Obviously we want to grow technology on Long Island, because it provides outstanding, high-paying jobs," Dean Shamash said. "We want to maintain our cutting edge. If this plan is implemented, it will keep us at the cutting edge."
 The Stony Brook report emphasized the potential economic benefits of creating and expanding research centers in areas like biotechnology, nanotechnology, sensors, software and wireless telecommunications and extending the research benefits to local manufacturing companies.
 The report called the current defense buildup and rising security spending "a timely opportunity," and drew parallels to the economic benefits that accrued to earlier generations when spending grew sharply -- in World War II and the cold and for space exploration. 
 "New opportunities should be vigorously pursued," the report said. "For example, a bicounty homeland security initiative" linked to New York City. This would "create both a secure region and opportunities for research development and economic growth within our region's universities and small businesses," it continued. 
 The report also pointed to anti-terrorism spending in fields like security and biohazard containment as growth potential areas. It also called for easing the permit process when constructing commercial buildings for biotechnology enterprises and recommended the establishment of a venture-capital forum specializing in biotech investment opportunities.
 Participants referred to the report as a "technology road map," and it made the case that businesses should be involved at every step. "The road map is about moving forward in an integrated way to create a more robust technology community," said Ken Morelly, the president of the Long Island Forum for Technology. Anyone looking for new ideas from either group will be disappointed, said Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "There really was nothing new there," he said, adding that the L.I.A. proposals "repeat what the regional planning board has been advocating since the 1960's, and what the L.I.A. itself has said many, many times over the years."
 Dr. Koppelman, who participated in the Stony Brook deliberations, nevertheless complimented both groups for highlighting regional needs and for encouraging cooperation among disparate groups. 
 "The real significance is they're keeping the pot boiling," he said, "reminding people of the problems and keeping the focus on Long Island problems."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Austin, the chairman of the Long Island Association's transporation committee, presiding over a brainstorming session. (Photo by Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
The Democrats' Fairy Godmother

BYLINE:  By ROBIN STEIN

 BODY:
TWENTY-EIGHT stories above Central Park South, Manhattan looks like a vast sweep of green fringed by jagged piles of skyscrapers. Inside the sunken living room, an appointed tray of teas and pastries waits.
 Agnes Varis offers coffee and a slice of baklava, explaining that the housekeeper is on vacation, and scurries excitedly to her favorite conversation piece, a fringed throw pillow, embroidered with the words, "Behind every great woman is herself." 
 "Hillary loved it," Ms. Varis says with a delighted chuckle, prompted more by her decorating find than the former first lady's visit. The occasion, she explained, was an intimate fund raiser she held in her penthouse apartment for a group of pharmaceutical executives during Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign. 
 Any evening that involves prescription drugs and Democrats - and especially a Clinton -- is going to be particularly memorable for Ms. Varis, the 73-year-old founder and president of Agvar Chemicals and Aegis Pharmaceuticals, suppliers of generic drugs and materials, in Little Falls.
 Round-featured with a lively tuft of brown curls, Ms. Varis seems more like a quirky great aunt than a political powerhouse. Everyone is addressed as "dear" and her cats, Kallee and Zeus, are among her favorite topics of conversation. But the little-known New Jersey businesswoman has quietly evolved into one of the nation's leading Democratic supporters. 
 "She's the greatest," Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, said in an interview. "She's like a Greek Jewish grandmother -- if I have a cold, she asks me about it 10 times."
 Records compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan group that tracks campaign financing, show that in the 2002 election cycle alone, Ms. Varis and her company made nearly a million dollars in political contributions -- 99 percent to Democrats. Even corporate giants like Merck and Dow were outspent by Agvar, a private company with a full-time staff of 12.
 The access she has gained to high-powered Democrats often helps Ms. Varis to promote the causes she advocates - whether it is support services for battered women of Bergen County, children's programs at Lincoln Center, or medicine for service workers who lost their jobs in the terrorism attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 -- and especially her fight to reform prescription drug policy.
 This one-woman lobby says she is committed to making medicine more affordable for Americans. Her battle to expand supplies of lower-priced generic drugs often pits her against the brand-name industry, which has spent $650 million and hired nearly 700 Washington lobbyists for its notoriously powerful political campaign. Ms. Varis is unarguably outgunned, but she is uncompromising -- and effective.
 Even coming from New Jersey, the brand-name drug epicenter, where the industry employs nearly 70,000 people, Ms. Varis said lawmakers have been "incredibly fair."
 "They call me and say, 'Agnes, there is pressure to pass this. Is this going to hurt?"' 
 This summer, despite intense opposition from the brand-name industry, Congress passed a generic drug bill, co-sponsored by Senator Schumer, who said Ms. Varis played an essential role in helping him and his staff draft the legislation, which is now pending in a Congressional conference as part of the Medicare package. 
 "Without her," he said, "I can unequivocally say there wouldn't be a generic drug bill."
 Her fierce political loyalties, tell-it-like-it-is style and willingness to put big money where her mouth is has earned Ms. Varis influence and respect, though sometimes it forces her to break with allies. And her roles as a drug executive, a Democrat and a gadfly are not always easy to reconcile.
 With a slight chuckle, Ms. Varis explained her penchant for controversy. "I'm a Greek American," she said, "So I gesticulate a lot." 
 "Put 10 Democrats in a room, and you end up with 15 political parties," added Ms. Varis, a lifelong Democrat. "That's why it's fun."
 Ms. Varis is often in rooms filled with leading Democrats -- like Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, or Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont or Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York. 
 When Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey got a new aide, Ms. Varis promptly got a call of introduction. 
 "She is one of my favorite people," said Senator Corzine, who rejected the idea that their friendship stemmed from her contributions.
 As he put it, "My acquaintance was struck because of my involvement in politics," but Ms. Varis stands apart from the "people involvedin political giving that you have a fairly business-like relationship with," he said. "She is very interesting and enjoyable to be with." 
 Even in times of scandal, Ms. Varis remains loyal to her party. She admitted being angry about Bill Clinton's involvement with Monica Lewinsky, though she remains charmed by his charisma and commitment to social causes. 
 When Mrs. Clinton's health care initiative provoked an angry backlash, Ms. Varis gave 200 signed copies of her book, "It Takes a Village," to drug industry executives as a party favor. And amid the ethics questions, plummeting poll numbers and censorship by Senate peers that ultimately led Robert G. Torricelli to drop his re-election bid last year, Ms. Varis remains a stalwart supporter. 
 "Bob is so honest, I couldn't give him a $10 Bic pen," she said.
 At the same time, Ms. Varis voted for Ralph Nader for president in 2000, a candidacy that may well have cost Al Gore the presidency. 
 "Of course I live in New York, so I can afford to be a big shot," she said, explaining that Mr. Gore's sure win in the state was only one reason for her defection. "But I'm not happy about the Democrats right now. Who is? They are becoming mild Republicans, wannabes." 
 Even now - as she grumbles about the Bush administration and the new laws that require her to ration contributions to Democratic candidates -- she has a mouthful of tough love. 
 For instance, she complained that the Democratic Leadership Council -- which helped catapult Mr. Clinton, a former chairman, onto the national stage -- treats progressives like "dinosaurs" and regards the party's traditional mishmash of constituencies as a politically lethal disease. "People in Peoria have different interests and values than me, sure," she said. "But since when did we all have to be the same?"
 "Most Democrats have big mouths and small wallets." Ms. Varis said, explaining why she gives so much money to Democratic candidates.
 Despite millions of dollars in political spending and vocal lobbying, Ms. Varis is not widely known.
 It is not that Ms. Varis has demanded anonymity in exchange for her contributions -- her name graces a New York election institute that trains Democratic women to run for public office as well as an endowed professorship and a lecture hall at Tufts University. Nearly a thousand unemployed service workers who lost their health insurance in the aftermath of Sept. 11 have "Agvar Generic Drug Plan" cards in their wallets -- good for a year of free generic drug prescriptions at any Duane Reade pharmacy in New York City. 
 But Ms. Varis does not view her political giving as worthy of public notice.
 Last month, when she was the host of a benefit for the New York state Democratic committee, the guest list for the $5,000-a-plate dinner at Alain Ducasse included Mr. and Mrs. Clinton, yet she was stunned by calls from reporters. 
 "Why would you want my picture? I am not a celebrity; I am a hard-working businesswoman," she said. 
 With that, she paused and smiled. Bill Clinton's 50th birthday party at Radio City Music Hall was one she did not want to miss, she admitted. For that one, Ms. Varis and husband, Karl Leichtman, turned out, accompanied by the entire Agvar staff and Chrisetta Campbell, her housekeeper of almost 30 years. 
 To be sure, Ms. Varis works as hard as she plays. Every morning, she is up by 5, and has read The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal before a car arrives to take her to Little Falls.
 After nearly 50 years in New Jersey's pharmaceutical industry, Ms. Varis has no plans to retire. "My housekeeper says if I stopped, I'd die," she said.
 Hard work has been a lifelong habit. She and her husband, who owned a printing business before he retired, now live in a 5,000-square-foot duplex apartment in Manhattan. It is a world away from the two-family home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn where Ms. Varis grew up, and even the townhouse in Englewood where they lived for 11 years. The youngest of eight children raised by Greek immigrants -- a garment worker and ice cream peddler -- Ms. Varis was the first in the family to attend college.
 In 1950, Ms. Varis graduated from Brooklyn College with a bachelor of arts in chemistry and English. Determined to avoid typing pools, she took a temporary position as a chemist at Fine Organics, a manufacturer in Lodi. Twenty years later she was still there, by then executive vice president and general manager of a plant with 300 employees.
 Ms. Varis was political as well as ambitious, founding "New Jersey Business Executives against the Vietnam War."
 "You should have seen my bosses face when he found out," she said. 
 In 1970, a major chemical company was negotiating to buy Fine Organics, hoping that Ms. Varis would stay on. But fearful that she would be plucked for her knowledge and then demoted, she rejected the promise of a lucrative contract. 
 Instead, at age 40, Ms. Varis, started Agvar Chemicals. 
 Years on the factory floor gave Ms. Varis an encyclopedic knowledge of day-to-day operations and the ability to anticipate the implications of coming federal rules for drug companies that were increasingly relying on offshore manufacturers. Agvar opened as a one-woman, "one-stop agent" for foreign-based manufacturers -- linking them to domestic generic companies, and ensuring that every aspect of production and supply complied with complex protocols established by the Food and Drug Administration. 
 Agvar's first contract, as she tells it, was a "bonanza." Ms. Varis helped a French company introduce a primitive version of Viagra, the sexual aid, which flew off the shelves for years until the government stopped reimbursing people for its use. 
 In the meantime, Ms. Varis had bought her first Mercedes-Benz.
 Next to the soft-focus photograph of a sick toddler tethered to an intravenous drip, a caption reads, "Pray for a Miracle because generic drugs will never cure him."
 When Ms. Varis saw the ad -- paid for by the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA), the biggest association of brand-name drug companies -- she was furious. "It was obscene," she said. "How can you use children this way?"
 In the past three years Ms. Varis has run more than two dozen ads in such Washington publications as Roll Call and The Hill with fiery headlines like, "YOUR SILENCE IS DEAFENING!" and, "NO MORE HANKY PANKY!"
 A particularly accusatory series ran in 2001, when Bristol-Myers Squibb tried to extend its patent on a diabetes drug called Glucophage. In response, her ads began: "Have you no shame?" One railed: "Why don't you admit it? Your actions aren't about the safety of our children, they're all about big money. It's all about $2 million a day to feed your insatiable appetite for undeserved, unearned monopoly profits."
 Unlike several competitors, Agvar was not in the market to produce the generic version of Glucophage when Bristol's patent expired. And business colleagues warned that her tone might alienate politicians and brand-name firms, which are often clients of the generic companies.
 In a telephone interview, Jeffrey L. Trewhitt, a spokesman for PhRMA, said he "vaguely recalled" the ads, which he said were "very frustrating" because they "conveniently left out the crucial fact that without the research of the innovator companies, there would be no generic drugs." Bristol Myers declined to comment. 
 Ms. Varis is the first to concede that she is outspoken and does not mind offending people. "I'm an iconoclast," she said. "If I'm going to worry about losing business, I might as well stay home and take care of the cats."
 Yet while she might not be concerned about alienating Bristol Myers, others clearly do mind. Her approach has forced breaks with people who share the same agenda but prefer more measured tactics.
 "Sometimes, it's just me and PhRMA out there," she said. "I am the only one who will do it."
 Ms. Varis played a leading role in bringing together the fragmented generic drug industry to form the Generic Pharmaceutical Association (GPhA) in 2000, and served as vice president for two years. But last year, in part to avoid pressure to reign in her outspoken partisanship and attack ads, she resigned from the group she helped found.
 But are her kamikaze tactics the act of a stubborn purest or a savvy business mind?
 A longtime colleague, William A. Fletcher, president and chief executive of Teva Pharmaceuticals, the world's biggest generic drug company, said that for Ms. Varis there is no difference. "She is very insistent that what is good for consumers is good for generics," he said. "Agnes is a conscience to many of us."
 As Senator Schumer said, "She is so effective because she is genuine." 
 Yet it is difficult to deny that Agvar would benefit from the "Greater Access to Affordable Pharmaceutical Act," which Ms. Varis helped draft. The proposed measure would update the 1984 Hatch-Waxman Act, which established rules for the competition between brand name and generic drug companies. If passed, the bill would limit the ability of brand-name companies to extend patents through infringement lawsuits.
 When asked about the conflict of interest, Ms. Varis scowled, reached for her reading glasses and opened a thick loose-leaf binder filled with pharmaceutical sales data.
 "O.K., let's take Lipitor," she began. "I know people who are supposed to take Lipitor every day who take it once a week," she said, pointing to a cell in the dense spreadsheet. Each $3 pill, she says, costs about 10 to 15 cents to manufacture. 
 Opponents of the bill contend that loosening patent protections would deter brand-name companies from making risky investments in expensive research and slow development of new medicines.
 Not surprisingly, Ms. Varis disagrees. "The only way to make drugs affordable," she said, "is to stop brand people from being greedy." 
 Once the patent expires, Ms. Varis estimates generic versions of Lipitor will cost less than $1.50 a pill. In the meantime, she said, it is the people who can not afford Lipitor who suffer, not her business.
 For all of her stubborn rants, Ms. Varis invariably seems to to be able to revert to the chuckling great aunt with the soft heart.
 One Sunday morning last May, she stood in a procession of women in caps and gowns at Tufts University. Ms. Varis had been selected by the trustees to receive an honorary doctorate in public service. As she followed throngs of students toward the ceremony, she realized that her escort was Peter R. Dolan, Tufts alumnus and chief executive of Bristol-Myers. 
 "He was a nice, tall young man, very good looking," she remembered, "very sweet." 
 She shuddered, but not because of her "Have you no shame?"attacks. That morning, news of a federal criminal investigation into Mr. Dolan's accounting practices had appeared in The New York Times.
 "I felt so bad for him," she said. "I didn't say a word. I was just thinking, 'I hope this guy didn't see the paper."'
 When it was their turn to walk down the aisle, she remembered Mr. Dolan turned to her and offered his arm. "Do you mind?" he asked.
 "Can you imagine, "Ms. Varis exclaimed. "A man like that asking me if I minded taking his arm -- I said, 'My God! Absolutely not."'

HEADLINE: Bush Cites Philippines as Model in Rebuilding Iraq 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: MANILA, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
President Bush told the Congress of this former American colony on Saturday that Iraq, like the Philippines, could be transformed into a vibrant democracy. He also pledged his help in remaking the troubled and sometimes mutinous Philippine military into a force for fighting terrorism.
 In an eight-hour visit, Mr. Bush for the first time drew explicit comparisons between the transition he is seeking in Iraq and the rough road to democracy that the Philippines traveled from the time the United States seized it from Spain in 1898 to the present day. 
 "Some say the culture of the Middle East will not sustain the institutions of democracy," Mr. Bush said, taking on the critics of his oft-stated goal to use Iraq as a laboratory for spreading democratic institutions in the Middle East. "The same doubts were once expressed about the culture of Asia. Those doubts were proven wrong nearly six decades ago." 
While the administration often speaks of the occupations of Japan and Germany after World War II as rough models for the effort to rebuild Iraq, Mr. Bush used the visit here to make a less explicit analogy to the American administration of the Philippines, which also led to the formation of a democracy. But the comparison has less power to reassure, given that the Philippine government did not gain full autonomy for five decades.
Aides traveling with Mr. Bush made it clear that he was worried about the stability of the Philippines. After meeting with President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo and her cabinet shortly after he landed here, Mr. Bush announced that the two countries had formalized a five-year plan "to modernize and reform" the Philippine military, though his aides said it was unclear how much of the cost the United States would contribute.
"The numbers are still in flux," a senior administration official told reporters, adding that the administration was still looking for roughly $20 million to provide the Philippines with used American military helicopters that Mr. Bush promised a year ago to help root out Abu Sayyaf, the terror and kidnapping group that is strongly suspected of being linked to Al Qaeda. 
The announcement was part of a broad plan to provide help to the Philippine military, which Mr. Bush sees as the best hope of preventing the Philippines from becoming a terrorist haven. But it has been marked by a number of setbacks, especially because of a Philippine constitutional prohibition against allowing foreign troops to engage an enemy on Philippine soil. There was no indication that the ban was the subject of talks between the leaders.
Mr. Bush's brief visit here, on the way to the annual Asian economic summit meeting to be held this year in Bangkok, was clearly intended to bolster President Arroyo. Reversing her previous pledge to step down next year, she said this month that she now planned to run for election in May even while still facing down a divided military. Some junior officers tried to oust her from power three months ago. 
The White House and Philippine officials made much of the fact that Mr. Bush was the first president to address a joint session of the Philippine Congress since Dwight D. Eisenhower came here in 1960, at the very end of his presidency. But in a taste of the anger that Mr. Bush has generated around the world, several thousand protesters filled the streets near the Philippine Congress and forced an hourlong delay in the arrival of the president's motorcade while the Secret Service assessed whether it was safe to move him through the streets. In addition to the protesters, tens of thousands of others simply clogged the streets of this humid capital, including schoolchildren waving flags and eager to catch a glimpse of Mr. Bush's motorcade.
The extraordinary security around Mr. Bush's visit here underscored Washington's continuing concerns about the stability of the Philippines. Mr. Bush flew in with American F-15's off the wings of Air Force One. The Secret Service would not permit Mr. Bush to stay overnight. 
The result was a state visit run at the pace at which Mr. Bush plays high-speed golf, from wreath-laying to meetings to his speech. Mr. Bush, his wife, Laura, and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, attended a state dinner at Malacanang Palace. Mr. Bush used his toast there to salute the Philippines as "the oldest democracy in Asia," and to recall that 17,000 Americans are buried here, having fallen in bitter combat with the Japanese during World War II. 
In a rare departure from his aversion to local garb, Mr. Bush was wearing a cream open-collared barong, the traditional Philippine shirt. It bore a vague resemblance to clothes Mr. Bush prefers at his Texas ranch. After dinner he moved on to Bangkok, where he is scheduled for another more formal state visit on Sunday and a meeting with China's new president, Hu Jintao. 
While Mr. Bush made elliptical references to the Spanish-American War, some of his critics have argued that the justification for invading Iraq bore a resemblance to the rationale the United States used to begin that war in 1898, citing evidence, discounted as flimsy, that the battleship Maine had been deliberately blown up in Cuba by Spanish forces. That began the first war in which the United States seized territory beyond its continental shores, and the first in which other nations accused Washington of imperialist and colonial ambitions.
Now, Mr. Bush faces similar accusations from critics questioning whether Saddam Hussein possessed weapons that posed an urgent threat. He gave no ground today.
Mr. Bush said the United States had "liberated the Philippines from colonial rule," using the same verb he often uses to describe American action in Iraq, but he skipped past Washington's own 48-year-long occupation of this archipelago of 7,000 islands. Even the State Department's own briefing papers about the Philippines, distributed to Mr. Bush's traveling retinue, notes that "U.S. administration of the Philippines was always declared to be temporary and aimed to develop institutions that would permit and encourage the eventual establishment of a free and independent government." That is very close to Mr. Bush's description of his plan for Iraq.
He returned to the subject later in his speech, making comparisons between the American experience here in the first part of the 20th century and in Iraq in the 21st, and arguing that the greatest threat to Philippine democracy now was Abu Sayyaf, which operates in the southernmost islands of the Philippines. 
"Murder has no home in any religious faith," Mr. Bush said, "and these terrorists must find no home in the Philippines." He vowed to "bring Abu Sayyaf to justice," and "to dismantle the Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist network" in neighboring Indonesia and nearby areas.
But he also alluded to the troubles with the Philippine military, and its dubious loyalties to the current government. "Members of the Philippine armed forces are commissioned to fight for freedom, not to contend for power," he said to applause.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: PLANNING; 
State Dept. Study Foresaw Trouble Now Plaguing Iraq

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT and JOEL BRINKLEY; Eric Schmitt reported for this article from Washington and Joel Brinkley from Baghdad.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
A yearlong State Department study predicted many of the problems that have plagued the American-led occupation of Iraq, according to internal State Department documents and interviews with administration and Congressional officials.
 Beginning in April 2002, the State Department project assembled more than 200 Iraqi lawyers, engineers, business people and other experts into 17 working groups to study topics ranging from creating a new justice system to reorganizing the military to revamping the economy. 
 Their findings included a much more dire assessment of Iraq's dilapidated electrical and water systems than many Pentagon officials assumed. They warned of a society so brutalized by Saddam Hussein's rule that many Iraqis might react coolly to Americans' notion of quickly rebuilding civil society.
Several officials said that many of the findings in the $5 million study were ignored by Pentagon officials until recently, although the Pentagon said they took the findings into account. The work is now being relied on heavily as occupation forces struggle to impose stability in Iraq. 
The working group studying transitional justice was eerily prescient in forecasting the widespread looting in the aftermath of the fall of Mr. Hussein's government, caused in part by thousands of criminals set free from prison, and it recommended force to prevent the chaos.
"The period immediately after regime change might offer these criminals the opportunity to engage in acts of killing, plunder and looting," the report warned, urging American officials to "organize military patrols by coalition forces in all major cities to prevent lawlessness, especially against vital utilities and key government facilities."
Despite the scope of the project, the military office initially charged with rebuilding Iraq did not learn of it until a major government drill for the postwar mission was held in Washington in late February, less than a month before the conflict began, said Ron Adams, the office's deputy director.
The man overseeing the planning, Tom Warrick, a State Department official, so impressed aides to Jay Garner, a retired Army lieutenant general heading the military's reconstruction office, that they recruited Mr. Warrick to join their team.
George Ward, an aide to General Garner, said the reconstruction office wanted to use Mr. Warrick's knowledge because "we had few experts on Iraq on the staff."
But top Pentagon officials blocked Mr. Warrick's appointment, and much of the project's work was shelved, State Department officials said. Mr. Warrick declined to be interviewed for this article.
The Defense Department, which had the lead role for planning postwar operations and reconstruction in Iraq, denied that it had shunned the State Department planning effort.
"It is flatly wrong to say this work was ignored," said the Pentagon spokesman Larry Di Rita. "It was good work. It was taken into account. It had some influence on people's thinking and it was a valuable contribution."
The broad outlines of the work, called the Future of Iraq Project, have been widely known, but new details emerged this week after the State Department sent Congress the project's 13 volumes of reports and supporting documents, which several House and Senate committees had requested weeks ago.
The documents are unclassified but labeled "official use only," and were not intended for public distribution, officials said. But Congressional officials from both parties allowed The New York Times to review the volumes, totaling more than 2,000 pages, revealing previously unknown details behind the planning.
Administration officials say there was postwar planning at several government agencies, but much of the work at any one agency was largely disconnected from that at others.
In the end, the American military and civilian officials who first entered Iraq prepared for several possible problems: numerous fires in the oil fields, a massive humanitarian crisis, widespread revenge attacks against former leaders of Mr. Hussein's government and threats from Iraq's neighbors. In fact, none of those problems occurred to any great degree.
Officials acknowledge that the United States was not well prepared for what did occur: chiefly widespread looting and related security threats, even though the State Department study predicted them.
Senior said the Pentagon squandered a chance to anticipate more of the postwar pitfalls by not fully incorporating the State Department information.
"Had we done more work and more of a commitment at the front end, there would be drastically different results now," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the senior Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee.
Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Feb. 11, Marc Grossman, the under secretary of state for political affairs, said the working groups were "not to have an academic discussion but to consider thoughts and plans for what can be done immediately."
But some senior Pentagon officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that while some of the project's work was well done, much of it was superficial and too academic to be practical.
"It was mostly ignored," said one senior defense official. "State has good ideas and a feel for the political landscape, but they're bad at implementing anything. Defense, on the other hand, is excellent at logistical stuff, but has blinders when it comes to policy. We needed to blend these two together."
A review of the work shows a wide range of quality and industriousness. For example, the transitional justice working group, made up of Iraqi judges, law professors and legal experts, has met four times and drafted more than 600 pages of proposed reforms in the Iraqi criminal code, civil code, nationality laws and military procedure. Other working groups, however, met only once and produced slim reports or none at all.
"There was a wealth of information in the working group if someone had just collated and used it," said Nasreen Barwari, who served on the economy working group and is now the Iraqi minister of public works. "What they did seems to have been a one-sided opinion."
Many of the working groups offered long-term recommendations as well as short-term fixes to potential problems.
The group studying defense policy and institutions expected problems if the Iraqi Army was disbanded quickly -- a step L. Paul Bremer III, the chief American civil administrator in Iraq, took. The working group recommended that jobs be found for demobilized troops to avoid having them turn against allied forces as some are believed to have done.
After special security organizations that ensured Mr. Hussein's grip on power were abolished, the working group recommended halving the 400,000-member military over time and reorganizing Iraqi special forces to become peacekeeping troops, as well as counterdrug and counterterrorism forces. Under the plan, military intelligence units would help American troops root out terrorists infiltrating postwar Iraq.
"The Iraqi armed forces and the army should be rebuilt according to the tenets and programs of democratic life," one working group member recommended.
The democratic principles working group wrestled with myriad complicated issues from reinvigorating a dormant political system to forming special tribunals for trying war criminals to laying out principles of a new Iraqi bill of rights.
It declared the thorny question of the relationship between that secular state and Islamic religion one "only the people of Iraq can decide," and avoided a recommendation on it.
Members of this working group were divided over whether to back a provisional government made up of Iraqi exiles or adopt the model that ultimately was adopted, the Iraqi Governing Council, made up of members from a broad range of ethnic and religious backgrounds. The group presented both options.
The transparency and anticorruption working group warned that "actions regarding anticorruption must start immediately; it cannot wait until the legal, legislative and executive systems are reformed."
The economy and infrastructure working group warned of the deep investments needed to repair Iraq's water, electrical and sewage systems. The free media working group noted the potential to use Iraq's television and radio capabilities to promote the goals of a post-Hussein Iraq, an aim many critics say the occupation has fumbled so far.
Encouraging Iraqis to emerge from three decades of dictatorship and embrace a vibrant civil society including labor unions, artist guilds and professional associations, could be more difficult than anticipated, the civil society capacity buildup working group cautioned: "The people's main concern has become basic survival and not building their civil society."
The groups' ideas may not have been fully incorporated before the war, but they are getting a closer look now. Many of the Iraqi ministers are graduates of the working groups, and have brought that experience with them. Since last spring, new arrivals to Mr. Bremer's staff in Baghdad have received a CD-ROM version of the State Department's 13-volume work. "It's our bible coming out here," said one senior official in Baghdad.

HEADLINE: Softer Rents, but the Hunt Is Still Hard 

BYLINE:  By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
ASKING rents in Manhattan have stopped falling but remain at least 10 percent below the levels of two years ago, brokers and building owners say. Yet when Jodie Welkes, a financial planner, returned to New York this summer, she found the search for an apartment a daunting and expensive experience.
 Before she was downsized out of a job in Chicago, she was paying $1,900 a month for a 950-square-foot apartment in a brand new high-rise with a panoramic view of the Chicago skyline and two walk-in closets. 
 Now back in New York, after a day of apartment hunting with a broker, David Weiss of Douglas Elliman, she found herself priced out of her dream apartment in the new high-rises that soar above Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea, the strongest of the new building markets, brokers say, and began looking elsewhere.
Finally, she found a one-bedroom apartment on the eighth floor of the Westport, a new 27-story building opened on Memorial Day weekend by the Related Companies on 10th Avenue and West 56th Street, in a largely commercial area with a small Housing Authority building next door, but a quick drive to the Lincoln Tunnel and her new job in New Jersey. 
The Westport has a grand lobby and all the latest amenities: granite counters, marble in the bathroom, a health club and valet service. But, she said, her new apartment is only 730 square feet, or 25 percent smaller than her last one, and has almost no closet space -- she would gladly trade in the stylish pedestal sink for an old-fashioned vanity with storage space below. 
The posted rent is $2,525 a month. After receiving two months of free rent to close the deal, she is paying $2,164, plus $275 for parking. As she sat with her puppy in her living room, on an overstuffed couch facing a large wall unit she brought with her from Chicago, both a bit too big for her New York space, she observed that despite her well paying job, she is spending half of her take home pay on her apartment, her garage space and utilities. "I have mainly lived in New York since I was 18 and haven't been able to save enough to buy," said Ms. Welkes, who is 31. "Rents have gone up faster than my income. I got the most I could for the money." 
Still, a typical one-bedroom in her neighborhood would have cost more than $2,800 at the market's peak, according to data from Halstead/Feathered Nest leasing consultants.
As the busiest rental season draws to a close, Ms. Welkes's experience at the Westport illustrates some of the changes and unchanging facts, in the market-rate rental market in Manhattan and beyond.
Although rents began declining in 2000, when the economic boom of the 1990's began to unravel, and were hurt again after the World Trade Center attack a year later, rentals have reached a bottom and are now stable or increasing, albeit significantly below levels where they were only a few years ago, , brokers and owner say. 
The downturn has affected market rents through much of the region, especially high-rises across the river in New Jersey that compete with the Manhattan rental market. But at the same time, one large developer of rental developments said that rents have continued rising in its Long island projects. 
There is no official data on changes in apartment rents in the prime Manhattan market. One broker survey, the Halstead/Feathered Nest survey, found that through the end of 2002, rents had declined 16 percent for studios and somewhat more for one and two bedrooms. Another survey by Citi Habitats showed prices stabilizing last winter. 
But beginning in the spring, owners of so-called luxury buildings, large towers with doormen and extensive services, say rents have rebounded somewhat and are now 10 percent below the peak. It is unclear, however, what will happen during the coming winter, a slow season for the rental market, brokers say.
Vacancies are up from the incredibly tight market a few years ago, when apartments were rented almost at soon as they went on the market, but only slightly, with a 95 percent occupancy rate reported in Manhattan by Halstead/Feathered Nest. The owners of several large groups of market-rate high-rises report occupancy rates of more 97 or 98 percent at the end of the summer. 
LARGE groups of new buildings, like the Westport, with new higher standards of amenities and kitchen and bathroom details, are reported to be renting extremely well in both long-established communities and many newer residential neighborhoods, like the financial district. At the Westport, crews were at work last week finishing up penthouse floor apartments, trying to keep pace with the brisk rental pace. 
"Everyone is surprised at how strong the market is," said David J. Wine, vice chairman of Related. "We purposely were very aggressive in terms of our pricing strategy, and we have definitely seen the reaction in the marketplace."
Most large building owners now routinely offer one month's free rent and build it into their price, because renters have come to expect it, and some offer up to three months. Most are willing to pay brokers fees, typically from 12 to 15 percent of one year's rent, which were routinely paid by tenants a few years ago. 
In Ms. Welkes's case, she got the standard one month free, plus a second month because her former employer was paying her broker's fees as part of her relocation costs, for a net rent of $2,164 a month for a 14-month lease, plus $275 a month for garage space downstairs. 
Although Ms. Welkes feels she has no choice but to pay more for rent than she would have liked, many building owners say they feel a similar loss of control in this softer market. The concessions are part of a nimbleness on the part of owners as they have learned to adapt to a weaker market. 
Giving a concession or lowering an asking rent is less costly than carrying a vacant apartment for several months. And building owners who understand the current market are usually willing to reduce renewal rents to match the market levels, rather than risk losing an existing tenant.
"We don't make the market; the market makes us," said Jack Levy, a senior managing director at Rose Associates.
Weaker demand for apartments and increasing supply have combined to weaken the Manhattan market. The economic slowdown, especially in the financial industry, has sharply curtailed the numbers hired from the class of 2003, making for fewer new New Yorkers scurrying to find a first apartment. In addition, the decline in interest rates has made owning more affordable, and many renters have decided to buy.
At the same time thousands of new apartments or office conversions planned before the economic downturn were coming to market, while a substantial number -- there is no agreement on how many -- of other apartments were freed from rent regulations during the same period.
But even when the market cools and rents drift downward, Manhattan remains at the vortex of a larger regional market and can pull in people who would rather live in Manhattan but were driven away to nearby boroughs or suburbs. 
"There is no vacancy rate in Manhattan; it is a function of price," said Nancy Packes, president of Halstead/Feathered Nest Leasing. "If vacancies are up, it means that the landlord's learning curve is a bit longer."
Ms. Packes is representing the Solaire, a new 27-story rental building in Battery Park City built by the Albanese Organization, which began renting on May 1. By the fall the building, still under construction, was more than 80 percent rented, and rents have been creeping upward, according to Chris Albanese, executive vice president of the developer.
"There is a tremendous pool of people who want to live here," said Charles Singer, director of market research for Rockrose Development, a major New York City developer and landlord. "When rents do drop, we attract a lot of people from the outer boroughs, New Jersey and a little bit of Westchester and Long Island."
Rockrose owns rental buildings in Battery Park City and the financial district and experienced a surge in rentals in the spring, when incentives of up to $500 a month offered to tenants in lower Manhattan were about to expire at the end of May. 
"The market stabilized, and by June the vacancy rates were low and the landlords didn't have to give as much away," Mr. Singer said.
George Hunt, a former anthropology professor, had a dream job, living on an island in Gulf of Mexico, near Tampa, Fla., with his wife and telecommuting and traveling around the country for a computer company, until that job disappeared in the economic downturn.
Like Ms. Welkes, he came to New York on the rebound, and now finds himself living most of the time in a studio in a Rockrose building at 45 Wall Street, a 28-story former office building that was put back on the rental market in February, after the city had dropped plans to demolish it to build new quarters for the New York Stock Exchange.
He got a job marketing computer management services to Wall Street firms, and in May with the help of a friend rented the studio, just down the street from the New York Stock Exchange, for $2,000 a month, less a $250 a month Lower Manhattan rent subsidy. His wife remains at their home in Florida, and they travel back and forth when they can.
Although apartments at 45 Wall were marketed mostly to young people starting out, Mr. Hunt is 58 years old and has two grown children and four grandchildren. He seems bemused to live in a building where most of his fellow tenants are law students, medical students or beginning executives.
"I have everything I need in this neighborhood," he said. "I want to focus on my work, have no distractions whatsoever. I get everything I need delivered to my door."
Matthew Fox, 22, a neighbor at 45 Wall Street, is in his first year, and second job, out of school. In his first job in Ohio, he commuted an hour a day from Cleveland, and it wore him out. Now he lives at 45 Wall Street and works as a trader at a hedge fund a few doors from home and plays poker regularly with some other new arrivals in the building.
OUTSIDE Manhattan, especially in the forest of high-rises across the river in New Jersey, market rate rentals are down, but are also showing signs of stabilizing.
Randy Lyn Ketive, a broker in Fort Lee and a principal in the Classic Realty Group, said that the rental market in newer market rate buildings had "gone down the drain" during the last year, as renters chose to buy condos instead, but lately shows signs of strengthening. 
"Rentals are starting to come back," she said. "They have gone down as much as they can go and are much more competitive with purchasing."
Financial filings by AvalonBay Communities, a national real estate investment trust that owns and develops rental developments in the New York region, illustrates the sagging demand seen by Ms. Ketive in Fort Lee as well as Jersey City to the south. 
At the end of 2002, filings showed an 83 percent occupancy rate at the 383-apartment Avalon Crest in Fort Lee, down from 92 percent a year earlier and 97 percent in 2000; and average rents were off nearly 6 percent from the previous year.
In its projects in northern New Jersey, it showed rents in the second quarter of this year off 12 percent from a year earlier. In southern Connecticut rents were down 5 percent, and in Westchester average rents were down 2.3 percent. But on Long Island, occupancy was high and rents were up nearly 2 percent. Fred Harris, vice president for development in AvalonBay's New York City office, said that the strength of the Long Island economy had helped buffer its projects there. The company's first New York City project, the 372-apartment Avalon Riverview, in Long Island City, Queens, a short subway ride from Manhattan, opened last year and is now at more than 92 percent occupancy, he said.
If you ask David Ayers, a member of the cast and a lead understudy in "Mamma Mia," how to get to Broadway, he will tell you, take the No. 7 subway, to Manhattan in 15 minutes.
A few weeks ago Mr. Ayers moved into a one-bedroom on the 20th floor of the Avalon Riverview with his girlfriend, Jessica-Snow Wilson, who is an understudy in "Little Shop of Horrors," for $2,350 a month for 13 months, less two free months.
They moved there after a search for a condominium on the Upper West Side and a tour of a small one-bedroom near Times Square renting for $3,500 a month. "It is amazing how much 300 grand won't buy you in Manhattan," Mr. Ayers said.
He said they paid a little extra for an apartment with stainless steel appliances and fancier wood cabinets and a view that extends from the Empire State Building to the 59th Street Bridge and across 42nd Street and on to New Jersey.
But other developers say it is difficult to attract renters willing to pay those high Manhattan rents in other boroughs. 
Linda G. Fine, the renting director for Hudson Park, a new building on West 96th Street near Riverside Park, said she learned a lesson about the rental market outside Manhattan last year, when she was marketing Newswalk, a condominium development in a former Daily News Plant in Prospect Heights in Brooklyn.
The developer, Boymelgreen Developers, wanted to rent out one floor of a brand new building, with units priced at $2,000 a month for 1,100 square feet. In a month, she could not close a single deal, but all the condominium units on the same floor then sold for $349,000 in three months.
At Hudson Park, she said, she has smaller units available but a waiting list for penthouse apartments and ground floor town houses with yards that are still under construction and renting for $6,500 and up.
Andrew Heiberger, president and chief executive of Citi Habitats, a brokerage, said that the reduction of crime in the city and improvements in the quality of life have reduced the significance of neighborhood boundaries. To many renters, he said, "Manhattan is one big neighborhood now."
And the barriers have come down as middle class renters have begun to explore neighborhoods in Harlem and Washington Heights. 
BUT this has not yet had an impact on David Waxenberg, a senior vice president at Norwax Associates, which owns 30 buildings and manages several hundred more, primarily in the Bronx. There is steady demand for his rent-regulated apartments, but with the economy weak, he has been unable to collect rent increases of up to 7.5 percent that were adopted to offset an 18 1/2 percent tax increase.
"It is not a problem renting apartments," he said. "The problem becomes collecting the increases we are entitled to when people have limited incomes and are only able to afford a certain amount of rent." 
While major landlords are closely attuned to the marketplace, this is not always the case with condo and co-op owners leasing out individual apartments. Brokers say they lose money while they learn.
John T. Lawrence, executive vice president and a sales manager at Bellmarc Realty, said an individual owner called recently wanting to list an apartment for $7,000. "I went into the building and saw there were three similar properties renting for $4,500," he said. 
Grant Silver, who works in the marketing department of The Golfer magazine, sublet a one-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue near 38th Street to cut down on the time and expense of his commute to Manhattan from Stamford, after he said he had spent two weeks "getting a feel" for the market.
The owner, he said, wanted $2,150, and he was able to bring the price down by $100. Then the broker reduced his fee from 15 percent to 12 percent, and his landlady agreed to pay half. The deal was done.
For Scott Corman, an investment banker, the weaker market was the ticket to a better apartment. He had lived in a small apartment in the Lucerne, a 44-story tower at First Avenue and 79th Street built by Glenwood Management, and loved the elegant lobby and generous layouts and high ceilings, and the pool.
When he needed a larger apartment, however, nothing was available, so he moved into another Glenwood building, the Marlowe at 81st and Lexington. But this summer, when he and family needed to upgrade, he was able to move back into the Lucerne. "I got more space for less than I would have paid before," he said.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
JOHNSON, GEORGE

 BODY:
 JOHNSON -- George. The Board of Directors, officers and employees of Mutual of America record with deep sorrow the passing of George E. Johnson. Mr. 
Johnson was a former acting president, member of the Board of Trustees, and a dear friend. In later years, he made his home in Tucson, AZ. For close to fifteen years, he shared with us his extensive knowledge of the insurance industry. Before joining Mutual of America, he served as Vice President and General Counsel of TIAA, as well as founder and president of both VALIC and EALIC. In 1961, Mr. Johnson wrote "Variable Annuities and Variable Life Insurance, Variable Pensions, Investment Annuities, Economic Index Annuities, Separate Accounts: The Most Complete Book Ever Written on Variable Annuities." At the time, it was the most comprehensive book written on this subject. In 1967, along with Donald S. Grubbs, Mr. Johnson wrote, "The Variable Annuity: A New and Exciting Financial Tool." Mr. Johnson was a member of the New York Bar Association, a Chartered Life Underwriter, a Fellow of the Life Office Management Association Institute, a Fellow of the Gerontological Society and a past member of the Life Insurance Council. George Johnson was a man of ideas. Through his work on the Long-Range Objectives Committee, he helped plan for the future needs of Mutual of America's clients. To him we owe a great debt of gratitude. His wife Elizabeth and son George E. Johnson, III, preceded him in death. We extend our sincere condolences to his children, Susan Hartdegan, and Robert A. Johnson. William J. Flynn, Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
The Nashers Keep It Close to Home

BYLINE:  By GRACE GLUECK

DATELINE: DALLAS 

 BODY:
FOR years, Dallas culturati waited for the shoe to drop. Would the Nasher collection, a peerless holding of modern and contemporary sculpture, go to the Tate in London? The National Gallery in Washington? The Guggenheim Museum in New York? These and other institutions had undisguised designs on the treasury of more than 300 works -- Rodins, Matisses, Picassos, Giacomettis, Miros, Moores, di Suveros and such -- assembled by the Dallas real estate entrepreneur Raymond D. Nasher and his wife, Patsy.
 But to the relief of home fans, Mr. Nasher, having thoroughly enjoyed the wooing, rejected the suitors. The collection is now rooted here, robustly in control of -- ta da! -- Mr. Nasher and his family. Tomorrow, the $70 million Nasher Sculpture Center, a smashing combination of indoor museum and outdoor environment built and owned by the Nasher Foundation, opens to the public on a 2.4-acre downtown plot, making Dallas a premier destination for the viewing of modern and contemporary sculpture. 
 "Dallas is the community where I have spent most of my adult life and where my children and grandchildren were born," said Mr. Nasher, who was born in Boston. It is also where he made his pile, as a builder of low-cost housing, office complexes and a high-end shopping mall, NorthPark Center. 
Laura Miller, mayor of Dallas, is one of the many who view the Sculpture Center as cause for celebration. "When people come to Dallas, it's the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth that's usually on their radar screens," she said. "This will be our counterpart to the Kimbell."
The center is also seen as a giant step forward for the laggard Dallas Arts District, which was designated in 1983 but until now has had only two major components: the Dallas Museum of Art and the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Hall. (Money is being raised, however, for a $250 million performing arts complex to be designed by Rem Koolhaas and Foster & Partners.)
In Dallas, there has been some grumbling about the Nashers wanting to turn the Sculpture Center into a family monument. The foundation's board, however, was recently expanded to include nonfamily members. And Mr. Nasher, a perfectionist who meticulously monitors every aspect of his projects, recently said that public organizations involve "too many committees." 
In the 1980's, the Dallas Museum of Art built a sculpture garden -- still largely empty -- in hopes of winning the Nasher collection. Though that didn't happen, John Lane, the museum's current director, seems pleased with how things have worked out. "What the Nashers are doing is so grand," he said, "that who cares who owns it?" The imposing Dallas Museum, now celebrating its centennial, is refurbishing a largely ceremonial entrance to create more rapport with the Sculpture Center, which sits directly across Flora Street.
Designed by Renzo Piano, the Italian architect, the Sculpture Center's 55,000-square-foot building opens on an even larger outdoor garden, planned by the landscape architect Peter Walker. 
Mr. Piano's building, between the symphony center and the art museum, is an essay in transparency: five subtly barrel-vaulted bays of travertine, with front and back exterior walls of clear glass, provide a continuous view from the street to the end of the garden. The effect is enhanced by the delicate glass curves of the roof, braced by steel struts. Above them, a graceful sunscreen device of sculptured aluminum blocks out direct sun, allowing in only a soft, even north light.
At the encouragement of the oldest of his three daughters, Andrea, Mr. Nasher had challenged Mr. Piano to develop a roof that let in more light than the flat, opaque one originally planned. "We wanted transparency above as well as below, so you could see the sky and the clouds," said Ms. Nasher, who has been closely involved with the center since its inception five years ago. 
Downstairs a large gallery is provided for light-sensitive works like drawings, as well as an indoor-outdoor auditorium, research and educational facilities and a conservation lab. A loading dock that is actually a giant elevator will carry trucks down from the street. 
The Walker garden was originally designed as a romantic setting of curves and hillocks, but it seemed to separate itself from the architecture. Again with the prompting of the Nashers, Mr. Piano took a hand in replanning to make it more flexible and contemporary. Now it functions as a continuum of the pavilion, with long allees of trees that extend the building lines. A folksy feature is the terrace garden, a flight of grass-covered steps where people can sit or sprawl, that leads to the downstairs auditorium. 
"It was a challenge to create a park that is luscious and green and yet has the spaciousness to absorb lots of sculpture," said Steven A. Nash, the center's director and a longtime adviser to Mr. Nasher. Cedar elms, crepe myrtles, live oaks, Afghan pine, weeping willows and bamboo create outdoor "rooms" for intimate viewing. Ms. Nasher selected some of them herself, working from a helicopter with the help of a professional tree spotter. 
Arrayed in the garden are some 25 larger works, among them "My Curves Are Not Mad," Richard Serra's 100,000-ton, walk-through of two 40-foot-long curved steel plates; Mark di Suvero's "Eviva Amore (Long Live Love)," a 35-foot three-legged tangle of I-beams bolted to a circular joint of welded steel plates; Jonathan Borofsky's 20-foot high motor-driven figure, "Hammering Man"; Jean Dubuffet's "Gossiper II"; Rodin's "Eve"; Joan Miro's playfully erotic "Moon Bird"; and Picasso's "Head of a Woman."
A dark, mysterious cube of black granite at the bottom of the garden was commissioned from the light artist James Turrell. Titled "Tending, (Blue)," it is open to the sky, and the subtly changing light in its cavelike interior influences what's seen above.
Inside the Piano pavilion are some 50 pieces, by Matisse, Picasso, Giacometti, Medardo Rosso and Max Ernst, among others. The center plans to mount shows from other sources, including a James Turrell exhibition with the Houston Museum of Fine Arts. Other works will be rotated among the Sculpture Center, NorthPark and the Nasher's elegant sculpture-filled home in Dallas's Preston Hollow enclave. Like the museum, the glass-and-brick house forms a continuum with its grounds, creating a flow between indoors and out.
A T the house, designed in 1949 by Howard Meyer, a Texas disciple of Frank Lloyd Wright, Mr. Nasher, an affable, laid-back guide, proudly showed visitors his Giacometti room, starring three rare painted bronze busts of Diego, the artist's brother. Mr. Nasher admires their combination of modeling and painting. "It helps that we knew Diego well," he said.
The room contains masterpieces like "Spoon Woman," influenced by African sculpture, and "No More Play," a Surrealist game board of marble pocked with circular depressions and three cryptlike trenches. As counterpoint, Mr. Nasher has included Rodin's life-size figure of a youth, "The Age of Bronze." 
"I like the idea of putting Rodin, coming from Michelangelo's theories, together with Giacometti," he said. "It makes a nice transition from the figurative, muscular tradition since the Renaissance to the modern quirkiness of Giacometti, with his skinny bodies, huge feet and small heads." 
Mr. Nasher, who graduated from Duke University in 1943 and holds a master's degree in economics from Boston University, and his wife, a graduate of Smith College who died in 1988, began collecting in the early 1950's. The stimulus was pre-Columbian artworks they saw at archaeological digs on their vacations in Mexico. A later collection of Guatemalan textiles, assembled by Mrs. Nasher, who contributed a formidable eye and a gift for scholarly investigation to the couple's pursuits, now reposes in the Dallas Museum. 
The Nashers bought paintings, too, beginning with a Ben Shahn oil of a tennis match that reflected Mr. Nasher's passion for the game. They soon got into artists of more gravitas, like Picasso, Leger, Hans Hofmann, de Kooning and Stuart Davis. Their first major sculptural acquisition was Arp's graceful"Torso With Buds" (1961), a birthday gift from Patsy to Ray. (It now stands in the vestibule of the house.)
"Paintings are great, but sculpture changes with every glance," said Mr. Nasher, who credits his feel for the three-dimensional qualities of sculpture partly to his experience as a developer and builder. "A great piece of sculpture is totally different from different angles. Walk around it and you get 360 separate views."
As Mr. Nasher's business bloomed and his shopping center -- designed by Eero Saarinen and Kevin Roche -- evolved, he looked for large works that could be placed around the mall. "More people will see art at the shopping center in a month than they will at the city's museums," he said. "Unfortunate but true."
There was also a practical side. "In real estate development the outdoor pieces had to be sculpture, weatherwise and sizewise," he said. "Also, almost into the 90's, sculpture cost about one-tenth or one-twentieth of the price of paintings by the same artist." 
He finds the stuff of sculpture intriguing and points out that 39 different materials are represented in his collection. He particularly likes plaster casts, the version made before a work is cast in bronze, "because you can see the hands of the sculptor in them."
Recently he acquired a number of heads by Medardo Rosso, the late-19th- and early-20th-century Italian sculptor whose impressionistic creations were often left in wax. The Sculpture Center will present a Rosso show, organized by the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University, early next year.
"We always bought things that gave us butterflies in the stomach," Mr. Nasher said. And unlike many collectors who aim for one of everything, he said, "if we got to like an artist, we always looked for additional pieces." That translated into 13 works by Giacometti, 11 by Matisse ( among the largest such private holdings in the world), 8 by David Smith, 8 by Moore, 7 by Picasso, 7 by Raymond Duchamp-Villon and 4 by Miro. 
A "breakthrough" came in 1968 with the purchase of two Henry Moores. "We went to Much Haddam, Moore's home -- we used to go to Wimbledon every year for the matches; he loved tennis, too -- and watched him make 'Two Piece Reclining Figure No. 9.' He also showed us three stones that would become 'Three Piece No. 3: Vertebrae.' Patsy liked 'Reclining Figure' and I liked 'Vertebrae,' so we wound up with both."
Another "butterfly" acquisition was Matisse's "Large Seated Nude," owned by the dealer Heinz Berggruen. "He brought it to his suite at the Carlyle in New York and gave us one day to decide," Mr. Nasher said. "It was the first time we'd gone into seven figures." In 2001, Mr. Nasher purchased his 11th Matisse, "The Serf," one of only two male figures by the artist, at auction for $3.1 million.
Mrs. Nasher would undoubtedly approve of her husband's move in a more contemporary direction. Since her death he has acquired works by, among others, Carl Andre, Tony Cragg, Jeff Koons, Antony Gormley and Richard Long.
Mr. Nasher's role at NorthPark, opened in 1965 and still regarded as an art and architectural showplace, is as hands-on as it is at the Sculpture Center. The long, low flow of white buildings (Mr. Nasher points out that most of the world's great buildings have been white, like the Taj Mahal and the White House), set on a onetime cotton field, is about to expand. Attractively landscaped by the San Francisco designer Lawrence Halprin, it shelters more than 120 stores, from Neiman Marcus and Tiffany to Anthropology, a youth-oriented apparel shop. 
"What I tried to do was democratize retailing, so that every store, from high to lowest income, got the same exterior and interior materials," Mr. Nasher said. "We felt the art we put in would become a permanent type of happening that people would see, enjoy, learn from and maybe come back to."
Among the first works installed was a 200-foot-long site-specific piece in Cor-Ten steel by Beverly Pepper. Works by Moore, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and Joel Shapiro followed. 
Mr. Nasher is also the prime patron of a new Nasher Museum of Art at Duke, to which he contributed $10 million of a projected $23 million construction cost. Designed by another hot architect, Rafael Vinoly, a runner-up in the competition to rebuild the World Trade Center site, it will open in 2005. Mr. Nasher, of course, is closely involved in this one, too, with the help of another daughter, Nancy, a lawyer who with her husband, David Haemisegger, now owns and runs NorthPark.
"Two museums is too much," Mr. Nasher sighed. But somehow you don't quite believe him.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
German Olympic Bid Has Sour Note

BYLINE:  By DESMOND BUTLER

DATELINE: ROSTOCK, Germany, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
When Mayor Wolfgang Tiefensee of Leipzig picked up a cello and played "Dona Nobis Pacem" after the announcement earlier this year that Leipzig and Rostock would be candidates for Germany's 2012 Olympic bid, the meaning for eastern Germany was palpable.
 Tiefensee, 48, made his name in East Germany during the 1989 "peaceful revolution," when he and other dissidents against communism gathered at St. Nikolai Church in Leipzig for prayer vigils and "Dona Nobis Pacem" became their anthem for change. 
 By choosing Leipzig and Rostock, two cities of the former East Germany, the German Olympic Committee hoped to play on the potent imagery of German reunification and send the message that the east had long since left behind the legacy of its Communist-controlled sporting machine, which evokes memories of an extensive doping program if also great Olympic success. 
"It was a starting point in changing the political way of the world," Tiefensee said of the 1989 revolution in a radio interview last month. "And this is something we can link with the Olympic Games." 
But in recent days, Germany's pitch to beat out New York, Paris, Moscow, Istanbul, Havana, London, Madrid and Rio de Janeiro has been complicated by disclosures that top officials from Rostock and Leipzig had worked for the East German secret police, the Stasi, before the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Last week, the head of Leipzig's Olympic bid committee, Dirk Tharichen, and the chairman of Rostock's public run Olympic marketing committee, Harald Lochotzke, stepped down from their positions after the German news media published details about their Stasi connections. On Saturday, the committee's supervisory board officially dismissed Tharichen.
After reunification, Germany established a government authority to maintain and organize the Stasi files recovered after the collapse of the East German state. Under certain strict conditions, the files on individuals may be requested and released. Stasi connections are still a hot-button issue in Germany, and in many professions those who worked for the Stasi or as informers may be barred from employment.
The disclosures have soured an already uphill German bid, submitted to the International Olympic Committee, which is still sensitive to charges of corruption in the bid process after the scandal that emerged from the selection of Salt Lake City to play host to the 2002 Games.
"It was a moving moment when Leipzig and Rostock won," said a Rostock City Council member, Sybille Bachmann. "Tiefensee's message was 'We are the people that brought change to East Germany,' but then it turns out that some of the same old people they were fighting are involved in the application."
Tharichen resigned after the German daily Die Welt revealed that as a 19-year-old, he had served briefly for the Stasi's Feliks Dzerzhinsky guard unit, named after the founder of the K.G.B.
On Monday, the German weekly Der Spiegel detailed Lochotzke's more extensive period of collaboration with the Stasi and also reported on suggestions of questionable business dealings in Rostock in the years immediately after the fall of the wall.
Stasi files obtained by a journalist working for Der Spiegel who applied for them some months ago detail Lochotzke's collaboration from 1986 until 1989 under the code name Kay Birkhoff. They state that Lochotzke reported informally to a Stasi economic unit run by Alexander Schalk-Golodkowski, chief acquisitor of foreign currency for East Germany, and was working to find ways of evading Western sanctions in order to import computers.
The position helped earn him the right denied to most citizens to travel in the West. The files also detail stipends and gifts awarded to him by the Stasi.
In defending himself, Lochotzke said he had never informed on others, but a number of the files indicate otherwise. One positive job evaluation noted that Birkhoff had "described and incriminated people with specific details, including close relatives," apparently his in-laws.
Only months after the collapse of East Germany, Lochotzke said he was the head of a company, Alpha Consulting, that was representing an international consortium that wished to invest 1 billion marks (about $500 million) in Rostock. According to city documents, his proposal included a letter detailing an advisory meeting with Karl Otto Pohl, then the central bank president, and others who had recommended the deal.
Some months later, when the new city government asked a lawyer, the former Hamburg mayor Peter Schulz, to review the deal, he shot it down. 
"It was immediately apparent that there was a swindle in the works," he said in an interview in Hamburg. According to Schulz, Lochotzke later admitted to him that he had not met with Pohl.
Schulz also noted that the telephone number listed for Alpha Consulting rang through to the Hotel Neptun, Lochotzke's former workplace, which also served as Schalk-Golodkowski's headquarters in Rostock. 
The disclosure led some in the German news media to ask whether Lochotzke was trying to launder Stasi money. Lochotzke, who is traveling abroad, has denied the suggestions and did not return calls made to his office.
In Rostock, which has been nominated to play host to the Olympic sailing events, the mayor's office responsible for the bid has distanced itself from Lochotzke, but local politicians and the German news media are asking why no one questioned Lochotzke before he took over the committee, especially given the marketing themes of the bid. 
"It is not a government position and I did not think it relevant to ask about Mr. Lochotzke's past," Mayor Arno Poker said.
Had the local authorities looked closer, they might have raised deeper questions about Lochotzke's political judgment. One of his last reports delivered to his handlers on Oct. 5, 1989, only days before the Berlin Wall was breached and neighbors were bolting for Czechoslovakia, was titled, "Information, Mood and Reaction of the Population," and began with the observation, "The politics of our party and government has been successful, but nonetheless needs some newer elements."
