HEADLINE: It Swallowed a Civilization 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
For decades, scholars have debated whether the eruption of the Thera volcano in the Aegean more than 3,000 years ago brought about the mysterious collapse of Minoan civilization at the peak of its glory. The volcanic isle (whose remnants are known as Santorini) lay just 70 miles from Minoan Crete, so it seemed quite reasonable that its fury could have accounted for the fall of that celebrated people.
 This idea suffered a blow in 1987 when Danish scientists studying cores from the Greenland icecap reported evidence that Thera exploded in 1645 B.C., some 150 years before the usual date. That put so much time between the natural disaster and the Minoan decline that the linkage came to be widely doubted, seeming far-fetched at best. 
 Now, scientists at Columbia University, the University of Hawaii and other institutions are renewing the proposed connection. 
New findings, they say, show that Thera's upheaval was far more violent than previously calculated -- many times larger than the 1883 Krakatoa eruption, which killed more than 36,000 people. They say the Thera blast's cultural repercussions were equally large, rippling across the eastern Mediterranean for decades, even centuries.
"It had to have had a huge impact," said Dr. Floyd W. McCoy, a University of Hawaii geologist who has studied the eruption for decades and recently proposed that it was much more violent than previously thought.
The scientists say Thera's outburst produced deadly waves and dense clouds of volcanic ash over a vast region, crippling ancient cities and fleets, setting off climate changes, ruining crops and sowing wide political unrest.
For Minoan Crete, the scientists see direct and indirect consequences. Dr. McCoy discovered that towering waves from the eruption that hit Crete were up to 50 feet high, smashing ports and fleets and severely damaging the maritime economy.
Other scientists found indirect, long-term damage. Ash and global cooling from the volcanic pall caused wide crop failures in the eastern Mediterranean, they said, and the agricultural woes in turn set off political upheavals that undid Minoan friends and trade.
"Imagine island states without links to the outside world," Dr. William B. F. Ryan, a geologist at Columbia's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, told a meeting of the American Geophysical Union.
Scientists who link Thera to the Minoan decline say the evidence is still emerging and in some cases sketchy. Even so, they say it is already compelling enough to have convinced many archaeologists, geologists and historians that the repercussions probably amounted to a death blow for Minoan Crete.
Rich and sensual, sophisticated and artistic, Minoan culture flourished in the Bronze Age between roughly 3000 and 1400 B.C., the first high civilization of Europe. It developed an early form of writing and used maritime skill to found colonies and a trade empire.
The British archaeologist Sir Arthur Evans called the civilization Minoan, after Minos, the legendary king. His unearthed palace was huge and intricate, and had clearly been weakened by many upheavals, including fire and earthquakes.
Nearby on the volcanic island of Thera, or Santorini, archaeologists dug up Minoan buildings, artifacts and a whole city, Akrotiri, buried under volcanic ash like Pompeii. Some of its beautifully preserved frescoes depicted Egyptian motifs and animals, suggesting significant contact between the two peoples.
In 1939, Spyridon Marinatos, a Greek archaeologist, proposed that the eruption wrecked Minoan culture on Thera and Crete. He envisioned the damage as done by associated earthquakes and tsunamis. While geologists found tsunamis credible, they doubted the destructive power of Thera's earthquakes, saying volcanic ones tend to be relatively mild. The debate simmered for decades.
In the mid-1960's, scientists dredging up ooze from the bottom of the Mediterranean began to notice a thick layer of ash that they linked to Thera's eruption. They tracked it over thousands of square miles.
Dr. McCoy of the University of Hawaii, then at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute on Cape Cod, took part in these discoveries, starting a lifelong interest in Thera. By the early 1980's, he was publishing papers on the ash distribution.
Such clues helped geologists estimate the amount of material Thera spewed into the sky and the height of its eruption cloud -- main factors in the Volcanic Explosivity Index. Its scale goes from zero to eight and is logarithmic, so each unit represents a tenfold increase in explosive power. Thera was given a V.E.I. of 6.0, on a par with Krakatoa in 1883.
The similarity to Krakatoa, which lies between Sumatra and Java, helped experts better envision Thera's wrath. Krakatoa hurled rock and ash more than 20 miles high and its blasts could be heard 3,000 miles away. Its giant waves killed thousands of people.
Despite the power of Thera, the Danish scientists' evidence raised doubts about its links to the Minoan decline. Their date for Thera's explosion, 1645 B.C., based on frozen ash in Greenland, is some 150 years earlier than the usual date. Given that the Minoan fall was usually dated to 1450 B.C., the gap between cause and effect seemed too large.
Another blow landed in 1989 when scholars on Crete found, above a Thera ash layer, a house that had been substantially rebuilt in the Minoan style. It suggested at least partial cultural survival.
By 1996, experts like Prof. Jeremy B. Rutter, head of classics at Dartmouth, judged the chronological gap too extreme for any linkage. "No direct correlation can be established" between the volcano and the Minoan decline, he concluded.
As doubts rose about this linkage, scientists found more evidence suggesting that Thera's eruption had been unusually violent and disruptive over wide areas. Scientific maps drawn in the 1960's and 1970's showed its ash as falling mostly over nearby waters and Aegean islands.
By the 1990's, however, the affected areas had been found to include lands of the eastern Mediterranean from Anatolia to Egypt. Scientists found ash from Thera at the bottom of the Black Sea and Nile delta.
Dr. Peter I. Kuniholm, an expert at Cornell on using tree rings to establish dates, found ancient trees in a burial mound in Anatolia, what now is in the Asian part of Turkey. For half a decade those trees had grown three times as fast as normal -- apparently because Thera's volcanic pall turned hot, dry summers into seasons that were unusually cool and wet.
"We've got an anomaly, the biggest in the past 9,000 years," Dr. Kuniholm said in an interview.
More intrigued than ever, Dr. McCoy of the University of Hawaii two years ago stumbled on more evidence suggesting that Thera'sash fall had been unusually wide and heavy. During a field trip to Anafi, an island some 20 miles east of Thera, he found to his delight that the authorities had just cut fresh roads that exposed layers of Thera ash up to 10 feet thick -- a surprising amount that distance from the eruption.
And Greek colleagues showed him new seabed samples taken off the Greek mainland, suggesting that more ash blew westward than scientists had realized.
Factoring in such evidence, Dr. McCoy calculated that Thera had a V.E.I. of 7.0 -- what geologists call colossal and exceedingly rare. In the past 10,000 years only one other volcano has exploded with that kind of gargantuan violence: Tambora, in Indonesia, in 1816, It produced an ash cloud in the upper atmosphere that reflected sunlight back into space and produced the year without a summer. The cold led to ruinous harvests, hunger and even famine in the United States, Europe and Russia.
"I presented this evidence last summer at a meeting," Dr. McCoy recalled, "and the comment from the other volcanologists was, 'Hey, it was probably larger than Tambora.' "
Dr. Ryan of Columbia has woven such clues into a tantalizing but provisional theory on how distant effects might have slowly undone Crete. First, he noted that winds at low and high altitudes seem to have blown Thera's ash into distinct plumes -- one to the southeast, toward Egypt and another heavier one to the northeast, toward Anatolia. Even if the changes wrought by Thera helped trees there, they apparently played havoc with delicate wheat fields.
Mursilis, a king of the Hittites, set out from Anatolia on a rampage, traveling between the plumes to strike Syria and Babylon and seize their stored grains and cereals. The subsequent collapse of Babylon into a dark age, Dr. Ryan said, also undid one of its puppets, the Hyksos, foreigners who ruled Egypt and traded with the Minoans.
He theorized that the new Egyptian dynasty had no love of Hyksos allies. So Minoan Crete, already reeling from Thera's fury, suffered new blows to its maritime trade.
In an interview, Dr. Ryan said he and other scholars were still refining dates on some of the ancient events, promising to better fix their relation to the eruption. The outcome of that work, he said, could either strengthen or undermine his thesis.
Even without such distant upsets, some prominent archaeologists have concluded that the volcano's long-term repercussions meant the end of Minoan Crete. For instance, they argue that the revolt of nature over the predictable certainties of Minoan religion probably crippled the authority of the priestly ruling class, weakening its hold on society.
In scholarly articles, Dr. Jan Driessen, an archaeologist at the Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium, and Dr. Colin F. MacDonald, an archaeologist at the British School in Athens, have argued that changes to Cretan architecture, storage, food production, artistic output and the distribution of riches imply major social dislocations, and perhaps civil war.
By 1450 B.C., Mycenaean invaders from mainland Greece seized control of Crete, ending the Minoan era.
Thera's destructiveness was probably the catalyst, Dr. Driessen and Dr. MacDonald wrote, "that culminated in Crete being absorbed to a greater or lesser extent into the Mycenaean, and therefore, the Greek world."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA/MOTOR CITY; 
Almost as Many Vehicles as People, and Every One Says, 'Me!'

BYLINE:  By BRIAN ALEXANDER

 BODY:
CALIFORNIANS feel differently about cars than the rest of America. "In other states," said Lonnie Miller, the director of analytical solutions at R. L. Polk & Company, an auto consultancy, "you do not see or hear, 'I want it to say something about me.' "
 Yet Californians are probably the most influential auto consumers in the world. 
 Their sway is partly related to the fact that the state is the biggest market in the United States. With about 35 million people, the numbers are bound to be daunting. As of Dec. 31, 2002, there were 22,605,810 licensed drivers in the state and 20,665,415 registered autos. Just about every licensed driver owns a car. Throw in commercial trucks, trailers and motorcycles, and you get 30,875,086 registered vehicles. 
Last year, California auto dealers reaped $83.4 billion in total sales, easily the highest nationwide and more than the annual government expenditures for most countries, as well as almost 14 times the annual gross domestic product of Afghanistan. 
With such economic clout, automakers must cater to Californians. But that is not easy given that the second reason California is so influential is that it is unpredictable.
What, for example, is an auto executive to make of the fact that Californians bought more Hummer H2's from January to July -- 3,048 according to Polk's numbers -- than any other state, yet drivers have also bought so many gas-electric hybrids that Detroit has been forced to play catch-up with the Japanese? 
On one hand, the Hummer sales say Californians are rich and therefore entitled to two parking spaces, but the new hybrids say the state is full of environmental advocates. 
Both pictures are true. California is a big, diverse state, and carmakers can count on one truism: that it is made up of free thinkers who chafe at dictates from the outside world, including Detroit.
Even in the age of the Duesenbergs, California body shops replaced the bodies with ones of their own. In the postwar hot rod era, California design ideas from the likes of Edward Roth, better known as Big Daddy, turned Detroit's cars upside down. 
So in 1958, when Datsun (now Nissan) began exporting cars to the United States, Californians fell in love with them because the Japanese understood the state and its iconoclastic culture. "They picked up the California market the quickest," said Art Spinella, the director of CNW Marketing Research, in Bandon, Ore. At the time, Detroit was dictating fins. The first thing California hot rod designers did was slice off the fins.
The Japanese, Mr. Spinella said, "designed simple, almost elegant small cars."
"They got rid of the geegaws," he said. "The original Corolla, for example, was a clean design because they were paying attention to California." 
Japanese cars are now part of the national landscape, but California hugged them first and still loves them more than the rest of the country. According to the research firm J. D. Power & Associates, the three most popular models in the state are the Honda Accord, the Toyota Camry and the Honda Civic. The three most popular models for the rest of the country are the Ford F-150 pickup truck, the Honda Accord and the Ford Explorer.
Power's numbers also show that the state has adopted European models. BMW and Mercedes-Benz both appear in the Top 10, but not on the 10 favorite nameplates of the other 49 states. 
But just when you think it is possible to make more generalizations about Californians and cars, consider that the state's industries include farming and ranching, thus the need to buy many trucks. The fourth best-selling model in Northern California is the enormous Chevy Silverado 1500. The fourth favorite in the southern half is the Ford F-150. 
The state is also fickle. "Californians are not patient," Mr. Spinella said. "We find in our surveys that there's a lot more complaining about satisfaction scores in the Northeast, but they'll go back and buy again. Californians for the most part don't complain; they simply won't go back. They will not be loyal." 
Because of that contrariness, California is an ideal proving ground for new models. Last June, Toyota introduced the Scion at 105 California dealerships. The model looks something like a shoe box on roller skates, and is meant to be customized. If it takes off, it will be distributed everywhere. 
Indeed, the Scion "was created to suit the demands of an emerging culture of new-car buyers known as Gen Y," according to a statement on the Toyota Web site. Sociological labels aside, Toyota is once again tapping into California's individualist culture.
Every carmaker that exports to the United States has caught on to the idea that a design democracy, or making one's own rules and filtering ideas from the bottom rather than from the top, is here to stay. Miami is often cited as another trend-setting spot, but the design democracy mind-set has reached full power on the West Coast. 
That is why car design studios are staffed with video-game veterans and designers from the movies, the technology world and, of course, cars. Alfonso E. Albaisa, the interim director for design at Nissan Design America in San Diego, has the task of making sense of California's chaotic milieu. He does it by paying attention to cues that seem to have little to do with cars: radical Japanese motorcycles, fashion, sports and architecture. "We have 70 people working here and 40 motorcycles in the parking lot," Mr. Albaisa said. "There are so many hobbies. And we have designers from all over the planet."
Such scavenging for inspiration has fostered the California car culture over the last 50 years. Today, though, that culture may be more aspiration than realization. 
Californians do not cruise much anymore, nor do they hang out at drive-ins, and parking is generally not allowed on the beaches. Still, the car culture persists because drivers continue to spend a lot of time sitting on freeway on-ramps, imagining they could be doing these things instead of waiting for the two-cars-per-green-light-meter light to join the herd on Interstate 5.

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA/MOTOR CITY; 
Pollution Fight Turns From Smog to Global Warming

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO 

 BODY:
THE next big regulatory battle between California and the auto industry will be over global warming. 
 For years, the Golden State has been aggressive on something quite different -- the smog-forming pollutants emanating from tailpipes -- because of the gray haze that settles over its cities. This year, the industry and California's powerful Air Resources Board called a truce on the issue after General Motors and Chrysler dropped a suit against the state's Zero Emission Vehicle mandate. Overall, considerable progress has been made in curbing smog since the 1970's, though this year the state suffered some of its worst pollution problems in more than a half-decade. 
 But as one struggle ends for now, another is beginning over a different tailpipe emission, carbon dioxide and other gases, like methane, that many scientists think are contributing to global climate change trends. The issue remains debatable in the scientific community and in Detroit, where global warming is often viewed skeptically. 
The opening salvo came last year, when Gov. Gray Davis of California signed into law the nation's first piece of legislation aimed at curbing automotive emissions of greenhouse gases. The legislation itself is vague and leaves it to the Air Resources Board, a branch of the California Environmental Protection Agency, to work out the details over the next year.
Automakers are widely expected to sue the state over the measure, but until the specifics of the plan are laid out there is little basis for a court challenge. Battle lines are already coalescing, though, with state regulators and environmentalists on one side and automakers from Detroit to Tokyo, as well as the White House, on the other. 
The Bush administration prefers voluntary action by industries over regulation and withdrew the United States from an international treaty, known as the Kyoto Protocol, to curb greenhouse emissions.
"When it comes to climate change, California is aligning itself with the rest of the world," Alan C. Lloyd, the chairman of the state air board, said in an interview in late September, adding, "Somewhere along the line, we would expect a lawsuit."
"My hope is that somehow we could work with the industry and say: 'Look, it's only a matter of time before these things are addressed. Voluntary agreements will work for a while maybe but you have an opportunity here to help us craft the regulation.' "
But he said all the major automakers had indicated resistance to the measure, including Honda, which has not taken part in industry lobbying campaigns against environmental legislation in the past. 
"Many of them are talking to us on a technical basis," Dr. Lloyd said, "but they draw the line there, typically, and say, 'We don't think having a state set tailpipe standards for greenhouse gases is the way to go.' "
Since Dr. Lloyd was appointed by Mr. Davis, who has been recalled from office, he could be out of a job when Arnold Schwarzenegger becomes governor. The new administration will mostly draft the regulation. That has aroused concern among environmentalists. Mr. Schwarzenegger has long been a booster of the gas-guzzling Hummer, the S.U.V. that groups like the Sierra Club love to hate. On one campaign stop, he made an offhand remark suggesting that the state should abolish its E.P.A.
Mr. Schwarzenegger's advisers later clarified the remark and said he supported the E.P.A. He has also tried to create a green image; among the positions laid out on his campaign Web site, at www. joinarnold.com, he said he supported the greenhouse gas legislation and would "work to implement it and to win the expected challenges in court along the way." He said he also wanted to make one of his Hummers more environmentally friendly. 
But the new Republican governor also inherits a battle with the Bush administration because of the state's greenhouse gas plan.
In August, the federal Environmental Protection Agency said it lacked the authority to regulate greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act, reversing the stance of the Clinton administration. 
Earlier this month, Governor Davis's administration said it would sue the E.P.A. over the issue before he leaves office. 
"It's apparent that California is reading the Clean Air Act one way, and the E.P.A. is reading it another way," said Mark Merchant, an E.P.A. spokesman. "There's a difference of opinion there, and California has decided to ask the court to make a decision."
While the suit is partly aimed at prodding federal action on global warming, it is also viewed in California as an effort to counter what could be a potent legal argument against the state's plan to curb auto emissions: if the E.P.A. says it does not have the authority under the Clean Air Act to regulate greenhouse gases, why does California have the authority on air issues granted by the same legislation?
Many legal experts on both sides believe that winning the suit against the E. P. A. will be crucial for the greenhouse gas law to stand up to a legal challenge and actually take effect, though California regulators do not concede the point. 
"Whatever California does on CO2 emissions would face a double-pronged challenge," said Sam Kazman, general counsel for the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group that receives industry financing. 
The first prong, he said, would be an argument based on the Clean Air Act authority. The second, he said, would be similar to one that automakers have used against the Zero Emission Vehicle mandate -- that emissions rules are superseded by federal authority to set fuel economy regulations. The argument could be stronger in this case because global warming is tied directly to fuel consumption. While smog-forming pollutants can be filtered by devices like catalytic converters, no such filter exists for carbon dioxide.
Dr. Lloyd believes the state's law will hold up, but added that "we think very strongly if we lose in the legal arena we're going to win in the court of public opinion," thus pressuring automakers to take action nonetheless. 
Certainly, the Air Resources Board is watched closely in automaking capitals from Stuttgart to Tokyo to Detroit -- because California is the world's eighth-largest auto market and because other states are allowed to choose its tougher air regulations over Washington's. 
In an interview last year, Nissan's chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, described the moment his staff told him the company would have to start producing expensive low- and zero-emission vehicles if an earlier and more demanding version of the state's final Zero Emission Mandate took effect. 
"I remember I had a meeting in Tokyo where they showed me all the cost of this stuff," Mr. Ghosn said. "I said, 'Oh my God, the others have to do this too?' Nobody believes in it, but you have to do it. It's a huge cost, but it's part of the cost of doing business."

HEADLINE: BUYING AND SELLING; 
In the Land of Never-Ending Rebates, a Guide to Value

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS

 BODY:
IF it seems as if there is a sale on cars and trucks every day, there is. Cash rebates and low-interest financing that used to be occasional treats for consumers or panic moves by manufacturers to rid themselves of slow sellers have become more or less permanent features of the marketing landscape. The cash rebates are climbing higher and higher, and the interest-rate offers are dropping to nothing.
 Buyers, however, need to be aware (if not exactly beware) that once a bargain becomes permanent, there is often a hitch. Manufacturers have raised prices for new models to compensate for rebates and other incentives. Another pricing strategy is to take features that used to be standard -- for example, antilock brakes -- and convert them to pay-extra options. 
 But even with such gimmicks, there are bargains. In fact, in the clearance sales of this summer, incentives set a record. In August, the average incentive hit $2,630 a vehicle, according to Edmunds.com, the online car-shopping site based in Santa Monica, Calif.
And incentives picked right up again with the new-car season this fall. General Motors announced on Oct. 1 a choice of cash rebates, ranging from $1,000 to $2,000 on 2004 models, or zero-interest financing. Ford Motor rolled out its Freestar minivan in late September with a choice of a $1,000 rebate or low-interest financing in tow.
Zero-interest financing, unheard of until two years ago when G.M. and other carmakers offered it to start car sales rolling after 9/11, is now routinely offered on five-year financing. Interest rates as low as 1.9 percent are showing up on six- and seven-year loans, almost unheard of at any interest rate until recently. In fact, eight-year loans are cropping up as well.
Detroit is the place to look for whopping cash rebates and no-interest financing for new cars and trucks. Chrysler, Ford and G.M. offered late-summer incentives averaging $3,687 a vehicle, an industry record, according to Edmunds. By contrast, the Europeans averaged late summer incentives of $1,752 a vehicle; the Koreans, $1,484; and the Japanese, $1,032. Jesse Toprak, Edmunds's director of pricing and market analysis, predicted that new incentives records would be set in November and December, with Detroit again leading the charge.
The biggest incentives are on large sport utility vehicles, vans and large cars, according to Edmunds. Sports cars, luxury S.U.V.'s and compact S.U.V.'s have the lowest.
A less obvious way to hold a sale is for the manufacturers to pay incentives to dealers, instead of to consumers. The dealer then uses the incentive to market the car. A smart consumer can negotiate a better deal by knowing about a dealer's incentive, which is listed by online car-buying services like Edmunds. Dealer incentives of up to $10,500 a car helped to push Jaguar, owned by Ford, to the top of the incentive charts in late summer among brands. The Swedish automaker Saab, owned by G.M., was second with an average incentive of $4,038.
"In most cases, incentives are required to reduce the price of a vehicle to a level consumers think is more appropriate," said Daniel Gorrell, vice president of Strategic Vision, a San Diego consulting firm. "Manufacturers have to resort to incentives when the brand and product are not strong."
Mr. Gorrell points to the contrast in Ford's Freestar minivan, introduced to the market with an incentive, and the 2004 Toyota Sienna, a redesigned minivan that went on sale last spring. The Toyota sells at close to list price with no incentives and has a waiting list of buyers, Mr. Gorrell said, adding that many consumers see value as not just a cheap price but also as reliability, durability and resale value.
Resale value should be an important consideration for the consumer who intends to sell or trade in a car every few years, and heavy incentives hurt resale values. So the big incentive may not be worth it. (Resale values can be found at online buying services like Edmunds or in used-car pricing guides like Kelley Blue Book (www.kbb.com).
Automotive Lease Guide, a Santa Barbara, Calif., company that establishes the value of a vehicle at the end of a lease, which also applies to used cars, reported that three-year-old cars from Chrysler, Ford and G.M. declined sharply in value the last year. In 2003, a three-year-old vehicle from those manufacturers is worth only 39 percent of its original sales price, compared with 45 percent a year ago. Three-year-old foreign cars are worth 47 percent of their sticker prices after three years, a number that has held steady in recent years. The Japanese automaker Honda and its luxury Acura division have the highest resale value at 52 percent after three years. 
Resale value is also critical for a consumer who wants to buy a new car before paying off the existing one. He may find himself in an increasingly common situation known in the industry as "upside down." In such cases, the car owner owes more on the loan for the vehicle than what the vehicle is worth. He then must pay off the loan before buying another car or roll the balance of the loan into a new loan for a new vehicle. 
Buying a car from the previous model year in the fall, when the new model year starts, is generally a solid strategy. Manufacturers pay dealers cash incentives and often offer consumer rebates or low-interest loans to clear the old models from dealer lots to make room for the new ones. As autumn passes into winter, the incentives on the previous year's models can grow bigger. For instance, in the recent round of incentives announced by G.M., rebates on 2003 models ranged from $2,000 to $4,000, compared with $1,000 to $2,000 on newer models; the list of eligible 2003 vehicles was far longer than the list of 2004 models. 
As time passes, however, the selection dwindles. That may not matter if a consumer does not care about a car's color or options. And buying at the end of any month can be a good bet. Incentives often come in the form of contests that pay dealers for meeting certain sales targets. Those incentives usually expire at the end of a month.
Consumers should also consider how long they intend to keep a vehicle when they are trying to decide on the better deal -- a cash rebate or low- or no-interest financing. The cash rebate is probably the best bet if the buyer intends to sell or trade in within two to three years. The low- to no-interest financing might be a better option if the buyer wants to keep the vehicle for a long time.
Indeed, consumers are taking on loans with increasingly longer terms. Mr. Toprak of Edmunds says that two years ago, the average loan was 53 months; today it is 59 months.
In the end, the incentive game is a reminder of the axiom that there is no free lunch. There is far more to consider in buying a car than a big fat incentive or long-term low-interest financing. "Value," said Mr. Gorrell of Strategic Vision, "is more than just a cheap price."

HEADLINE: WHAT THEY DRIVE; 
Guys Mod Up to Solve Their Midlife Minivan Minicrisis

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY

 BODY:
JIM NYE was not what you would call a minivan kind of guy. Mr. Nye, a 47-year-old special education teacher from Ventura, Calif., spent his free time tinkering with cars like Porsches or the Mini Cooper. With his first two children, he chose a sedan over a van.
 But when he and his wife, Cathi, adopted a child with cerebral palsy last year, they needed room for a wheelchair, and he became the reluctant driver of a Honda Odyssey. "It wasn't something I initially desired," Mr. Nye said. "I used to be one of the people who made fun of them." 
 So he did what came naturally to him -- decked it out with features like a high-end radio, a PlayStation game console, an oversize front grille and a red-flame paint job. 
The teenagers in his town feel that he has broken the rules of tuning, or modifying cars for performance and style. "That's not fair," one told him. "You're not supposed to look twice at a minivan."
Minivans, which were introduced by Chrysler in 1984, are more often decorated with spilled Cheerios than spoilers. But scattered around are a few proud individuals like Mr. Nye, who look upon these loaf-shaped kiddie movers as things of beauty. Or at least good candidates for a makeover.
These redoers are not proverbial soccer moms, said Jerry Tagliano, a manager at the Erebuni Corporation, an aftermarket parts company in Brooklyn. They are mostly men who have reached the minivan stage of life but still hear the refrain from "Born to Be Wild."
"The husbands are the ones who had the muscle cars in the 70's and 80's, and now they are dads," said Mr. Tagliano, whose company is one of the few that sells stylish accessories in the United States for minivans. "Maybe they have a Corvette, they have a Mustang. Now, they have the minivan."
Fitz Eusebio, 27, a student and enhanced Odyssey owner from Southern California, agreed. "Modifying stays in your blood until you grow out of it, I guess," he said, "which I don't think will happen to me."
If you browse Web sites like cardomain .com, an online forum where car owners brag about their modifications, you will see a surprising number of people posting photos of their spruced-up minivans, particularly Caravans, Odysseys and Mazda MPV's, which Mr. Tagliano said were dressed and pampered most often. Some owners go for subtle upgrades like clear taillights, carbon- fiber dashes and alloy wheels, while others give their vans new silhouettes, lowering their suspensions and bulking up with ground effects. Some younger owners, who got their minivans as hand-me-downs from parents or grandparents, quickly add details like neon lights under the seats that flash in time with the stereo. But they admit that they leave themselves open to jeers.
Eric Sebalos, 33, a stay-at-home father of two in Jersey City and a longtime modifier, saw great potential in the minivan. He willingly switched last year from a fully modified Ford Expedition, with an air-bagged suspension and a supercharger, to a silver 2001 Odyssey.
"When I first got it, my friends and family were like, 'What are you doing with a minivan?' " Mr. Sebalos said.
But he had a plan, and so far, he has added a body kit, lip spoilers, two 13.3-inch flip-down TV monitors and a PlayStation. The audio system is constantly changing; the car is on its third suspension system; Mr. Sebalos also plans to add a computer to control his systems through a touch screen.
"Reactions are mixed, but 90 percent think it's hot looking and didn't think a minivan could look so nice," he said in an e-mail interview. "Even the younger kids are into the van, being that it's modded up."
Granted, you would be hard pressed to find a Ford Windstar making a cameo in "The Fast and the Furious." But some car companies are trying other ways of fighting the Mommymobile connotation. For 2005, General Motors has redesigned its Venture and Montana minivans to look more like sport utility vehicles and is even backing away from the "M" word, introducing them as "crossover sport vans."
Nissan calls its 2004 Quest a minivan ("We don't skirt around the issue," a spokesman, John Schilling, said) but has given it one of the most sports-car-like styling the genre has ever seen, hoping that it will attract parents who care what their ride looks like. In one Quest television commercial, a group of wives take the van out for a night on the town while their husbands stay home and watch the children.
The ultimate goal is to duplicate the emotional bond that forms between buyers and less utilitarian models. Buying a minivan has never been an emotional purchase, Mr. Schilling said: "It was 'I need a minivan because I have kids.' People just didn't want to be seen in them."
The makers of minivans could benefit from a spokeswoman like Charlotte de Vera. Also known as Momma C or Turbo Mom, Ms. de Vera, 55, is a minor celebrity at racetracks, where she races her turbo-charged, nitrous-fed Odyssey.
Why a minivan? "I've always been a wagon-and-minivan lady," she said. "I'm such a people person; I like to pile in a lot of people."
She also has a son, R .J., who modifies cars and is willing to do all the work, including a gold paint job for her 50th birthday. The novelty earns him a lot of "props."
"I get a lot of twentysomethings and thirtysomethings who say, 'I saw your mom's van and it totally inspired me to do ours,' " he said. 
But modifying a minivan is more difficult than changing a sports car, he said, because aftermarket parts are harder to find and many pieces have to be custom made.
In Japan, however, the story is different. There, minivans are respected for their practicality and, yes, suave looks. Aftermarket manufacturers offer a range of add-on aerodynamic parts to accentuate the cars' clean lines, and auto competitions commonly include a category for vans.
On his trips to Japan, Mr. Tagliano has seen gatherings where hundreds of families take their well-appointed boxes, popping their hatches to show off the interiors.
"We started introducing minivan products with the hope that there would be a transition of the market from Japan to here," he said. "It didn't happen."
Dempsey Bowling, 33, a car salesman in Provo, Utah, has seen many men buy S.U.V.'s when they actually need minivans because they fear looking foolish.
"The funny thing is, that fear is unfounded," Mr. Bowling said. "When you drive a van, people don't even notice you at all."
Which increases what Mr. Bowling calls "the whole surprise factor" -- the dropped jaws when his blue '89 Dodge Caravan does the quarter mile in 14.4 seconds on the track in Salt Lake City. He got the idea for racing minivans while he was tweaking other Chryslers, surprising his competitors with his souped-up econoboxes.
"I thought, if it's fun to beat a Mustang in an Omni," he said, "it must be hilarious in a minivan."
Minivans make good racing "sleepers," Mr. Bowling said. His 1989 Caravan dates to a two-year period when the cars came equipped with turbo-charged engines. They generally weigh less and handle better than S.U.V.'s. To further reduce the weight, Mr. Bowling, a bachelor, took out the air-conditioning, insulation, spare tire and rear seats.
"I like to joke with my friends it's a two-seat sports car with a huge trunk," he said.
He has beaten Camaros and other muscle cars; now, he even sometimes has trouble finding people to race.
"They don't want to be seen losing to a minivan," he said "and I can understand that."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA/MOTOR CITY; 
Some Green Machines Swim in the Mainstream

BYLINE:  By BRADEN PHILLIPS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
LAWRENCE ANG never intended to be environmentally correct. He wanted a new car with an economical price tag, good gas mileage and looks he liked. By choosing a Ford Focus, he also got a car with tailpipe emissions so low they are often cleaner than the ambient air in smoggy urban areas.
 "To be honest, I never considered the low emissions, and didn't really find out about it until after I bought it," said Mr. Ang, 36, a computer technician who lives here. "But it never hurts. I'm hoping it means I will have years of no trouble with smog tests." 
 Mr. Ang is not the only person who bought a Focus this year, thinking it was no different from other cars. Most of them are no different, but the ones sold in California and some other states are partial zero emission vehicles, or P.Z.E.V.'s (as are 11 additional brands made by seven other manufacturers). Though these vehicles burn gasoline, more than 90 percent of their smog-producing emissions are removed, compared with the average new car. 
This is the first year that automakers have mass-produced the P.Z.E.V., and the car is not well known among consumers. Compared with the hoopla surrounding hybrids (cars powered by gas and electric motor), which are currently on the market, and hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (a combination of hydrogen and water that creates electricity), which are a decade from assembly lines, its arrival on the market has been muted. (A third alternative to fossil fuel, the battery-powered engine, is regarded as too impractical for most everyday use.)
"The more advanced technologies, the ones getting away from gasoline, are the sexier technologies," said Alan C. Lloyd, chairman of the California Air Resources Board, the regulatory agency that in 1990 required automakers to mass-produce zero-emission vehicles, or Z.E.V.'s, setting off the search for nonpolluting cars. 
"But in terms of breathing cleaner air," Dr. Lloyd added, "it is easier for companies to come out with hundreds of thousands of P.Z.E.V.'s than the more revolutionary technologies."
Evaporative emissions from the engine and fuel tank of a P.Z.E.V. are almost nonexistent.
And the price of these cars is either the same as regular models or slightly higher (about $200 at most), depending on the manufacturer. P.Z.E.V.'s range from $13,000 for a Ford Focus compact to $28,000 for a BMW 325i sedan. Horsepower is roughly the same, as is fuel efficiency. Moreover, all P.Z.E.V.'s have a 15-year or 150,000-mile warranty on the smog controls.
"The beauty of the technology is that manufacturers are applying it to cars that everyday people can buy," said Jerry Martin, a spokesman for the California air board. "And with the warranty, second or third owners, who are frequently lower-income, will have a car running like new."
Automakers sell P.Z.E.V.'s only where they are mandated, in California and those states that have adopted its tough air-quality standards, Massachusetts, New York and Vermont. The cars are therefore not nationally advertised, making it difficult for them to shed their obscurity. Maine, which adopted a less stringent version of the California mandate, will also get P.Z.E.V.'s from some manufacturers. About 135,000 P.Z.E.V.'s will be sold nationwide this year, 100,000 of which will go to the California market, according to the air board. By 2012, the agency estimates that the state will have 3.4 million such cars on the roads. 
To convert regular models, automakers have spent an average of several hundred dollars on each car. 
With uncertain market demand, higher production costs make manufacturers hesitant to produce more P.Z.E.V.'s, especially when their profits are being squeezed by the current competitive market. The other concern to manufacturers is the warranty, which would be harder to meet in states outside California, where gasoline formulations are not as clean. 
The marketing approach to these vehicles is typified by Nissan, which came out with the first P.Z.E.V., in 2000, the Sentra CA. (The company produced only a small number, limited to the California market.)
"Some of the research we've done shows consumers think there is a trade-off between environmental friendliness and other attributes," said Ken Zapp, a Nissan executive. "We don't downplay it, but it's not the primary selling point." Carmakers worry that consumers will think that P.Z.E.V.'s performances will suffer at the expense of their environmental virtues. 
Only Ford is breaking from the pack, having recently completed its first television advertisement highlighting the Focus's virtues. The ad, titled "Cleaner and Meaner," will be broadcast in California and the Northeast.
"We've got nothing to be ashamed of," said Rich Stoddart, the Ford Division marketing communications manager. "We're terrificallyproud of a power train that delivers environmental friendliness and more performance than you might expect."
Foreign manufacturers, especially Honda, Toyota and Nissan, led the way toward developing P.Z.E.V. technology, selling such versions of the Accord, Camry and Sentra, respectively. The other P.Z.E.V.'s are the Volvo S60 and S70, the Volkswagen Jetta, the Subaru Legacy L and Outback and versions of the BMW 325 series. Ford is currently the only American automaker producing P.Z.E.V.'s. Several foreign companies and Ford are coming out with additional models in 2004.
Ron Cogan, the editor and publisher of the Green Car Journal, a magazine based in San Luis Obispo, Calif., that covers cars and the environment, thinks that Ford will spur the competition to do likewise.
"Automakers haven't had the best crystal ball when it comes to environmental regulation and marketing green cars," Mr. Cogan said. "But environmental benefits are going to become a competitive issue and another buying criteria."
The California air board and the other states that have adopted its standards consider the P.Z.E.V. clean enough to earn manufacturers a partial credit toward the zero emission vehicle mandate, which takes effect in 2005. But how manufacturers meet that mandate varies with the number of credits they have earned, and which technologies they have chosen to develop. Ford, for example, is putting most of its stock in its P.Z.E.V. engine, and plans to offer it as an option on all Focus cars in 2004, expecting to sell 69,000 by next year. A total of 240,000 Focuses were sold for the 2003 model year. 
General Motors has not committed to a P.Z.E.V. as part of its strategy to comply with California's mandate.
"If we come to market with P.Z.E.V.'s, it won't be until 2005 to 2010," said Dave Barthmuss, a G.M. spokesman. "Our goal is to establish the commercial viability of hydrogen fuel cells. We see that as the ultimate endgame."
The greening of the gasoline engine is a result of many small improvements and not any one significant change.
Partial zero emission vehicles have better fuel combustion, extremely precise valve-control and fuel-injection systems and exhaust control that instantly eliminate cold-start emissions. Evaporative emissions are cut by tighter gaskets, hoses and fuel tanks.
The next challenge for automakers is for them to adapt P.Z.E.V. technology to pickups and sport utility vehicles, a more difficult task because these engines use much larger volumes of gas and oxygen. Still, automotive engineers think that P.Z.E.V. technology will make it onto S.U.V.'s before hydrogen fuel cell cars hit the mass market. (Toyota and Ford will produce hybrid S.U.V.'s next year.)
Environmentalists hail the P.Z.E.V. and California's lead in improving air quality. But they also point out that though two of the pollutants that contribute to global warming, nitrous oxide and methane, are reduced by P.Z.E.V.'s, the main culprit, carbon dioxide, is not. 
"The next frontier in California is tackling global warming, especially carbon dioxide emissions," said Roland Hwang, a senior policy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "We've been doing well on smog, but with global warming we've been going backwards over the past 15 years."

HEADLINE: MARKETING; 
Appealing to Youth, Selling to the Not-So-Young

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

 BODY:
THE vehicle rumbles down a traffic-free city street, a trail of fast-flying papers in its wake. It is a Cadillac Escalade, turning the heads of 30-somethings, as rock music -- not too loud, mind you -- plays in the background.
 This television commercial ends before you see anyone driving the Escalade. If you did, chances are he or she would look a bit grayer than the gape-mouthed bystanders on the street in the advertisement. The buyers of this youth-oriented Cadillac are, on average, a not-so-youthful 46 years old -- precisely the age of the average buyer of a new car in the United States. 
 As the American population grows older and as new car prices rise (even with incentives), the average buyer of new vehicles has ventured far into middle age. Among the major automakers, the average buyer's age ranges from 41 years old for the Volkswagen and Mitsubishi to 64 for the Buick. 
"Yet you are never going to see those cars driven by old people in a commercial," said Karl Brauer, the editor in chief of www.edmunds.com, the car-buying advisory Web site. "There is one general rule that people in the auto industry swear by: you can sell a young person's car to an old man, but you can't sell an old man's car to anyone."
Still, there are apparently many older men and women buying new cars these days, even some models many might consider "young."
According to figures from J. D. Power & Associates, for instance, the average buyer of a new Thunderbird is 53 years old. For the PT Cruiser, it's 50; the Corvette, 48; and the MX-5 Miata, 50.
While General Motors will be discontinuing "not your father's" Oldsmobile in 2004, it should become clear to people in their 40's and 50's that they, at least in their car buying, have become their fathers.
"I made a lot of buying decisions about automobiles when I was 18 that have absolutely no relevance today," said Bob Garfield, 48, who reviews advertisements for Advertising Age and is a co-host of "On the Media," a programshow on National Public Radio. "As recently as 10 years ago, my buying habits would have been different."
"But advertisers are obsessed with marketing to the 18-to-34-year-old demographic, so that is what their campaigns even for older car buyers are geared to," he continued. "Of course, that makes no sense whatsoever demographically because the largest pool of discretionary dollars in the history of humanity resides in the baby boom."
Yet the ruse is to make older car buyers think they are buying a "younger" car. For the last two years, for example, Cadillac has used excerpts from Led Zeppelin's "Rock and Roll" in its commercials.
"They are trying to bring about a young feeling," Mr. Brauer said, adding that the song itself is 32 years old. "The hope is that the music, which baby boomers may have listened to when they were young, will make them think young and buy a hip Cadillac."
Cadillac thinks the campaign has worked in attracting younger buyers. Company figures show that the average age of a new Cadillac buyer is 59 today, compared with 65.5 two years ago. 
"The Escalade, especially, has been a huge success in that regard," said Kelly Cusinato, a Cadillac spokeswoman. "It has been the vehicle of choice among some Hollywood folks and athletes, even though we've never particularly marketed it that way."
In contrast to the Escalade, the average buyer's age of the Cadillac Seville is 62 and the DeVille is 66.
Art Spinella of CNW Marketing Research, an automative research company in Bandon, Ore., said that the average age of the new car buyer had risen faster than the population at large for many reasons: a slower economy for young job-seekers; the availability of certified used cars; and the trend of older buyers to buy new cars more often. 
But Mr. Spinella said that marketing "young" has advantages even if the young person is not buying immediately. He has developed a Stodgy Index, a rating based on a long questionnaire given to people 24 years old or younger to find out how "old" they think certain cars are. 
"Cadillac and Mercedes are prime examples," Mr. Spinella said. "If you are 18, you might want to one day own one, but just not right now." 
The top five "stodgy" cars on the company's list are Buick, Oldsmobile, Lincoln, Mercury and, surprisingly, Audi. The first four all have average new-car buying ages of more than 50 years old, but Audi's is only 43. Volkswagens, Porsches and Kias, all of which have average buying ages in the 40's, are the least stodgy on the list.
Mercedes-Benz, like Cadillac, seems to be trying to appeal to the youthful yearnings of its presumably older buyer.
A recent advertising supplement in The New Yorker featured Nicole Kidman with a Mercedes key in her hand and a come-hither look.
Other photos showed stylish people seemingly in their mid-20's lounging on and about Mercedes sedans. But while there are certainly not many in that age group buying the Mercedes (the average buyer's age is 48), it is obviously the image of youth that counts.
Honda, which does relatively well at attracting younger buyers (the average age is 44), but lands in the midrange of the Stodgy Index, has been particularly aggressive in seeking young buyers.
"Honda sent us for training on how to sell younger people on the Element," said Peter Perrotta, a former Honda salesman who now sells Jaguars for Cherry Hill Classic Cars in New Jersey. The Element is a four-wheel drive short S.U.V., whose polyurethane floors are specifically designed to carry snowboards, skis and the like. 
"They told us to let young buyers control the sales process, which goes against everything everyone says about older buyers," Mr. Perrotta said. "Older people are less independent, so the salesman controls things, which is maybe why they buy more new cars."
Not every automaker that rates high on the Stodgy Index appears to be trying to appeal to younger drivers. Last year, Buick ran an ad that featured an actor impersonating Harley Earl, the premier car designer at General Motors in the 40's and 50's.
Even though Earl's image was paired with Tiger Woods as a pitchman, more than a few young watchers were probably left scratching their heads.
Ads aside, automakers are not completely unaware of the real demographics of their customers. The minivan, for instance, would naturally seem to be a vehicle for younger people; it is family-oriented and utilitarian. But the average age of buyers for Ford's Windstar is 48, while its more expensive S.U.V., the Expedition, is 42. "Technically, the commercials market to 30-somethings with kids," Mr. Brauer said. "But the automakers know that the market for minivans is expanding to grandparents."
" The sliding doors make it easy to get in. They travel a lot and carry stuff with them. And when they get to the grandkids' house, they have the van to take them around in. My in-laws own an Olds Silhouette. You won't see them in a commercial, but they know when they see the ad they can cart the grandkids around in a minivan."
Just as soccer moms do not buy only minivans, not every Lincoln Town Car is driven by old folks. The average age of new buyers of Town Cars, which is 67, does not reflect the many bought by fleet operators. But the sales to older people are important enough to Lincoln that it at times gives a discount to AARP members.
Even so, Lincoln does want to ensure that its buyers remember their youth, or something closer to it. 
Its new spokesman is a basketball star, smooth, successful -- and 44-year-old -- Magic Johnson.

HEADLINE: CUSTOM-MADE; 
Mixing Rough Roads With Home Comforts

BYLINE:  By ALICIA AULT

 BODY:
WHEN most people dream about rumbling down back roads, cutting through canyons and climbing mountains, they usually fantasize about doing it in a Hummer or a Land Rover -- something big and brawny, tested on the Serengeti Plain or in a Middle Eastern desert. For a small, dedicated group of outdoor enthusiasts, though, the preferred way to go off-road is in a four-wheel-drive Sportsmobile van camper.
 At first, it looks like a conventional cargo van. But then you notice the oversize knobby tires, the nerf bars (custom bumpers), the fog lights and the high ground clearance. It says rough and tough, but in a friendly package. The Sportsmobile has a galley kitchen, sleeping space for four, a hot-water heater and a chemical toilet. 
 The first Sportsmobile was a do-it-yourself Volkswagen van customized in the late 1950's by Curtis Borsky, a tinkerer from Indiana. After his buddies saw it, he began to make more. Realizing he was onto something, Mr. Borsky approached VW, which gave him an exclusive license to modify its popular van in 1961.
The pop-topped VW van was an icon in that decade, a symbol of freedom, peace, love and understanding. It was so successful, a German company called Westfalia got in on the act, driving Mr. Borsky out of business with VW. The last VW customized by Sportsmobile rolled off the line in 1967.
But the company was also converting Ford, Chevrolet and Dodge vans, adding galleys, pop-tops and other touches. Sportsmobile sells only 350 four-wheel-drive campers a year but draws the same free-spirited buyer that it did in the 60's, said Alan Feld, the president of Sportsmobile West, the West Coast division of the company.
"We view ourselves as the Harley-Davidson of the RV world," Mr. Feld said, adding that a custom Sportsmobile takes four to six months to complete and costs $40,000 to $80,000. The company also sells a clothing line and brings owners together for adventure trips. (For more information, see the Web site at www.sportsmobile.co.) 
For four-wheel-drive models, Sportsmobile orders a bare cargo-van chassis -- the Ford E-350 Econoline Super Duty -- and adds off-road and interior components. Until June, the 4-by-4 component was added by Quigley Motor Company, in Manchester, Pa. Customers can now choose between Quigley or Sportsmobile, which is doing its own 4-by-4 conversions at its 60,000-square-foot plant in Fresno, Calif. The van comes with a 5.4-liter V-8 Triton, 6.8-liter V-10 Triton or 7.3-liter turbo diesel engine. According to Mr. Feld, 90 percent of buyers choose the diesel, which has better fuel economy at about 18 miles a gallon. Interiors are finished in Fresno or at Sportsmobile's Austin, Tex., or Huntington, Ind., plants. 
Mr. Feld, a former semiconductor salesman, bought a Sportsmobile in 1989, inspired by the first one he saw. After a year of being chased through parking lots, flagged down on highways and finding notes on his windshield asking about his van, he persuaded Sportsmobile to let him open a West Coast division, and he quit his job. 
A Sportsmobile draws the curious in droves. "I call it a 'man magnet,' " said Janine Petersen, 39, who has witnessed the phenomenon over the last nine summers while on the road with her husband, Craig, 55, in their 4-by-4 Sportsmobile.
Mrs. Petersen is a naturalist with the Orange County Department of Education in Newport Beach, Calif., and Mr. Petersen teaches biology and environmental science at Mount San Antonio College in Walnut, Calif. Their Sportsmobile, an extended version of the Ford E-350 with a turbo-diesel V-8, also tows a Sportsmobile-designed off-road trailer, loaded with mountain bikes, kayaks and coolers. The Petersens bought their first Sportsmobile for $50,000 in 1994, eight years after seeing one at an RV show. As former tent campers who did not care for supersize motor homes, they still wanted to get away from it all with luxuries. (Sportsmobiles are eligible for 15-year motor-home financing.)
The Petersens sold that van eight years later, and on New Year's Day, toasted their newest one at the bottom of the Grand Canyon. This summer, they covered 8,500 miles in 13 states.
Gary Smith, 48, of Parker, Colo., saw his first Sportsmobile at the Outdoor Retailer show in Salt Lake City, an annual convention of outdoor gear makers and retail buyers. Since buying his Sportsmobile in November 2002, he has logged 48,000 miles, cruising Colorado and Utah ski resorts selling Volkl snowboards in the winter and MBS mountain boards in the summer. 
Like the Petersens, he has found the Sportsmobile to be a big draw, especially when parked near the bottom of a ski lift with music booming from the $4,000 Pioneer DVD-CD surround-sound system.
Mr. Smith's fire-engine-red van is like a billboard, plastered with Volkl and other sports-gear logos. The ads have helped cover his monthly Sportsmobile payment. And because he sleeps in his van, he estimates that he saves about $5,000 a month in hotel bills. (A room in Aspen at the height of ski season can cost $300 a night.) 
Driving last winter in white-out conditions over Vail Pass, Mr. Smith realized he might not make it home. So he pulled into a state park and hunkered down. Thanks to an inverter (a device that converts DC power to AC power), he ran his heater off batteries all night. Total silence descended with the accumulating snow. In the morning, as he warmed up a mug of hot chocolate, Mr. Smith watched as a herd of elk surrounded him. "It was the most therapeutic night I ever spent in my life," he said. 
The Sportsmobile owners' group Web site on Yahoo (autos.groups.yahoo.com/group /sportsmobile--owners/) is full of similar stories, as well as tips on maintenance, destinations, power sources and add-ons. When owners spot one another on streets, in parking lots or in the back country, they tend to become fast friends.
Owners have also influenced the vans' interiors. Windsurfers, for instance, are core buyers because the Sportsmobile is well suited for maneuvering to a choice spot like the Columbia River Gorge, where the winds are too strong for tent camping. So the company makes an interior suited for windsurfers, with Neoprene-covered seats, a marine-grade rubber floor liner, storage racks for boards and a storage compartment with a drain for wet gear.
Sportsmobile has also built vehicles for mountain bikes, including one for Brian Lopes, the sport's world champion. Kennan Ward, a well-known wildlife photographer, has helped design a signature model with lockable cabinets throughout the vehicle for storing tripods and Lowepro camera backpacks. Mr. Ward, who photographs animals in their natural settings, also came up with the idea of zip-off screens for the pop-top, making it easier to capture elusive subjects like grizzly bears. 
No matter how it is customized, the Sportsmobile seems to sell itself. "It's the kind of vehicle that when people see one, they've just got to have one," Mr. Feld said.

HEADLINE: THE INTERNET; 
Online, Used Car Lots That Cover the Nation

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN

 BODY:
STEFAN ROSEN of Huntington, N.Y., had given the chassis and transmission of his 1993 Dodge Dakota a thorough going-over long before he saw it. He spotted his $4,000 pickup among more than two million car listings on AutoTrader.com and flew to Detroit, where a representative of Extreme Dodge in Jackson, Mich., picked him up at the airport. Mr. Rosen test-drove the truck he had studied in high-resolution photographs online, bought it and drove it all the way home.
 In seeking buyers like Mr. Rosen, automakers and dealers invested hundreds of millions of dollars in Internet commerce ventures in the late 90's. Start-up companies promised that buying cars on the Internet would send auto dealers down the path of encyclopedia salesmen. And major newspapers, fearing competition for their lucrative classified car advertisements, even formed their own Web-based business, cars.com. 
 But the bursting of the dot-com bubble, coupled with car buyers' perpetual urge to kick the tires, has led to a rare harmony between computer clicks and test drives. For new cars, the Internet has changed the nature of haggling, as buyers compare Internet price quotes on vehicles in their region and either pick the lowest one or show up at the local dealership and demand that it be matched. 
For used cars, however, the change has been far more profound. The Internet has transformed a $376 billion market in which, according to CNW Marketing Research, almost 30 percent of the 42.6 million used cars sold in 2002 were bought using the Internet.
Used cars have always provided auto dealers with thousands of dollars more in profit per car than new ones. Last year, according to CNW, 12 million used cars were sold by individuals, 14 million by independent used-car dealers and 16 million by franchised dealers. Car experts say that the battle among cars.com, eBay, AutoTrader .com, autobytel.com, carmax.com and others for listings hinges on whose business model best suits dealers' advertising needs, as well as the buyers' ability to balance price with confidence in the transaction.
"The Internet has become an integral part of the used-car business," said Scott Weitzman, a senior director at J. D. Power & Associates. "Dealers have to be aggressive on the Internet to compete. Buyers do vast research by going to Kelley Blue Book and edmunds.com first, and then they go over to the transaction sites like AutoTrader and eBay. So both the buyer and the dealer save time and transaction costs, and these Web sites are fighting for the business of a very educated market."
Ebay, the Wall Street darling and dot-com survivor that has positioned itself as a middleman between sellers and buyers of items ranging from Lamborghinis to golf balls, started eBay Motors in 2000 and auctioned nearly $3 billion in cars last year. Half of eBay's listings come from dealers and half from individuals, and the company projects that its auctions will rise from 300,000 in 2002 to more than 500,000 in 2003, according to Simon Rothman, the global vice president of Ebay Motors.
"We have 10 million visitors and only tens of thousands of cars at any given time because we want more buyers than sellers," Mr. Rothman said of his efforts to keep eBay attracting car dealers nationwide. "We engender trust in the transaction by providing money-back guarantees and by giving the buyers an option to send their money to an escrow agent to delay payment until they test drive the vehicle." 
Ebay also concentrates on individually owned vehicles as well as inventory that dealers are having difficulty moving off the lot. It has also won a large portion of the specialty car market, which includes car collectors and people who want that rare Mustang.
The famed eBay business model, built on sight-unseen buying and good faith, meets a steep test when it comes to a business that has long been a byword for chicanery.
But many bidders have been happy with the results. Jan Small, of Sarasota, Fla., bought a 1997 Red BMW for $15,901 after a tense bidding battle. She says she will not hesitate to buy a car through eBay again.
"I printed out 15 pages of vehicle information and 24 photographs of the car before I bought it," Ms. Small said. "When I saw it, I felt like I knew it completely, little dings and all."
Ebay charges $40 for a car listing, and takes $40 when a car is sold. These fees are too steep for dealers like Wes Lutz, the Extreme Dodge owner in Michigan who sold Mr. Rosen his pickup.
"I prefer to pay a flat monthly fee with a company like AutoTrader," said Mr. Lutz, who managed the information technology committee for the National Auto Dealers Association for two years. "Ebay has that huge marketplace for all items, but cars are just a different commodity. The so-called kick of the tires is a necessity for our customer."
Mr. Rosen says he will never buy a used car without the test drive that brought him to Mr. Lutz's dealership. He said his $200 flight to Michigan saved him more than $2,000 on the truck.
"With cars, Internet buying just doesn't work," Mr. Rosen said. "To get under the hood, smell the interior -- sight-unseen buying is too tricky."
Instead, the dominant figure in the used-car market has become AutoTrader, which has captured 30 percent of the Internet transaction market, according to J. D. Power. (Among others, it says, eBay has 7 percent, cars.com 6 percent and carmax 11 percent, based on vehicles that are six years old or less.) Rather than carving out a direct path between buyers and sellers, AutoTrader has forged links with the traditional methods of selling cars: classified ads and used-car dealerships. 
AutoTrader's president and chief executive, Chip Perry, who was working on Internet ventures for The Los Angeles Times when he was hired by AutoTrader in 1997, said he thought that AutoTrader's online renovation of the old classifieds model accounted for the willingness of more than 40,000 dealers to list their inventories on AutoTrader's Web site. 
"We chose to focus on used cars from the very beginning," Mr. Perry said. "We thought the Internet offered dramatic potential to improve classified advertising, if we were willing to let go of the traditional newspaper business model of charging for every listing. Dealers could only afford to put 3 to 5 percent of their inventory in the paper, whereas now they can get everything up with photos for a monthly fee."
According to Mr. Perry, 10,000 dealers pay a $800 premium monthly fee to get higher placement on the site and to include extensive photographs. The site also sells ads to 250,000 private sellers who pay $45 to $75 for spaces with photographs and vehicle history. Buyers pay no fee. Experts say that this model allows dealers to lower their prices because of savings in advertising and transaction costs. 
One dealer who buys into the AutoTrader model is Mr. Lutz. He says his franchise sells approximately 25 used cars a month from the Internet and that AutoTrader generates the bulk of his online business.
"One of the strong points of AutoTrader for us is the weekly report they give us that tells me how many unique hits we are getting," Mr. Lutz said. "I know from this data that if I'm not selling cars, I'm not pricing or describing them correctly."
Dealers never heeded the prophecies that the Internet would render the business of middlemen irrelevant. Now they view sites like AutoTrader and eBay as tools that have helped refine their business and bolster their bottom lines.
"This is a much cheaper form of advertising than newspapers, with a much wider reach," said Jerry Murray, the Internet sales manager at Heritage Honda in Parkville, Md. "Though you will never be able to sell a car to a reasonable buyer sight unseen, the Internet helps buyers and dealers focus the transaction so much more quickly."

Buying or Selling
More people each year are buying or selling used cars over the Internet. In interviews, car experts, dealers and buyers offered this advice: 

Buyers
* Do not buy without taking a test-drive and having the vehicle checked by an independent mechanic.
* Print out quotes and pictures of similar cars from different dealers and use them as negotiating tools. 
* Before you fly to buy, ask the dealer for more photographs and information by e-mail.

Sellers
* Scan and post all records of the car's maintenance history. 
* Post only high-quality photographs: buyers will be suspicious of blurry images.
* More buyers are willing to fly long distances for the right car, so do not rule out faraway bids.
 GREGORY JORDAN
